    7. This is a highly recommended comment.

      Candice Lea

      logged in via Facebook

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      What is 'independent research?'

      Can you name an organisation suitably qualified to do these studies you consistently whinge for?

      Even if the 'funding' comes from the Government, the very same people you claim are corrupt are *still* the experts in this area.
      If you believe you have the skills to conduct such studies as a lay person, why haven't you done it?

      Scientific debate occurs in peer reviewed journals so that everyone around the world can see the evidence and with their own scientific research, conduct a study challenging those claims. That is how science works, with scientists.
      If you think you should be included in this debate, go get the qualifications necessary to contribute and do some work.

      Whinging and whining that you don't like the funding/scientist/qualifications/etc is not scientific debate. Contributing to the body of knowledge through well constructed, *ethical* research IS.

      Hi Elizabeth,

      "Citizens are entitled to ask well-founded questions about vaccination..."

      I agree wholeheartedly and encourage such. I question though, whether some citizens are willing to accept answers which are not in alignment with their views on the matter. I have come across many cases in which anti-vaccinationists have requested evidence for the safety and efficacy of vaccines or insights into the way phaemecutical trials work or public health decisions are made, only to ignore or dismiss it when it is presented to them. Calls to present and debate the evidence which are followed by refusals to acknowledge the evidence are tiring.

      I would also like to note that it is important to distinguish the difference between a concerned citizen who is questioning vaccine safety and policy and an anti-vaccination advocate who promotes herself as an authority on the safety and efficacy of vaccines and believes that she is on such equal footing with experts that she should be consulted when the media covers news relating to vaccine safety, vaccine innovation and epidemics of vaccine preventable diseases.

  9. Tim Niven

    Chinese Student and EFL Teacher at Tzu Chi University, Hualien City, Taiwan

    Nice one, Patrick.

    I can have whatever opinion I want, but there's no garuantee it will be respectable and not liable to merciless ridicule. And in some kind of "social regulatory" way, I hope ridiculous beliefs are mercilessly ridiculed - that's how I learned when I was a youngster (mis)educated in postmodern philosophy. I found like minded people in my classes easy to talk to, but as soon as I had to argue in the broader world I all of a sudden found people saying "what you're saying gives…

    Read more

    Nice one, Patrick.

    I can have whatever opinion I want, but there's no garuantee it will be respectable and not liable to merciless ridicule. And in some kind of "social regulatory" way, I hope ridiculous beliefs are mercilessly ridiculed - that's how I learned when I was a youngster (mis)educated in postmodern philosophy. I found like minded people in my classes easy to talk to, but as soon as I had to argue in the broader world I all of a sudden found people saying "what you're saying gives me no good reason to believe you" (at the polite end of the spectrum).

    And so if I actually want to have a conversation (a real one, where you are actually trying to convince someone of the truth or validity of what you're saying, and not just posturing and beating your chest), I very quickly learned that poorly reasoned, lazily argued, emotionally led argument was frustratingly ineffective with anyone who didn't already believe me anyway. And then of course if you think you're right but no-one has any respect for what you're saying, it can often force some important re-evaluation - if you're honest, or if your beliefs aren't so tightly coupled to your sense of identity and the world - like believers in the free market religion and climate change denial. Seems that's the best we can hope for form this kind of social regulatory approach, but there are unfortunate psychological facts mitigating against it. I did my philosophy honour's thesis (analytical philosophy by then) on "Intelligent Design". You can bang your head against the wall reading that literature. I have to share the best argument I ever read, from an evangelical philosophy journal though I unforunately lost the reference since the argument didn't make my paper:

    (1) As science progresses, it should explain more and more
    (2) But as science has progressed on its current course, it is increasinly unlikely that it will explain the virgin birth
    (C) Therefore, (yep, you guessed it) science is on the wrong path, we need Jesus as a scientific postulate, etc...

    And amazing analogies to climate change denial, reading through that literature.

    almost 2 years ago report

  10. Joseph Callingham

    Student of Astrophysics at University of Sydney

    Excellent article but we have to be careful. Who is to decide if an argument is bulldust? It is obvious in cases of vaccinations and astrology but when the issue becomes more contentious, who is to dictate which side gets to present their view?

    I do not mind someone presenting both sides of the argument of vaccinations as long as the journalist states that there is no peer reviewed data that support their claim etc. Leaves it to the audience to make their minds up for which argument is the strongest, removing an arbiter of public debate.

    almost 2 years ago report

    1. Geoffrey Edwards

      logged in via email @gmail.com

      In reply to Joseph Callingham

      "...who is to dictate which side gets to present their view?'

      I think Patrick's position is not so much about dictating who gets to present a view. It is about what views are deserving of our respect.

      It is the shift to pragmatic relativism in which all opinions are "equal"

      I say that Soctrate's mortality leads us to conclude that all humans are mortal. You say that Socrates humanity leads us to conclude that Socrates is mortal.

      One is valid, the other is not. I can state my case, but I cannot claim that my case should be respected just because it is my case when it is clearly not the case.

      almost 2 years ago report

      Read more

      Great article.

      I agree Joseph that we should not dictate debate but unfortunately I don't think the public and "current affair" shows such as Today Tonight would ever present both sides nor state that there is no scrap of peer reviewed data for one side of the debate because that wouldn't be sensational enough or draw a crowd. (Plus a lot of people wouldn't know what a peer review entails or how important real evidence is).

      The problem with vaccination though is that there was once a debate but that was over many years ago.
      It's quite disconcerting that anti-vaccination groups are still active in 2012. It's equivalent to someone believing the earth is flat.

      I work as a doctor and it pains me to see that propagating unscientific "opinion" by anti-vax groups is acceptable under the guise of free speech - surely they would need to work in the field or have research in the area?
      Doctors support vaccination because we have seen the difference in saving lives. My grandparents were doctors in the mid to late 1900s and saw many infectious diseases which are now preventable because of vaccines, whereas us docs of today work mainly in chronic diseases.

      It's also jolly selfish for people to refuse vaccinations for themselves or their children because the premise of vaccination is "herd immunity" i.e. population health and I don't think it is the right of one person to put others at risk by refusing immunisation when it is safe to do so and the evidence is unequivocal, unless it is for some exceptional reason.

      almost 2 years ago report

    4. account deleted

      logged in via email @gmail.com

      In reply to account deleted

      Science requires falsifiability, which requires reproducibility.

      I have no great knowledge of the vaccination topic, but I do have a sense that the good outweighs the bad, mostly because I have confidence that those who have done the research have done their best to falsify their hypotheses and that their results are reproducible.

      It's the scientific method I have confidence in, and that leads me to have confidence in the results that it produces.

    5. Meryl Dorey

      logged in via Facebook

      In reply to account deleted

      Again Craig, I agree with you. And I was always under the impression that those who had gone before had done their best to make sure that any evidence of dangers or ineffectiveness had been thoroughly investigated and that we would never use products on our children (or adults) which had been shown to have a benefits:risk ratio which was skewed towards the risks. Unfortunately, my research has shown that for a significant minority, the risks of vaccination far outweigh their benefits and those benefits…

      Read more

      Again Craig, I agree with you. And I was always under the impression that those who had gone before had done their best to make sure that any evidence of dangers or ineffectiveness had been thoroughly investigated and that we would never use products on our children (or adults) which had been shown to have a benefits:risk ratio which was skewed towards the risks. Unfortunately, my research has shown that for a significant minority, the risks of vaccination far outweigh their benefits and those benefits are themselves based upon the poorest of scientific theories - that the presence of antibodies equates to immunity.

      If antibodies don't equal immunity (and we know that they do not), then how are vaccines meant to prevent infection? I suggest that anyone who is interested in more information on this issue read the ebook - Vaccine Illusion by Harvard-trained immunologist, Tetyana Obuyhanych http://www.amazon.com/Vaccine-Illusion-ebook/dp/B007AW2CLG.

      Is there reason to be concerned about whether or not vaccines do what we have been told they do? Yes, there is and that reason is found within peer-reviewed science - not subject to interpretation.

      Is there reason to be concerned about whether or not vaccines can cause harm to a significant subset of those they are administered to? Yes, there is - and that information is found within peer-reviewed science - not subject to interpretation.

      Is there reason to worry about those who say that only those who toe the current medical party line should be heard or be able to participate in this scientific debate? I leave it to you to answer that question.

      almost 2 years ago report

It would be a fantastic starting point for you to begin to equip yourself with the skills and understanding to assess your information and argue your case from a more credible position.

    12. Biotic Factor

      logged in via Facebook

      In reply to account deleted

      "If antibodies don't equal immunity (and we know that they do not), then how are vaccines meant to prevent infection?"

      Ummm, Meryl - nobody has ever claimed that vaccines prevent infection. They prevent the development of disease subsequent to an infection. The difference between infection and disease is significant (have you heard of lag time?). Similarly, it is not the presence of antibodies that is said to confer immunity, but the presence of memory B cells. The difference between proteins and cells is also significant.

      It's surprising that in 20+ years of reading around the issue, you would make these elementary mistakes. Unless, of course, you have not understood what you have read.

      almost 2 years ago report

  13. This is a highly recommended comment.

    Meg Thornton

    Dilletante

    I quite like the view that the author John Scalzi puts of the matter: you're entitled to your own opinion, but you're not entitled to your own facts. Or in other words, if you want to put forward an opinion and have it *respected* (or use that opinion as a way of influencing others to share it) you need to be able to support your position with evidence, and to deal with evidence which opposes your opinion in a way other than by dismissing it entirely. If you can't support your position with equivalent…

    Read more

    I quite like the view that the author John Scalzi puts of the matter: you're entitled to your own opinion, but you're not entitled to your own facts. Or in other words, if you want to put forward an opinion and have it *respected* (or use that opinion as a way of influencing others to share it) you need to be able to support your position with evidence, and to deal with evidence which opposes your opinion in a way other than by dismissing it entirely. If you can't support your position with equivalent evidence to the opposing view, why should I respect your position?

    I'd be much more willing to deal with the anti-vaxers, the flat-earthers, the global climate change deniers, the intelligent design crowd and all these other contra-science positions if ANY of them were willing to deal with the evidence as it stands at present, particularly where that evidence points toward a contradiction of their position. Instead, these sorts of groups show a profound tendency to want to cherry-pick the facts, dealing only with the ones which support their position, and ignoring the ones which point in opposite directions.

    So, for example, the anti-vaccination crowd (both in the USA and here in Australia) tends to point to the increase in diagnoses of autism spectrum disorders as being evidence that vaccines are harmful[1]. Now, there's two possible reasons for the increase in diagnoses. One of these is that there's more cases of autism around; more children are developing disorders on the autism spectrum. The other possible reason runs like this: the base level of ASD cases is the same as it always was, and we're just getting better at *diagnosing* them. I tend to support the latter explanation, since this explains the level of ADULT ASD diagnosis which is occurring. It's not that there's more around, it's just that we're better at spotting what we're looking at for what it is.

    (My own contention is that ASD conditions have ALWAYS been with us - it's just that each generation found its own way to bull through the whole business).

    However, the anti-vaccination crew don't want to deal with the phenomenon of adult ASD diagnosis. They don't want to have to deal with that fact, because it means their nice, neat, seamless explanation for the world starts to develop some holes. In the same way, the flat-earth movement doesn't deal well with photographs from space; the intelligent design people don't cope well with the theory of evolution being able to be used as a predictive tool; climate change deniers argue endlessly that unusual weather multiple years in a row doesn't mean the climate is changing. The people in these groups won't actually deal with evidence which doesn't go the way they want it to.

    [1] I'm not going to bother with debunking the link between ASD and vaccination. That's been done already, and by better people than myself.

    almost 2 years ago report

  14. Russell Walton

    Retired

    We're not all learned philosophers, or philosophy students, members of the public are entitled to their opinions because of the possibility that their opinions might indeed be correct.

    That said, the possibility that the opinions of unqualified climate change sceptics or anti-vaccinators might be valid, is very small. "To each his own trade." There's certainly no obligation to give fringe opinions publicity, I'm certainly irritated when lawyers, economists and scientists with irrelevant qualifications pontificate on climate change. The real problem is not that people express looney opinions but that they are taken seriously by significant sections of the public--that's a failure of our education system.

    Commercial 'news' services are not in the business of disseminating facts or reasoned opinions.

    almost 2 years ago report

    1. Christopher Chen

      Software Engineer

      In reply to Russell Walton

      "We're not all learned philosophers, or philosophy students, members of the public are entitled to their opinions because of the possibility that their opinions might indeed be correct."

      If I'm reading Stokes's post correctly, he would agree that members of the public are all absolutely "allowed-to-say"-entitled to have their opinions, full stop. (And they're "entitled"-entitled to have opinions, but only some of the time, depending on how well they can vouch for them.)

      I'm vaguely miffed that he's introduced two definitions for the same phrase. It makes it impossible to tell whether commenters on this article are talking at cross purposes :(

      almost 2 years ago report

  19. Peter Bowditch

    IT consultant and teacher

    I would love to comment extensively on this article, but due to an ongoing court case I have to be careful about what I say in public about certain matters. The court case is about my right to express an opinion which is contrary to someone else's opinion, an opinion which I think is wrong. The person taking the action against me claims to be in favour of free speech and is even on record as saying that they encourage people to disagree with them and have never tried to suppress contrary opinion…

    Read more

    I would love to comment extensively on this article, but due to an ongoing court case I have to be careful about what I say in public about certain matters. The court case is about my right to express an opinion which is contrary to someone else's opinion, an opinion which I think is wrong. The person taking the action against me claims to be in favour of free speech and is even on record as saying that they encourage people to disagree with them and have never tried to suppress contrary opinion.

    As part of never suppressing contrary opinion they have banned me from at least two Internet mailing lists, blocked me from commenting on Facebook pages, blocked me from following them on Twitter, refused to allow my comments on blogs to pass moderation (even on blog articles mentioning me by name) and announced that any emails from me will be deleted unread.

    I have promised never to do any of these things in response. People are entitled to their opinions, no matter how wrong those opinions are. They don't, however, have an automatic entitlement to be taken seriously.

    almost 2 years ago report

    1. Scott Hansen

      Web developer

      In reply to Peter Bowditch

      Indeed. For someone that bangs on about censorship, she sure does being a complete and utter hypocrite.

      almost 2 years ago report

    2. Meryl Dorey

      Public Officer at Australian Vaccination Network, Inc.

      In reply to Peter Bowditch

      For everyone else here who would like to make this a debate about me personally, I will not be participating. The issue raised in this article is - do people who are critical of a belief held by the mainstream establishment have a right to express their side of the vaccination issue. I believe that they do - if they can provide evidence to back up their assertions. I can provide evidence - it's just that 'science' as it is practised today - does not like to examine evidence contrary to currently-held dogma.

      So perhaps the question isn't - do those who are critical of vaccination have a right to express their opinions and present their evidence in public. Instead, the question should be - are scientists mature enough to examine evidence when it is presented to them - even if that evidence flies in the face of what they believed to be true.

      almost 2 years ago report

      Meryl, if you haven't noticed, this article uses the first half to destroy what it is you spout on a daily basis. This article is not only regarding the right to an opinion, it is about how you *personally* try to make opinion as valid, if not *more* valid than objective fact.

      Cry all you want about people taking you to task for your lack of qualifications/education on the topic, thing is - this is exactly what this article is all about.

      "do people who are critical of a belief held by the mainstream establishment have a right to express their side of the vaccination issue. I believe that they do - if they can provide evidence to back up their assertions."

      If they actually knew what they were talking about, then sure. Thing is - the vast majority of the anti vax movement don't have a clue about what they are rabbiting on about.

      You made the claim on WIN news that vaccines (not just the usual tired argument re: MMR), *all* vaccines can cause autism. Strangely enough - there is absolutely NO evidence to back this assertion of yours.

      "I can provide evidence - it's just that 'science' as it is practised today - does not like to examine evidence contrary to currently-held dogma."

      Oh really? Of course it does. This is at the heart of science, testing, falsifiable evidence and testing. If one hypothesis has more evidence to back it than another, then that is where we look.

      Thing is, I have not seen any evidence come from your circle that backs a single thing you say. You have not conducted any trials or studies yourself via use of the scientific method. You do not have any contrary evidence to supply in regards to currently accepted evidence.

      Your whole argument rests on conspiracy theory - that the scientific "elite" are somehow covering up the "real" research and that people such as yourself are purposely being silenced by supposed vested interests.

      This isn't the case at all. What is happening is that people are taking you to task for your ridiculous assertions, they are advising you that you are wrong, on so many levels.

      On so, so many levels.

    4. This is a highly recommended comment.

      Candice Lea

      logged in via Facebook

      In reply to Peter Bowditch

      "I can provide evidence - it's just that 'science' as it is practised today - does not like to examine evidence contrary to currently-held dogma."

      It is statements like these that make real researchers not take you seriously.
      Just because you're not seeing such things played out on your turf (Google, blogs etc) doesn't mean it isn't happening.
      Even in weekly staff meetings there are constant conversations about data quality, how we can challenge ideas, extend knowledge - we don't get funding…

      Read more

      "I can provide evidence - it's just that 'science' as it is practised today - does not like to examine evidence contrary to currently-held dogma."

      It is statements like these that make real researchers not take you seriously.
      Just because you're not seeing such things played out on your turf (Google, blogs etc) doesn't mean it isn't happening.
      Even in weekly staff meetings there are constant conversations about data quality, how we can challenge ideas, extend knowledge - we don't get funding unless we do this! We have to be shown to be a valuable contributor to the body of knowledge.

      To have a person who doesn't have the qualifications or experience say that "you're not doing your jobs properly" - really, it is quite amusing. And when I say experience, I don't mean reading about the topic (I've been reading cookbooks for 11 years, doesn't make me a chef) I mean experience in the field, coming up against obstacles in research and debating solutions with your peers, taking what you've learned, publishing it, sharing it with other peers to be challenged. The process is continual.

      You can be critical and hold a 'belief' contrary to anything you wish to. Doesn't make it valid.

      The 'evidence' you claim to have is completely without context. Unless you can argue why it is valid in the context of the playing field you are trying to play on, then it will continue to be dismissed as invalid. Protip: the stuff you have, HAS been viewed in context of the playing field. That is why it was dismissed. Not because it 'goes against the grain'

      almost 2 years ago report

    5. Euan Reavie

      Meryl; your comment suggests you have not actually spoken to many scientists, or you decided to simply ignore the predominant findings of peer-reviewed research. I hear this nonsense about how scientists "do not like to examine evidence contrary to currently-held dogma" all the time on media outlets. As a scientist, I have never known a colleague to act this way. Yes, fraud and bias have rarely occurred. But you base your argument on your belief that there is resounding scientific bias. If you actually integrated yourself into the lives of scientists you would quickly learn that this is not true.

    6. Meryl Dorey

      Public Officer at Australian Vaccination Network, Inc.

      In reply to Peter Bowditch

      Euan: I think you are presuming too much. To the best of my knowledge, we've never met or spoken. You don't know me and therefore, you can't possibly know who I've spoken with, what I've studied or what knowledge I've gained over my 23 years of research into this subject.

      You said that my comments suggest to you that I have not actually spoken with many scientists and then, continue on to the absolutely gob-smacking statement that "fraud and bias have rarely occurred". I will be kind and assume…

      Read more

      Euan: I think you are presuming too much. To the best of my knowledge, we've never met or spoken. You don't know me and therefore, you can't possibly know who I've spoken with, what I've studied or what knowledge I've gained over my 23 years of research into this subject.

      You said that my comments suggest to you that I have not actually spoken with many scientists and then, continue on to the absolutely gob-smacking statement that "fraud and bias have rarely occurred". I will be kind and assume that you haven't read many medical journals in the last 20 years because if you had, you could be excused for thinking that bias and fraud had become the rule rather than the exception when it comes to issues of medical science.

      The fact is that this article wants us all to defer to the greater knowledge and expertise of doctors who - the author claims - are the REAL experts when it comes to vaccination. But I have spoken with literally hundreds of doctors who are totally clueless on this subject - and that includes immunologists, paediatricians, rheumatologists and other specialists.

      As opposed to the opinion of many people here and in the greater community, a degree in medicine does not give one any 'magical' powers to determine the truth or otherwise of scientific issues. Doctors are not trained in research and in fact, that majority of their information about drugs and vaccines comes directly from the manufacturers of those same products.

      Unless a doctor does their own research, they will never know any different. When they do take the time to independently investigate this issue, they very often change their viewpoint 180 degrees. Look at Larry Palevsky, Foad Yabak and other paediatricians who openly question vaccines. I would name some Australian experts as well, but in our 'free' country, being named as someone who questions the safety and effectiveness of vaccination from within the medical community is professional suicide.

      Science, when it is based on real evidence, is robust and needs no protection. Science is never above debate. Science is not the exclusive property of people who name themselves scientists and who gained their qualifications by agreeing to abide by accepted dogma without question.

      I am absolutely entitled to my opinion and to express it with my evidence. Denying me - or anyone else - that right whilst ignoring the elephant in the room which is the huge amount of research questioning the validity of current vaccine theory - is totally unscientific and should not be supported by anyone claiming to be a scientist.

      Again I say, if someone feels that their grasp of this issue is better than mine and their references are stronger, then debate me. Stating that debating me is pointless because you claim I have no information is self-serving at best.

      almost 2 years ago report

      Meryl I have read all your comments on here and other fora in which you have posted. You question how people can know what you have studied or to whom you have spoken. I think that the bottom line here is that you don't have any paper qualifications. Having a brain is simply not enough. Having read alt med websites and publications for 23 years, is not enough. Despite what you might say to your critics, in order to have your opinion about vaccination and other health issues taken seriously, you need paper qualifications. Such qualifications show that you have been taught, that you have learned and that your knowledge has been tested through exams and assessments. All this happens to ensure that you know your stuff.

      Strutting around, constantly challenging people to debate you simply makes you look ridiculous. Put your ego to one side for a moment and think about it. Why would a medical/scientific professional with 10 years or more tertiary qualifications and years of experience bother to debate you? Quite simply, if they did, they would be tarnishing their credibility and at the same time lending undeserved credibility to you. You constantly talk about challenging "their" data with "your" data. You don't have any data. You simply have scooped up muck from crank sites such as whale.to And the data that you claim comes from mainstream medical journals - well that is cherry picked, misinterpreted and misunderstood by you. Here is a classic example of how people like you in the anti vax/alt med world operate. A homeopath who is well know to you, recently claimed on their website that they had read an article in BMJ supporting homeopathy. Wow! Just wow! Really? Well, it turns out that when this claim was checked that the article in question was actually a letter to the editor and it was written by a naturopath. Now that is quite different to BMJ supporting homeopathy isn't it? Now you are probably saying "oh but that wasn't me - I didn't do that" but the point is that you do, do it - frequently.

      Now Meryl, I hope that you have noted that I have not discussed vaccination at all here. Not once. The reason for that is that I don't hold any scientific or medical qualifications. None. Also note that this is not a personal attack. I am addressing what you have said with regards to your entitlement to have an opinion. What I have is an opinion on your behaviour. I think, having read hours and hours of your writing, that I am entitled to hold that opinion and I am entitled to have that opinion taken seriously. My opinion? You are getting an absolute hiding from all sectors of society and you think it is some conspiracy against you. Did it ever occur to you, with so many many people disagreeing with you, that you might be wrong? Your behaviour reminds me of a spoilt three year old child, screaming "listen to me - I'm right" and then when others try to respond you stick your fingers in your ears and chant "la la la I'm not listening". So please, Meryl, listen. The world is trying to tell you something and you just might learn from it.

      "The fact is that this article wants us all to defer to the greater knowledge and expertise of doctors who - the author claims - are the REAL experts when it comes to vaccination. But I have spoken with literally hundreds of doctors who are totally clueless on this subject - and that includes immunologists, paediatricians, rheumatologists and other specialists.

      As opposed to the opinion of many people here and in the greater community, a degree in medicine does not give one any 'magical' powers to determine the truth or otherwise of scientific issues. Doctors are not trained in research and in fact, that majority of their information about drugs and vaccines comes directly from the manufacturers of those same products."

      You seem to get clinicians confused with real doctors who write the research, you know, PhDs.
      Instead of whinging you have 'spoken to the delivery people', then claim they're clueless on the subject, why don't you go to the source?
      Doctors (PhD) in virology (I happen to know one, but you refuse to listen to them), immunology, epidemiology etc
      these are the real experts, surely you know that?

      As far as having an opinion on bias, 'reading' journals over 20 years makes you know more of an expert on the research, writing, peer review, and publication than when you started. You're an observer.
      You could read music and watch someone play piano for years, until you actually sit down and play, you really can't claim superior skills, no matter how sure you are that you could play better than everyone.

      It is this divide that makes your opinion not worthy of being taken seriously. You can comment all you want on the process, nobody is bothering to listen because you don't even attempt to get involved and broaden your knowledge to, at the very least, be equal to the basic knowledge of the other players.
      If you think you possess the exact same knowledge, then step up, start publishing, start attending conferences and become part of the conversation with your peers.

      Whinging isn't a valid opinion.

      You claim Meryl..." Doctors are not trained in research and in fact, that majority of their information about drugs and vaccines comes directly from the manufacturers of those same products."......

The role extends for those who work in Specialist medicine is to discuss ( not write!) peer reviewed articles on a disease state, or new information on a drug that has an approved indication.
      How to evaluate a patient is nothing to do with Pharma.

    13. Stephanie Buydens

      Student

      In reply to Peter Bowditch

      "Having a brain is simply not enough. Having read alt med websites and publications for 23 years, is not enough. Despite what you might say to your critics, in order to have your opinion about vaccination and other health issues taken seriously, you need paper qualifications."

      Although I agree with the rest, I strongly disagree with this statement.

      As a homeschooled teenager, I developed an interest in genetics. I used to spend hours hanging out in the Health Sciences library, reading American…

      Read more

      "Having a brain is simply not enough. Having read alt med websites and publications for 23 years, is not enough. Despite what you might say to your critics, in order to have your opinion about vaccination and other health issues taken seriously, you need paper qualifications."

      Although I agree with the rest, I strongly disagree with this statement.

      As a homeschooled teenager, I developed an interest in genetics. I used to spend hours hanging out in the Health Sciences library, reading American Journal of Medical Genetics and other similar journals. I looked up stuff on PubMed and Google Scholar. I read pretty much everything I could find on rare genetic syndromes, especially chromosome disorders.

      My only formal training in the subject comes from Biology 100. But in the area of genetics (though not other areas), I have been told by trained professionals that my understanding is as good as someone with a medical degree.

      It is possible to be a self-taught expert. We should not judge the claims on who is making them, but on how well they match up to the facts.

      In psychology (which is my major, and I studied this in much the same way as genetics), the predominant model of persuasion is the Elaboration Likelihood Model. They postulate two modes of processing an argument - central and peripheral. The central mode involves a reasoned, logical analysis of their statements and the corresponding facts. The peripheral mode involves deciding based on superficial features, such as the number of arguments (regardless of quality) or how 'official' the paper looks - or the qualifications of the one writing.

      Trained experts are still human, and they still make mistakes. Self-taught people can be quite knowledgable, if they put enough time and effort into learning. Although the probability is higher that a trained expert is correct, we must not assume that - we must look at how well the facts back up their statements.

      In the case of the cause of autism, I can tell you by my research into the topic that autism is predominantly genetic. If you want I could cite a pile of journal articles about it. There are hundreds of candidate genes for autism, each of which likely accounts for some autistics, because autism isn't one condition, it's many. Are there some kids whose autism was caused by vaccination? Yes - I know of at least one, who had an undetected mitochondrial disorder and the fever and lack of appetite after vaccination sent her into a metabolic crisis. But these kids are a very small proportion of autistic kids. I don't need a degree to know this. I've done my reading, medical journals instead of quack science. Many journals are free to the public, and if you live near a university, by visiting it you can find many more. Not having a degree doesn't stop you from finding stuff out.

      almost 2 years ago report

    14. Sue Ieraci

      Public hospital clinician

      In reply to Peter Bowditch

      "Self-taught people can be quite knowledgable, if they put enough time and effort into learning."

      Stephanie - of course it is possible to learn a great deal by reading - many interested amateurs know a lot more of the theory about their specific area of interest than professionals who are not specialists in that area.

      There is a huge gap, however, between knowing theory on a topic and actually practising a profession or making policy decisions where you are responsible for health outcomes…

      Read more

      "Self-taught people can be quite knowledgable, if they put enough time and effort into learning."

      Stephanie - of course it is possible to learn a great deal by reading - many interested amateurs know a lot more of the theory about their specific area of interest than professionals who are not specialists in that area.

      There is a huge gap, however, between knowing theory on a topic and actually practising a profession or making policy decisions where you are responsible for health outcomes of real human beings.

      A real understanding of clinical genetics means understanding all the clinical sciences - you can't understand the way the human organism functions by learning only the anatomy of the lower limb, or only the function of the renal tubules.

      FOr example, you quote a case of a child where "the fever and lack of appetite after vaccination sent her into a metabolic crisis." But did you know that a much more frequent cause of fever and lack of appetite is An infective illness - something as simple as a minor viral infection? The vast majority of simple febrile convulsions in childhood are caused by relatively minor infective illnesses. So, if the child you know had not been vaccinated, could the same reaction not have occurred when they caught any infective illness?

      almost 2 years ago report

    15. Sue Ieraci

      Public hospital clinician

      In reply to Peter Bowditch

      Ms Dorey makes these proclamations while having no idea what doctors are trained in - either in medical school or during life-long ongoing education.

      She names a couple of American paediatricians: the first is a general paediatrician who has no scientifc publications in the area of vaccination - nor in any other area.

      Dr Fouad Yazbak (not "Foad Yabak") was a co-author on papers about the impact of rubella on pregnancies in the 1960's. Accuracy is important.

      IN the meantime, the overwhelming majority of paediatricians understand and promote the enormous benefits of vaccination, while acknowledging the small incidence of significant side-effects.

    18. Sue Ieraci

      Public hospital clinician

      In reply to Peter Bowditch

      Most people understand that human life involves non-zero risk, Craig.

      Wearing seat-belts and having vehicle air-bags also entails non-zero risk, but our cooperative society has agreed that these tiny risks should be systematically borne for the much larger benefits. The risks and benefits have been studied and quantified - as they have been with vaccination.

      I don't ignore a non-zero-risk - I live with it, as does all of humanity.

      almost 2 years ago report

    19. account deleted

      logged in via email @gmail.com

      In reply to Peter Bowditch

      I ride a motorcycle Sue and I've had more than one incident involving serious injury. The rewards I get from riding the motorcycle are sufficient in my mind to make the risk worthwhile. I work with someone who has just sold his motorcycle because he had a slight skid in the wet and came to the conclusion that the risk was too great for the benefit he gains. He may be right, but he's not me.

      The anti-vaxers believe that the benefits associated with vaccination are not sufficient to justify the risk they perceive as being associated with the process.

      I agree that this is entirely subjective, but that's the way it is. For some people no amount of avoidable risk is acceptable, while for others risk is part of life.

    21. Debra Joan Smith

      Account Executive

      In reply to Peter Bowditch

      The issue remains this- Craig- that if you knowingly choose to accept the risks of riding a motorcylce- it is your skin and bone and brain tissue or those of your knowling passenger that remain like skid marks on Australia's roadways where as when you choose not to vaccinate your child- you choose danger for everyone who intersects with your child's life and they never consciously assumed that risk.

    22. Sue Ieraci

      Public hospital clinician

      In reply to Peter Bowditch

      Craig - I see two issues with that argument:

      First, the risks and benefits of both motorcycle riding and infectious diseases are quantifiable - in objective numbers (incidence, hospitalisations, deaths etc). The risks of infectious diseases are significant, those of vaccination are tiny in comparison.

      Second, both people who are sick with infectious diseases and those who ride motorcycles in traffic interact with the general community - their behaviour or condition impacts on others, and they…

      Read more

      Craig - I see two issues with that argument:

      First, the risks and benefits of both motorcycle riding and infectious diseases are quantifiable - in objective numbers (incidence, hospitalisations, deaths etc). The risks of infectious diseases are significant, those of vaccination are tiny in comparison.

      Second, both people who are sick with infectious diseases and those who ride motorcycles in traffic interact with the general community - their behaviour or condition impacts on others, and they use the health care system.

      If people want to ride motorbikes on their private properties only, and never seek health care for injuries sustained, then they have the right to those choices. When those behaviours impact on others, however, the significance of the decisions changes. Even more so when one makes the decision on behalf of a minor (as in vaccination).

      Do you hold the same views for seat-belts, drink-driving, airbags, childseats in cars? Fences on cliffs? When you ride your motorbike, do you wear a helmet? Do you stop at red lights? Many people argue that these societal requirements breach their civil liberties, but our society believes in regulation for the greater good.

      almost 2 years ago report

    23. account deleted

      logged in via email @gmail.com

      In reply to Peter Bowditch

      I couldn't agree more Sue. My point was that all that rationality doesn't matter when you're trying to convince people who hold an irrational viewpoint. By any objective rational measure riding a bike is crazy, yet I still do it, irrationally. Sure, I take the usual self-protective measures, but I know from personal experience they don't work especially well.

      I suspect the same applies to anti-vaxers. They place high weightings on aspects of their decision-making that by any object and rational…

      Read more

      I couldn't agree more Sue. My point was that all that rationality doesn't matter when you're trying to convince people who hold an irrational viewpoint. By any objective rational measure riding a bike is crazy, yet I still do it, irrationally. Sure, I take the usual self-protective measures, but I know from personal experience they don't work especially well.

      I suspect the same applies to anti-vaxers. They place high weightings on aspects of their decision-making that by any object and rational assessment are simply not justified, while they weight the risk associated with failing to vaccinate quite lightly,

      There is another parallel with motorcycles in the helmet laws. When helmets were made compulsory in the S (that happened before my time here), there were lots of people who refused to comply on the grounds that they were worried about the helmet causing neck injury and hence some form of disabling paralysis, which wasn't completely unfounded, but the odds were low and much lower than the risk of skull fracture and other injuries without a helmet. Since then it has become even lower with new designs of helmet, but some people still refuse to comply, even today. They really hate the idea of being confined to a wheelchair so much that they'd rather die.

      The anti-vaxers hold purely a subjective perception of the nature (not the magnitude) of the risks and that's why you won't change their minds.

      As I said earlier, it then becomes a discussion over their heads about whether it is justifiable to coerce them. I'm still not entirely convinced that it is, given that the diseases in question have been with us for many, many centuries and are readily managed if a child does contract them. As a child I had all the usual illnesses, including both measles and rubella and chickenpox, although I never had mumps, despite my parents best efforts to expose me.

      I personally think vaccination is a public good that should be encouraged, but I'm not sure that it is such a great public good that it should be mandatory, or that it should be supported by coercion. It concerns me that our society is becoming ever more ready to use coercion as a first rather than last resort, but that's probably a discussion for elsewhere.

      almost 2 years ago report

  21. Elizabeth Hart

    Independent Vaccine Investigator

    Patrick, The Conversation’s comments thread on “Measles outbreak calls for vaccination vigilance” was arbitrarily shut down today, preventing me from responding to Sue Ieraci’s query about my definition of “paternalistic experts”: https://theconversation.edu.au/measles-outbreak-calls-for-vaccination-vigilance-10042
    As my response is pertinent to the Mediawatch story on a measles outbreak mentioned in your article, and provides a practical example of what you call “a policy response to science…

    Read more

    Patrick, The Conversation’s comments thread on “Measles outbreak calls for vaccination vigilance” was arbitrarily shut down today, preventing me from responding to Sue Ieraci’s query about my definition of “paternalistic experts”: https://theconversation.edu.au/measles-outbreak-calls-for-vaccination-vigilance-10042
    As my response is pertinent to the Mediawatch story on a measles outbreak mentioned in your article, and provides a practical example of what you call “a policy response to science”, I will post it here, on the “No, you’re not entitled to your opinion” thread.
    So, on the subject of ‘paternalism’…or the tyranny of ‘experts’…
    In the “measles outbreak” article linked to above, Peter McIntyre, (who is an ex officio member of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation [ATAGI], and I assume in a position to contribute to discussion on vaccination policy), is quoted as saying: “To start primary school in the US if you don’t have your paperwork showing two measles shots they say “sorry, come back when you have the paperwork,”…That might be seen as a bit tough…but on the other hand it does really work.”
    It appears Professor McIntyre believes that “parents should be required to show proof their children have been immunised against measles before they are allowed to start school”, i.e. compulsory vaccination with two MMR live vaccines.
    Yet, according to various sources, most children are likely to develop immunity to measles after the first MMR live vaccine.
    For example:
    - the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) advises: “Measles antibodies develop among approximately 95% of children vaccinated at age 12 months and 98% of children vaccinated at age 15 months (CDC, unpublished data)…Although vaccination produces lower antibody levels than natural disease, both serologic and epidemiologic evidence indicate that the vaccine induces long-term – probably lifelong – immunity, in most persons.”(1)
    - the Product Information sheet for GlaxoSmithKline’s PRIORIX measles/mumps/rubella live vaccine sold in Australia states, “in previously seronegative vaccinees, antibodies were detected in 98.0%, 96.1% and 99.3% of subjects against measles, mumps and rubella respectively”;(2)
    - the Cochrane Collaboration’s systematic review of MMR vaccination reports that “based on the available evidence, one MMR vaccine dose is at least 95% effective in preventing clinical measles and 92% effective in preventing secondary cases among household contacts”.(3)
    Patrick, in your response to Meryl Dorey you said: “Now, here’s where you and I *are* entitled to have opinions, and to have those opinions taken seriously: we’re citizens, and as such policy responses to science are very much our business.”
    I forwarded a letter to the Federal Health Minister, Tanya Plibersek, querying the Australian government’s demand for arbitrary revaccination with two MMR live vaccines to obtain tax benefits: http://users.on.net/~peter.hart/Letter_to_Minister_Plibersek_re_MMR_vaccine.pdf
    Minister Plibersek’s office has refused to respond to my letter.
    (My letter was also copied to Professor Terry Nolan, Chair of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation [ATAGI]. Until recently, membership of ATAGI was not publicly known. I have correspondence with the Minister’s department enquiring about membership of ATAGI commencing in November 2011.)
    Patrick, some questions for you:
    1. Is it acceptable that parents of young children are not informed of the reportedly high response rate to the first MMR live vaccine, and arbitrarily ordered to have a second MMR vaccine for their children?
    2. Is it acceptable that the Australian government demands that, to qualify for the Family Tax Benefit Part A Supplement, children must have two MMR live vaccine doses, regardless of whether they are already immune after the first MMR vaccine?
    3. Is it acceptable that parents are not advised of the availability of serological testing to verify a response to MMR live vaccination (i.e. evidence based medicine)?
    4. Is it acceptable for people/parents of children to be denied the opportunity to give their ‘informed consent’ to preventive health interventions, and other medical interventions?
    5. Is Peter McIntyre entitled to demand that every child have two MMR live vaccines?
    6. Do you think Minister Plibersek has a duty to respond to my detailed argument?
    I would appreciate your response.
    Thanks
    Elizabeth Hart
    References:
    (1) Measles, Mumps, and Rubella -- Vaccine Use and Strategies for Elimination of Measles, Rubella, and Congenital Rubella Syndrome and Control of Mumps: Recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP), CDC MMWR May 22, 1998 / 47(RR-8);1-57: http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00053391.htm
    (2) GlaxoSmithKline PRIORIX Product Information: https://www.ebs.tga.gov.au/ebs/picmi/picmirepository.nsf/pdf?OpenAgent&id=CP-2010-PI-05279-3
    (3) Demicheli V, Rivetti A, Debalini MG, Di Pietrantonj C. Vaccines for measles, mumps and rubella in children. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2012, Issue 2. Art. No.: CD004407. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD004407.pub3. http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD004407.pub3/abstract

    almost 2 years ago report

    6. Candice Lea

      logged in via Facebook

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      Thank you Patrick - seems Elizabeth is only concerned about her own say and not reading the comments people put in reply to it. So I'll quote myself here for Elizabeth's benefit.

      There are some things in health policy that are about the bigger picture Elizabeth.

      "

      Elizabeth, if it is your opinion that the NIP 'arbitrarily' has two doses of MMR in the schedule - do you honestly think the addition of a second dose to the schedule (at incredible cost and resource cost) *hasn't* been thoroughly…

      Read more

      Thank you Patrick - seems Elizabeth is only concerned about her own say and not reading the comments people put in reply to it. So I'll quote myself here for Elizabeth's benefit.

      There are some things in health policy that are about the bigger picture Elizabeth.

      "

      Elizabeth, if it is your opinion that the NIP 'arbitrarily' has two doses of MMR in the schedule - do you honestly think the addition of a second dose to the schedule (at incredible cost and resource cost) *hasn't* been thoroughly debated by the subject matter experts?

      On a slightly different note, you claim in your letter that the emphasis should be on getting everyone vaccinated with one dose.
      Surely you understand the basic logistics of getting *every* child in Australia vaccinated with only one-dose on the schedule is pretty darn hard to do - combine that with the one-dose 5% failure to confer immunity and the vaccination coverage for one-dose on the schedule for MMR in Australia would be well below what is needed for herd immunity.

      Adding a second dose to the schedule *is* maximising one-dose MMR coverage, it's ensuring the most opportunity for children to get at LEAST one-dose."

      In other words, the addition of another vaccine to the schedule is incredibly expensive for the government to fund and administer. THAT is how serious they take measles in this country. They don't cross their fingers and dilly dally with one-dose on the schedule. When you combine the percentage vaccinated at 12months with MMR and then consider another 5% of those will not get immunity from the vaccine. We are dropping below herd immunity numbers.

      What else is taken into consideration is the R0 this is the reproduction rate of the disease (ie how many people ONE case would infect) in the case of measles it is 12-18. to put that in perspective influenza is 2-3.
      There are so many more factors taken into consideration such as complications from the disease, economic cost etc etc.

      Your 'opinion' isn't taken seriously because you haven't even scratched the surface of what a decision like this entails. To write a letter to that effect, stomping your feet just clearly shows how little you know.

      now I have given you a really really basic heads up of what goes into making these types of decisions (and I mean REALLY basic) and so you know these are not my 'opinions' this is what I learned in my Master of Public Health.
      To fully inform you of the entire process, you'd at minimum have the same qualification as me by the end of it!

      almost 2 years ago report

    7. Keith Thomas

      Retired

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      I apologise if I am complicit in letting the topic stray into the MMR debate, but I have a question about MMR. Some of the criticism of MMR is because the triple vaccine is a "triple whammy" and so it may have a greater impact on infants than would three separated vaccinations. Is there a medical reason why separate vaccinations are not routinely available? I may be wrong, but I get the impression that many people who oppose MMR are not opposed to all or even most vaccinations, just this one particular "king hit".

      There is a second issue: some parents would like to see their children tested and shown to be healthy enough to withstand the special impact of each vaccine before it's administered. I don't want to get into the medical arguments here, but I mention it because I want to point out that people opposed to MMR are not all dogmatic anti-vaccination zealots.

      almost 2 years ago report

      some parts of your arguement are outside the scope of my expertise.
      "Is there a medical reason why separate vaccinations are not routinely available?"
      there will always be *some* reason why people who oppose vaccination will have issue with any vaccine.
      However. Sure, entertain the idea of giving a baby of 12months *3* seperate needles when they dont need too, just because the mummy warrior feels she knows more than every immunologist etc etc.
      These developments and approvals are NOT taken lightly. The better question would be 'why are the vaccines combined? what is the benefit?'

      The second issue of testing. To date no antivaxxer has suggested what to actually test for?
      How do you 'test health?'
      Is it merely the absence of disease?

      My OPINION on the matter is that parents, and mothers especially, (and I am a single mother so don't think i'm speaking out of turn) have this drive to be in control of everything. I believe there is some odd cultural shift with women who are now in the workplace as dominant forces, having to apply their natural 'control' to parenting and believe they can apply the same logic they use in their jobs to fields WELL outside their expertise, *just* because it is involving their child. Somehow giving them some pseudo expertise on the matter.

    14. Keith Thomas

      Retired

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      I'll be careful with this reply as I don't want to tread further on Patrick's patience or The Conversation's generosity.

      I did not say I knew what tests would ensure we will not get anaphylaxis from vaccination. All I said was I could suggest appropriate tests. And I meant - but did not say, sorry - that, surely, such tests would be prudent, understood in the context of patient history, as a means of identifying children who were at greater or lesser risk of suffering ill effects from vaccination…

      Read more

      I'll be careful with this reply as I don't want to tread further on Patrick's patience or The Conversation's generosity.

      I did not say I knew what tests would ensure we will not get anaphylaxis from vaccination. All I said was I could suggest appropriate tests. And I meant - but did not say, sorry - that, surely, such tests would be prudent, understood in the context of patient history, as a means of identifying children who were at greater or lesser risk of suffering ill effects from vaccination at a particular time.

      I think we come nicely now back to Patrick's point which is not about MMR or even vaccination. It's about whose interventions are worthy of consideration in a serious public debate with real consequences in the real world, and not about who wins a debate.

      Overshadowing all this is the public controversy about climate change and its many subsidiary controversies (carbon tax, renewable energy, whether climate change is due to human activity - and which activity - the health impacts of wind power, the rights of irrigators, bushfire management, even immigration and population growth etc.). This issue is far more important than vaccination for the future of human civilization itself.

      Even the controversy about climate change has itself been infected with and largely shaped by another controversy imported from the USA about the role of government, with those who want to take decisive action to reduce the human impact on climate being branded as socialists, interferers or aligned with 'one-world-order' proponents who seek to undermine the US Constitution and the most cherished amendments. On the other side, those who reject government action catch a ride on any skeptic argument going, expediently acting as if the ends justifies the means. The science - to the dismay of scientists - has taken a back seat.

      Both sides in these major controversies can be seen attempting to frame the questions to suit their own expertise and to focus the debate on areas where they have most likelihood of "winning" (in their eyes). We can see this happening above (not you Candice) and we see it in what's left of newspaper letters to the editor. How many people posting above are saying something like "thank you for alerting me to this - I had not thought of it this way before - I am pleased to say I have changed my mind"? And how many people have resorted to 'straw man' arguments and other rhetorical devices to score a debating point - when, as many have both said and implied above - winning a point is to miss the point of the discussion.

      almost 2 years ago report

    15. Sue Ieraci

    16. Sue Ieraci

      Public hospital clinician

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      Keith Thomas - vaccine policy is a combination of immunology and public health practice. The reasons for the timing of the various vaccines include:
      - Age at which the child is able to mount an effective immune response
      - Age at which the condition being vaccinated for is most prevalent
      - Age at which the child is most exposed to other children (eg pre-school)

      Most anti-vaccinationists are less concerned about the antigens in the vaccines so much as the fluid they are carried in and the preservatives…

      Read more

      Keith Thomas - vaccine policy is a combination of immunology and public health practice. The reasons for the timing of the various vaccines include:
      - Age at which the child is able to mount an effective immune response
      - Age at which the condition being vaccinated for is most prevalent
      - Age at which the child is most exposed to other children (eg pre-school)

      Most anti-vaccinationists are less concerned about the antigens in the vaccines so much as the fluid they are carried in and the preservatives (although all these have been found to be safe). Combining vaccines reduces the number and volume if the injections and the load of diluent and preservative.

      ALthough I can understand why people might ask these questions, I find it hard to understand when they don't accept the answers. IN the extreme case, Neonatal ICU nurses and doctors, who look aft er the most vulnerable micro-premmies, promote the vaccination schedule, why would the rest of us disagree? These people know a newborn's immune system intimately, and dedicate their lives to the welfare of babies. How would it make sense that they are part of some world-wide conspiracy, or just have a blind spot in this area.

      Ms Hart and Mr Beattie like to use the term 'experts'. For NICU nurses and doctors, I prefer the term experts.

      almost 2 years ago report

    17. Sue Ieraci

      Public hospital clinician

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      Mr Thomas - on what basis would you choose tests to be "healthy enough to withstand the special impact of each vaccine before it's administered."?

      Do you mean whether they have a normal immune system and are therefore able to mount an immune response, or do you mean whether they might have an egg allergy and react to some components of some vaccines? If they are not "healthy", don't they need immunisation all the more, as they might not be able to withstand the actual infections?

      I wonder why…

      Read more

      Mr Thomas - on what basis would you choose tests to be "healthy enough to withstand the special impact of each vaccine before it's administered."?

      Do you mean whether they have a normal immune system and are therefore able to mount an immune response, or do you mean whether they might have an egg allergy and react to some components of some vaccines? If they are not "healthy", don't they need immunisation all the more, as they might not be able to withstand the actual infections?

      I wonder why you imagine that there has not been supremely detailed consideration of all these factors when vaccine policy is made? I fyou have not been part of a process of developing, for example, a clinical guideline, you might not appreciate the degree of detail and expertise that goes into clinical policy. Not only does it have to be rationally argued, but it also has to be visibly backed up by evidence, and regularly reviewed. I don't know what work you did before retirement, but do you imagine that someone untrained in the area could have done it better than you?

      You say "Both sides in these major controversies can be seen attempting to frame the questions to suit their own expertise and to focus the debate on areas where they have most likelihood of "winning" (in their eyes)."

      In my personal case, I frame my comments from my personal area of training and expertise. You will not see me questioning the evidence in climate science, or economics, or political strategy - I am neither trained in those disciplines, nor experienced in practising those professions.

      On the other hand, the anti-vaccine posters here wish to argue on the basis of their lay opinions, without having been health care providers, or even trained in the clinical sciences.

      Of course one can ask questions, but when the answers repeatedly go against what your originally thought, it's time to ask different ones. The questions about vaccine efficacy and safety posed by Ms Dorey, Mr Beattie and colleagues have not been ignored. On the contrary - they have been refuted with evidence over and over.

      almost 2 years ago report

    19. Elizabeth Hart

      Independent Vaccine Investigator

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      Sue, refer to my recent detailed and referenced response to Patrick Stokes.
      In your role as a public hospital clinician, I have some questions for you that may help provide more illustration. Bearing in mind Aesculapian authority:
      1. Is it acceptable that parents of young children are not informed of the reportedly high response rate to the first MMR live vaccine, and arbitrarily ordered to have a second MMR vaccine for their children?
      2. Is it acceptable that the Australian government demands…

      Read more

      Sue, refer to my recent detailed and referenced response to Patrick Stokes.
      In your role as a public hospital clinician, I have some questions for you that may help provide more illustration. Bearing in mind Aesculapian authority:
      1. Is it acceptable that parents of young children are not informed of the reportedly high response rate to the first MMR live vaccine, and arbitrarily ordered to have a second MMR vaccine for their children?
      2. Is it acceptable that the Australian government demands that, to qualify for the Family Tax Benefit Part A Supplement, children must have two MMR live vaccine doses, regardless of whether they are already immune after the first MMR vaccine?
      3. Is it acceptable that parents are not advised of the availability of serological testing to verify a response to MMR live vaccination (i.e. evidence based medicine)?
      4. Is it acceptable for people/parents of children to be denied the opportunity to give their ‘informed consent’ to preventive health interventions, and other medical interventions?
      5. Is Peter McIntyre entitled to demand that every child have two MMR live vaccines?
      6. Do you think Minister Plibersek has a duty to respond to my detailed argument: http://users.on.net/~peter.hart/Letter_to_Minister_Plibersek_re_MMR_vaccine.pdf ?

      almost 2 years ago report

    21. Stephanie Buydens

      Student

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      "I apologise if I am complicit in letting the topic stray into the MMR debate, but I have a question about MMR. Some of the criticism of MMR is because the triple vaccine is a "triple whammy" and so it may have a greater impact on infants than would three separated vaccinations. Is there a medical reason why separate vaccinations are not routinely available? I may be wrong, but I get the impression that many people who oppose MMR are not opposed to all or even most vaccinations, just this one particular "king hit"."

      I am not an expert in immunology, but from what I understand, the reason why they give all three together is to have earlier immunity. If you gave them separately, the kid would spend several more months susceptible to one or two of the trio of illnesses that vaccine defends against.

      Unless you're proposing just having separate injections for each, which would accomplish nothing apart from giving the kid a bit more pain.

      almost 2 years ago report

    22. Stephanie Buydens

      Student

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      Yes, you can't always generalize from animals to humans, just like you can't generalize between different species of animals. For example, rabbits are one of the few species that don't have birth defects from prenatal exposure to thalidomide. Rats, for example (http://www.nature.com/pr/journal/v52/n4/abs/pr2002225a.html), have pretty much the same reaction to thalidomide as humans do.

      We're not special. Every species has its unique quirks. Good use of animal models involves testing multiple species…

      Read more

      Yes, you can't always generalize from animals to humans, just like you can't generalize between different species of animals. For example, rabbits are one of the few species that don't have birth defects from prenatal exposure to thalidomide. Rats, for example (http://www.nature.com/pr/journal/v52/n4/abs/pr2002225a.html), have pretty much the same reaction to thalidomide as humans do.

      We're not special. Every species has its unique quirks. Good use of animal models involves testing multiple species, and especially ones similar to us in the relevant mechanisms (for example, pigs are best for studying digestive issues, because their digestion is a lot like ours) in the hopes that if the medication has adverse effects on humans, we'll see similar effects in another species as well. It's not always perfect, but the alternatives are either to test it first on humans, risking ill effects for the human subjects, or else forego potentially beneficial treatments because we don't know if they're safe.

      almost 2 years ago report

    23. Candice Lea

      logged in via Facebook

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      *exactly* Debra - one way conversation for Ms Hart. Something makes me believe she wouldn't pay attention if the answers are not what she wants to hear. She's already ignored my responses, twice.
