    24. Elizabeth Hart

      Independent Vaccine Investigator

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      Patrick, as intimated earlier, I was astonished by your offhand reply to my comment about unnecessary vaccination with the MMR second dose, and the lack of response to my letter to Health Minister Tanya Plibersek. It was obvious from the speed of your reply that you gave barely any thought to my detailed and referenced comment.
      Please note there is an important principle at stake here. We are in very dangerous territory when 'experts' and governments demand that citizens/children have questionable…

      Read more

      Patrick, as intimated earlier, I was astonished by your offhand reply to my comment about unnecessary vaccination with the MMR second dose, and the lack of response to my letter to Health Minister Tanya Plibersek. It was obvious from the speed of your reply that you gave barely any thought to my detailed and referenced comment.
      Please note there is an important principle at stake here. We are in very dangerous territory when 'experts' and governments demand that citizens/children have questionable medical interventions.
      In this regard, I am interested to examine the process to add vaccines to the National Immunisation Program Schedule. There appear to be serious problems with transparency and accountability. For instance, until recently, membership details of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI) were not publicly accessible.
      Looking at vaccines individually, I am dubious about HPV vaccination, which has been uncritically promoted on The Conversation website, see for example Ian Frazer's article "Catch cancer? No thanks, I'd rather get a shot": https://theconversation.edu.au/catch-cancer-no-thanks-id-rather-have-a-shot-7568 and Charis Palmer's article "Study should dispel vaccine myths": https://theconversation.edu.au/study-should-dispel-hpv-vaccine-myths-9914 (Critical analysis is being provided by contributors to the discussion threads on these articles.)
      I question how the HPV vaccine got onto the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. In this regard, refer to my open letter to the Editor-in-Chief of The Australian, Chris Mitchell, i.e. "Is universal HPV vaccination necessary": http://users.on.net/~peter.hart/Is_universal_HPV_vaccination_necessary.pdf
      Patrick, vaccination is a serious and complex topic. Polarised discussion on this subject is hindering the airing of legitimate concerns about vaccination practice.

      almost 2 years ago report

    25. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      Hi Elizabeth,

      I apologise if I came across as abrupt in my earlier response. It certainly wasn't my intention to offend. However, as indicated, all the questions you raised ultimately turn on matters on which I, not being a scientist working in the relevant area, can’t really comment on. As I say, the answers to your questions would depend on the relative costs and benefits of one-dose vs. two-dose schedules. I don’t know what those costs/benefits are (obviously that’s a technical question well…

      Read more

      Hi Elizabeth,

      I apologise if I came across as abrupt in my earlier response. It certainly wasn't my intention to offend. However, as indicated, all the questions you raised ultimately turn on matters on which I, not being a scientist working in the relevant area, can’t really comment on. As I say, the answers to your questions would depend on the relative costs and benefits of one-dose vs. two-dose schedules. I don’t know what those costs/benefits are (obviously that’s a technical question well outside my scope of expertise). That leaves me with two options: I can (politely, I hope) decline to answer the question, or I can give you an answer that, by definition, would be next to worthless. In my view, the former is the more ethical and indeed more courteous approach, and so that’s what I chose.

      You say that “We are in very dangerous territory when 'experts' and governments demand that citizens/children have questionable medical interventions.” The scare quotes around the word expert are telling, but let’s leave that to one side. The question is: on what basis do you say these are questionable? Is this a scientific claim or a policy claim? In your letter to The Australian, for instance, you provide some fairly vague assertions about “queries re the long-term efficacy of the vaccine” and “inadequately researched possible adverse reactions to vaccination” but the only bit of peer-reviewed research you cite would appear to be a paper questioning whether HPV vaccination is an appropriate health spending priority for India given the cost and the relatively low incidence of cervical cancer there. That’s a question about resource allocation, not about the efficacy of the vaccine itself. Hence it’s unclear whether your concern is a scientific one – in which case you need scientific training in order to make your case – or a policy one.

      Let’s assume your concern is with the policy aspects. If your point is that below a certain incidence and lethality of a disease we should avoid preventative interventions because there’s always the risk that there will be unexpected consequences down the track, you need to articulate the point at which such a theoretical risk outweighs the reduction in the incidence of the disease. (In this case, you put a lot of weight on the fact the immune system usually clears HPV without it developing into cervical cancer, but you then seem to downplay the seriousness of the disease when it does occur). If your claim is that the money spent on HPV vaccination could be better spent elsewhere, that might also be a valid claim given other priorities, but again you need to make your case. Either way you face having to answer a pretty grim question: what number of preventable cervical cancer deaths should we tolerate, given the other claims on our resources? That may sound like a rhetorical question, but it’s not. We have finite resources and policy makers often have to make decisions that implicitly accept a certain number of deaths. So it’s a valid question, but to make a case for taking HPV vaccines off the PBS you would, I think, need to do a lot more.

      You also make the point that vaccines make a lot of money for those who make them. I think there are serious questions about the way healthcare and medical imperatives intersect, but is the sheer fact that making vaccines is profitable evidence that they don’t work? Wouldn’t the very opposite be, at least, no less likely to be the case?

      We agree that this is a serious and complex topic and one that raises serious policy questions, and that it calls for civility and level heads. I'd submit the discussion surrounding this topic isn't helped by people making unfounded scientific assertions without being properly equipped to do so, nor by the disparagement of expertise, not to mention the constant impugning of the motives of experts and professionals working in the field.

      Best wishes,
      Patrick

      almost 2 years ago report

    26. Elizabeth Hart

      Independent Vaccine Investigator

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      Ken, I don’t claim to be an expert in anything…least of all immunology, that’s why I’m careful to cite references to support the arguments I make in my documents and comments.
      As you have discovered, my interest in vaccination was initiated after my eight year old dog Sasha became inexplicably ill, and was put down after an (unnecessary) vaccination. I subsequently discovered that veterinarians in Australia were ignoring international dog and cat vaccination guidelines that recommended reducing…

      Read more

      Ken, I don’t claim to be an expert in anything…least of all immunology, that’s why I’m careful to cite references to support the arguments I make in my documents and comments.
      As you have discovered, my interest in vaccination was initiated after my eight year old dog Sasha became inexplicably ill, and was put down after an (unnecessary) vaccination. I subsequently discovered that veterinarians in Australia were ignoring international dog and cat vaccination guidelines that recommended reducing vaccination to minimise the risk of adverse reactions to vaccine products. Many veterinarians were abusing the trust of their clients by insisting on unnecessary medical interventions for their pets, and failing to obtain ‘informed consent’ for these interventions.
      I have been researching and lobbying on this subject for the past four years, along with my friend and colleague Bea Mies. We have both had extensive correspondence with the Australian Veterinary Association (AVA), the Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA), the World Small Animal Veterinary Association’s Vaccination Guidelines Group, the UK Veterinary Medicines Directorate, the US Center for Veterinary Biologics, international veterinary associations, veterinary boards, academics etc. We have attended meetings with representatives of the AVA and APVMA, and were invited to comment on the APVMA’s draft Position Statement on Vaccination Protocols for Dogs and Cats: http://www.apvma.gov.au/use_safely/vaccination.php
      A summary of the Australian campaign for ethical and evidence-based vaccination of companion animals provides more background: http://users.on.net/~peter.hart/Australian_campaign_for_ethical__pet_vax.pdf
      Here also is a link to a list of documents I have produced on this subject – articles, open letters, submissions etc: http://users.on.net/~peter.hart/Papers_articles_open_letters_re_pet_vax_E_Hart.pdf
      Consumer watchdog CHOICE reported on over-vaccination of pets in 2010, i.e. “Pet vaccination – over-vaccinating your pet could be harmful to their health as well as your own hip pocket”: http://www.choice.com.au/reviews-and-tests/household/backyard/pets/pet-vaccination/page.aspx
      At the risk of appearing immodest, it was largely due to the persistent efforts of Bea Mies and myself that action was taken on this matter. Certainly the veterinary profession in Australia, the so-called ‘experts’, were reluctant to lead due to a conflict of interest, i.e. loss of practice income.
      While there has been some improvement in the situation with a slow move to (unnecessary) ‘triennial vaccination’, and some action on updating vaccine product labels, many animals continue to be over-vaccinated.
      I suggest that pet vaccination is also relevant to human vaccination. It is interesting that while there have been calls in veterinary medicine to “reduce the ‘vaccine load’ on individual animals in order to minimize the potential for adverse reactions to vaccine products”(1), vaccination of humans, (children, adolescents and adults), is increasing at an alarming rate. I question the need for some of the vaccines on the schedule (e.g. the second MMR dose, and HPV vaccination).
      There is a lack of transparency and accountability regarding vaccination practice in Australia and critical analysis is well overdue.
      Reference:
      (1) Guidelines for the Vaccination of Dogs and Cats, compiled by the Vaccination Guidelines Group (VGG) of the World Small Animal Veterinary Association (WSAVA). Journal of Small Animal Practice. Vol. 51. June 2010: http://www.wsava.org/PDF/Misc/VaccinationGuidelines2010.pdf

      almost 2 years ago report

      Read more

      Elizabeth, please do not think that people do not respect your experience. IT IS THE UNWARRANTED GENERALIZATION OF IT THAT WE FEAR AND FIGHT.

      Your experience is compelling- for you-a one off that you seem to fear for the general population. Let me give you a hypothetical equivalent.

      Last December I went in for a benign tumour in my spine. I had my friend drop me off at the front door in perfect health (besides that annoying tumour that threatened my lower half) and the surgeon told me the only risk was infection and as I was at a major hospital with a sterling reputation and as it was one of my own accounts -with one of the lowest infection rates anywhere- I felt good to go. So good in fact, that I walked in alone, and took only one change of clothing and 4 books as I expected to be out in 3 days- fixed. The surgoen was throughly vetted and i discovered has a good record.

      Well almost 6 months later I left a rehab hospital after a coma and learning to walk and talk again. The surgery went wrong.

      i DO NOT TELL OTHER PEOPLE NOT TO HAVE SURGERY FOR TUMOURS IN THEIR SPINE-for I would consider that irresponsible.

      In science your situation is serious, and lamentable but it has no generalizable value other than a clue of what to watch out for. It would be called a case study and we are all taught to be VERY careful with what we think we learn from them>

      I would suggest that all you might have learned just as I did -is that one practioner can be a bozo.

      almost 2 years ago report

    28. Elizabeth Hart

      Independent Vaccine Investigator

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      Patrick, re your flourishing of the ‘peer-reviewed research’ card…
      I suggest this piece by Frank Furedi is relevant i.e.: “Turning peer review into modern-day holy scripture – The treatment of peer-reviewed science as an unquestionable form of authority is corrupting the peer-review system and damaging public debate”: http://www.frankfuredi.com/index.php/site/article/378/
      A quote: “Increasingly, peer review has been turned into a quasi-holy institution, which apparently signifies that a certain…

      Read more

      Patrick, re your flourishing of the ‘peer-reviewed research’ card…
      I suggest this piece by Frank Furedi is relevant i.e.: “Turning peer review into modern-day holy scripture – The treatment of peer-reviewed science as an unquestionable form of authority is corrupting the peer-review system and damaging public debate”: http://www.frankfuredi.com/index.php/site/article/378/
      A quote: “Increasingly, peer review has been turned into a quasi-holy institution, which apparently signifies that a certain claim is legitimate or sacred. And from this perspective, voices which lack the authority of peer review are, by definition, illegitimate. Peer review provides a warrant to be heard – those who speak without this warrant deserve only our scorn.”
      Here’s another quote that nicely sums up some of the attitudes on this forum: “You can almost visualise peer-review dogmatists waving their warrant and demanding that their opponents be silenced.”
      Other articles also provide another perspective on the often industry-funded ‘peer-reviewed research’, e.g.:
      1. Medical Journals are an extension of the marketing arm of pharmaceutical companies: http://www.plosmedicine.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pmed.0020138
      2. Ghost management: How much of the medical literature is shaped behind the scenes by the pharmaceutical industry?: http://www.plosmedicine.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pmed.0040286
      3. Ghostwriting: The dirty little secret of medical publishing that just got bigger: http://www.plosmedicine.org/article/info:doi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pmed.1000156
      4. From evidence-based medicine to marketing-based medicine: Evidence from internal industry documents: http://i.bnet.com/blogs/spielmans-parry-ebm-to-mbm-jbioethicinqu-2010.pdf
      5. Selling sickness: the pharmaceutical industry and disease mongering: http://www.bmj.com/content/324/7342/886.1
      6. The imperative to share clinical study reports: Recommendations from the Tamiflu experience: http://www.plosmedicine.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pmed.1001201

      almost 2 years ago report

    29. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      So what alternative to peer review do you propose then, Elizabeth?

      Your quotes from Furedi are actually not that far off the mark: peer-review is the best method we have available to us for telling us which findings meet the appropriate scholarly standards, such that we don't have any particularly compelling reason to take anything non peer-reviewed seriously. Is it a perfect system? Of course not. (Says the guy who's revising two papers for resubmission at the moment...). Is it open to corruption…

      Read more

      So what alternative to peer review do you propose then, Elizabeth?

      Your quotes from Furedi are actually not that far off the mark: peer-review is the best method we have available to us for telling us which findings meet the appropriate scholarly standards, such that we don't have any particularly compelling reason to take anything non peer-reviewed seriously. Is it a perfect system? Of course not. (Says the guy who's revising two papers for resubmission at the moment...). Is it open to corruption? Potentially, though frankly if the researchers who review papers are corrupt they're not very good at it, given how modest their incomes appear to be. But if you don't accept the authority of peer review, what better form of quality control do you recommend?

      All academic disciplines need a method to screen out data that doesn't meet the appropriate evidentiary and/or argumentative standards. Double-blind peer review, though far from perfect, is the best we've come up with to date. Again, if you have an alternative, I'm all ears. (It would be nice if 'everyone just publishes everything and we all make our own minds up' was an alternative. Unfortunately it simply isn't. As a researcher I don't have years to wade through material that should never have been published in order to find the credible stuff. Without the quality control provided by peer review we simply could never get started).

      almost 2 years ago report

    30. Sue Ieraci

      Public hospital clinician

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      As a self-described "research officer", I'm surprised Elizabeth Hart doesn't understand the dynamics and significance of "peer-review" a bit better.

      The purpose of placing research into the public domain is for an informed audience to critique the methodology and assess whether the conclusions made by the authors bear any merit. The peer review that occurs before publication is only a way of checking whether that paper appears to be suitable for publication in that particular journal. It has to…

      Read more

      As a self-described "research officer", I'm surprised Elizabeth Hart doesn't understand the dynamics and significance of "peer-review" a bit better.

      The purpose of placing research into the public domain is for an informed audience to critique the methodology and assess whether the conclusions made by the authors bear any merit. The peer review that occurs before publication is only a way of checking whether that paper appears to be suitable for publication in that particular journal. It has to reach a threshhold level of quality -in structure, methodology, language, presentation of data etc. Publication does not "validate" the findings - far from it. If all published research were totally valid and without fault, the letters pages would not be filled with debate and critique.

      When journals were only on paper and people either subscribed or went to libraries, the readership was an informed one - people read the material within their professional areas, knowing the other research and understanding the principles behind the practice (whether this was engineering, arboriculture, immunology or paediatrics).

      Now, anyone can find a huge variety of internet-accessed papers, generally without accessing the full papers, and without needing to have any knowledge or understanding of that field.

      Have you produced any published output, Elizabeth? IF so, how do you think it should be handled and communicated to the world?

      It is correct to report and consider information about potential biases in research - the majority of which are methodological and not intentional. These are generally discussed under "Study Limitations". They don't negate the study's findings - but declarations of potential bias should serve to make the reader's critique all the more sophisticated.

      almost 2 years ago report

      Read more

      Well there's peer-review and "peer-review", Ms Sue.

      Sometimes one must examine the fine print.

      Take for example the peer reviewed journal where one local climate expert claimed he'd had his research published. Well, according to the editor of Energy & Environment, it is a peer-reviewed journal - one of the biggest anti-warming journals in the world actually - but not all of it is peer reviewed. Folks of "like minds" can get a paper pubished in the short article section without even basic sub-editing let alone peer review apparently.

      Or the weird but widely quoted journal on climate published by a retired agronomist and his sons in some rustic corner of middle America. Can't remember his name - it'll appear at 2.30am. When one submits an article for publication here one is prompted to provide the names and contact details of three of these very peers who you'd like to review your article. Now that must cut down the paperwork, not to mention the revisions.

      Like everything Ms Sue ... it's buried in these damn satanic details.

      almost 2 years ago report

  22. Doug McNabb

    Engineer

    Don't confuse a good argument for truth. A good argument is useful for being more effective. But, winning an argument only loosely correlates with knowing the truth. Whenever I'm arguing with someone, I (try to) consider that they may be right - even if they don't know _why_ they are right.

    Read more

    Hi Patrick, when I first read this piece a few days ago comments were disabled and I see they are back on now. At the time I was itching to just write a quick not to tell you how fantastic I think this is and now I have the chance. This is a great piece and I hope this link stays accessible for a long time because I will be recommending it to many of my students and to many other people. You have very clearly articulated a very important point about how arguments should proceed that is topical inasmuch as it is so often overlooked in contemporary discussions.

    I saw an example, just yesterday, of similar problems to those you highlight. Tony Abbott presented a power bill in parliament claiming its near doubling was because of the carbon tax, only to be shown that the lady whose bill it was had nearly doubled her power use and that accounted for the increase. Interestingly, a day later an on-line news source reported that the lady still maintains that the carbon tax was responsible for the big increase, or at least more than the 9% stated on her bill. Why, in all seriousness, would a news source report the opinions of someone whose point is that they don't accept an objectively-true fact?

    almost 2 years ago report

    1. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

    2. Guy Curtis

      Senior Lecturer at School of Psychology and Exercise Science, Murdoch University

      In reply to Guy Curtis

      Yes, It was truly silly. The story I read said: "The bill from power firm Synergy also clearly stated that bills were going up by about 9.13 per cent because of the carbon tax." ..."Mrs Verolme believed the increase in her bill due to the carbon tax was more like 20 per cent ""I did the calculation this morning and it looks something like 19 point something, nearly or 20 per cent.""

      So there you have it, she did her own maths (who knows how because she'd not have had access to all the necessary variables) and came up with a different figure than what is stated on the bill and believes her own calculation is more believable than the black-and-white figure on her bill. And, this gets reported as news! The headline was "Pensioner backs Abbott", it could easily have been "Pensioner disputes fact but fails to demonstrate how she's correct to do so".

      The article I was thinking of is here: http://www.watoday.com.au/wa-news/pensioner-backs-abbott-on-bill-20121011-27fau.html

  25. Greg Beattie

    logged in via Facebook

    Patrick

    There's no escaping the fact that we're all entitled to an opinion, as you note in your article (despite the headline). But you suggest we should actively throttle some opinions because they enjoy more popularity than you would like to see. The arbiter here, you suggest, should be 'authority'. It strikes me as a curious appeal for a philosopher to make.

    We do need to carefully scrutinise arguments we (or others) find attractive. But to do so on the basis of authority is foolish. Science…

    Read more

    Patrick

    There's no escaping the fact that we're all entitled to an opinion, as you note in your article (despite the headline). But you suggest we should actively throttle some opinions because they enjoy more popularity than you would like to see. The arbiter here, you suggest, should be 'authority'. It strikes me as a curious appeal for a philosopher to make.

    We do need to carefully scrutinise arguments we (or others) find attractive. But to do so on the basis of authority is foolish. Science is all about enabling valuable arguments to bubble to the top through robust discussion. When policy is debated many things are taken into account, including advice from so-called 'experts', which frequently differs (sometimes substantially and other times not so). But we should never hand the decision making process to a group of (usually interested) experts. Someone who is expert in the field of immunology will likely know precious little about the practical value in a community of a vaccine. I believe there is no qualification which elevates one to the position of 'authority' on this question. Researchers are too specialised in their field. GP's are by and large hopelessly uninformed. I would listen to all their arguments however.

    Meryl Dorey has had the good grace to appear here and open herself to your readers. She is obviously willing to have her arguments examined. Unfortunately some have chosen to attack her on the basis that she isn't a recognised authority. Your editor/moderator has allowed unhelpful comments aimed at a personal level, presumably because the article tacitly invited them. These comments rely almost exclusively on appeal to authority. But ultimately the value of her opinions is found in the strength of her arguments.

    The rational approach is to debate the topic rather than the person. If your readers aren't interested in doing this, they should simply ignore her opinions. If she's having an impact on the wider community, and they don't like it, the only acceptable option is to address her arguments. Alternatively they could call to censor, which is what Meryl claims is happening, and indeed what you appear to be encouraging. Those who attack her lack of recognised status as an authority, or worse, her perceived character, display a weakness in their own position, and do nothing but damage the image of scientists and philosophers in general.

    Obviously this is not the place to weigh the competing arguments on vaccination, but nor is it the place to crucify someone on the altar of authority. Remember, strong arguments don't need authority for their foundation. Weak ones, on the other hand, frequently depend on it. I think your slip is showing.

    almost 2 years ago report

    1. Rohan James Gaiswinkler

      logged in via Facebook

      In reply to Greg Beattie

      "Remember, strong arguments don't need authority for their foundation".

      That's right Greg. As Patrick explained eloquently they need evidence. And where does this evidence come from? From science. And who practices this science, and relays its discoveries to society? Scientists. That's right Greg, EXPERTS in immunology do that. Can non-experts present counter evidence? There is non censorship against them trying. Will they be taken seriously? Only if the evidence is good. There is no conspiracy against the provision of good evidence here.

      You can pin your *argument from authority fallacy* tail on the evidence donkey all you like. It will fall off.

      almost 2 years ago report

    2. Rohan James Gaiswinkler

      logged in via Facebook

      In reply to Greg Beattie

      "Someone who is expert in the field of immunology will likely know precious little about the practical value in a community of a vaccine."

      Lets test this claim by applying it in other domains:

      "Someone who is expert in the field of air traffic control will likely know precious little about the practical value in a community of radar."

      "Someone who is expert in the field of tourism / hospitality will likely know precious little about the practical value in a community of a hotel."

      "Someone who is expert in the field of information technology will likely know precious little about the practical value in a community of an internet connection."

      Epic fail, Greg.

      almost 2 years ago report

    3. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

      In reply to Greg Beattie

      Hi Greg,

      Sorry for the long and somewhat clunky line-by-line response that follows:

      1. “There's no escaping the fact that we're all entitled to an opinion, as you note in your article (despite the headline).”

      - In the relatively thin sense of ‘entitlement’ I identify in the article, yes, but not in the thick sense I discuss (hence the title, which I chose and for which I take full responsibility).

      2. “But you suggest we should actively throttle some opinions because they enjoy more popularity…

      Read more

      Hi Greg,

      Sorry for the long and somewhat clunky line-by-line response that follows:

      1. “There's no escaping the fact that we're all entitled to an opinion, as you note in your article (despite the headline).”

      - In the relatively thin sense of ‘entitlement’ I identify in the article, yes, but not in the thick sense I discuss (hence the title, which I chose and for which I take full responsibility).

      2. “But you suggest we should actively throttle some opinions because they enjoy more popularity than you would like to see.”

      - That's simply not an accurate gloss of what I said. I’m not suggesting some opinions be ‘throttled,’ I’m suggesting we’re not obliged to take them seriously. Nor am I worried by how ‘popular’ they are per se, I’m worried that they’re scientifically unsupported and, given the subject matter, dangerously irresponsible.

      3. “The arbiter here, you suggest, should be 'authority'. It strikes me as a curious appeal for a philosopher to make. We do need to carefully scrutinise arguments we (or others) find attractive. But to do so on the basis of authority is foolish.”

      - It’s a common misconception that appeals to argument are automatically fallacious. They only become fallacious when a) the authority is irrelevant to the question and/or b) we use the appeal to claim more than it can do. Neither a) nor b) is the case when we claim, as I do here, that scientists have authority over non-scientists with respect to (and only with respect to) scientific questions. The downside of our exponentially-expanding knowledge base is that we’ve ended up with fields of knowledge so complex and specialized that technical training and qualification is a prerequisite for being able to speak with any authority about them. Or to put it bluntly: expertise matters.

      4.“When policy is debated many things are taken into account, including advice from so-called 'experts', which frequently differs (sometimes substantially and other times not so). But we should never hand the decision making process to a group of (usually interested) experts.”

      - No-one is suggesting we do that. As I made clear, policy responses to science are a separate matter to the science itself. The benefits and risks of vaccines is a wholly empirical question, and we have precisely one massively successful paradigm for understanding and intervening in empirical reality. Now, if you want to argue that, say, individual autonomy trumps collective welfare, or that there are other moral or policy questions raised by vaccination, that’s another matter entirely. But we need to be clear about what we’re talking about. “No-one has the right to force me to vaccinate my children” is a moral statement, and needs to be argued for morally. We’re all moral agents, and we can all argue for or against such a view. “Vaccines cause autism,” by contrast, is a scientific question and needs to be argued for through the techniques and evidentiary standards of science. At this point in the development of the species, only scientists with specialised training in the relevant area can do that. Whether that statement will count as ‘true’ or ‘false’ will therefore be wholly a function of the prevailing view among those scientists. Let’s just re-state that so there’s no misunderstanding here: with empirical questions, we have no direct access to the ‘fact of the matter;’ we have only the prevailing scientific view at any given time. (For the record, I’m comfortable with the idea that we have other ‘ways of knowing,’ but not as they apply to the physical world).

      5. “Someone who is expert in the field of immunology will likely know precious little about the practical value in a community of a vaccine. I believe there is no qualification which elevates one to the position of 'authority' on this question. Researchers are too specialised in their field.”

      - One would think the ‘practical value’ of a vaccine is whether it lessens the incidence of the given disease without producing results as bad or worse than the disease itself. By definition immunologists and those in related disciplines are the *only* people in a position to answer that complex empirical question. If there are other practical questions then it becomes a policy question, and yes, that’s a broader discussion. But again, we have to avoid conflating the science and the practical responses to it.

      6. “GP's are by and large hopelessly uninformed. I would listen to all their arguments however.”

      - Uninformed relative to what standards? The only relevant standards here being medical ones, the only people in a position to judge that would be medical experts.

      7. “Meryl Dorey has had the good grace to appear here and open herself to your readers. She is obviously willing to have her arguments examined.”

      - I'm very pleased to see her exercising her right to post here, and if Ms. Dorey wants to enter a scientific debate, great. But there are rules of evidence and argument that have to apply in a scientific debate. If Ms. Dorey wants to conduct research, write up her findings, and submit them for peer review, then provided she adheres to appropriate research ethics etc. that’s fine. But that, and that alone, is how scientific questions are examined (see my point about our limited epistemic situation in point 4 above).

      8. “Unfortunately some have chosen to attack her on the basis that she isn't a recognised authority. Your editor/moderator has allowed unhelpful comments aimed at a personal level, presumably because the article tacitly invited them. These comments rely almost exclusively on appeal to authority.”

      - It’s not attacking someone on a personal level to say that when people make pronouncements they’re not qualified to make, they do not have any prima facie entitlement to be taken seriously.

      9. “But ultimately the value of her opinions is found in the strength of her arguments.”

      - Again, if Ms. Dorey or anyone else wants to make philosophical/ethical/political arguments, that is true. But if she or anyone else wants to make scientific claims, that has to happen in peer-reviewed journals if it is to have any validity at all.

      10. “The rational approach is to debate the topic rather than the person. If your readers aren't interested in doing this, they should simply ignore her opinions. If she's having an impact on the wider community, and they don't like it, the only acceptable option is to address her arguments.”

      - Except that every time someone claims “Vaccines cause autism!” and science responds “Actually we’ve found no evidence of that” the original claims just keep being re-asserted. Exactly how many times does an argument have to be ‘addressed’ before those making it modify or abandon their claims? Is that not also a non-negotiable tenet of rational discussion – that you admit when you’ve been proven to be wrong?

      11. “Alternatively they could call to censor, which is what Meryl claims is happening, and indeed what you appear to be encouraging.”

      - Again, this is clearly not what I said and is not entailed by anything I said either. Consider again the distinction I drew between the two senses of ‘entitlement’ in the article. Censorship would be preventing a view from being expressed i.e. violating the thin sense of entitlement. Not giving equal airtime to all views when not all views have equal standing within the topic does not violate the thin sense of entitlement; hence, declining to give unqualified views airtime alongside overwhelming scientific consensus as if both were equally valid isn’t censorship.

      12. “Those who attack her lack of recognised status as an authority, or worse, her perceived character, display a weakness in their own position, and do nothing but damage the image of scientists and philosophers in general.”

      - As far as I know I’m the only philosopher commenting here at present, and I think (and certainly would hope) I’ve steered pretty clear of ad hom (as per my response to no.8). I’m not sure how it weakens a scientific argument to point out that the person making the counter-argument doesn’t possess the relevant qualifications to evaluate the evidence.

      13. “Obviously this is not the place to weigh the competing arguments on vaccination, but nor is it the place to crucify someone on the altar of authority. Remember, strong arguments don't need authority for their foundation. Weak ones, on the other hand, frequently depend on it.”

      - That would be true if we lived in a world where each and every one of us was qualified to evaluate the merit of every argument. Unfortunately this simply isn’t the case with respect to scientific questions. If you want to call that worshipping at an ‘altar of authority,’ fine. I’d suggest that’s preferable to sacrificing the value of expertise – and by extension the value of advanced education – in the name of our need to feel we’re entitled to have our views taken seriously regardless of qualification.

      14. "I think your slip is showing"

      - Argh! I knew wearing a dress today was a mistake...

      Best regards,
      Patrick

      almost 2 years ago report

      You showed your true colours when you finished your post with the misogynist, sexist comment "I think your slip is showing". Is that where you had to go? Implying that Patrick was behaving like a woman and therefore his beliefs and arguments were not worthy of a man.

    5. Sue Ieraci

      In reply to Greg Beattie

      Greg Beattie says "Science is all about enabling valuable arguments to bubble to the top through robust discussion. "

      Not so, Mr Beattie - science is about testing "valuable arguments" rigorously, looking at the evidence, and rejecting or revising the "argument" on the basis of the findings.

      The arguments raised repeatedly by yourself, Ms Dorey and others have been examined and de-bunked, also repeatedly.

      People who are inexpert in the area the argue about frequently use the (derogatory) allegation 'experts'', as if having knowledge, training and experience in an specific area of practice somehow disqualifies you from commenting in your own area.

      What instead - prefer the views of the untrained and inexperienced because they are not 'experts'?

    8. Greg Beattie

      logged in via Facebook

      In reply to Greg Beattie

      Patrick

      Thanks for your friendly reply. I'll make this brief because I'm travelling and in and out of reception.

      You say an appeal to authority is not automatically fallacious. Sure, but take note: I didn't claim your argument was fallacious. I said it was weak, as it rested exclusively on the appeal. The same applies to your commenters who've joined you in the attack on Meryl.

      As for the thrust of your article, I don't accept that all you're trying to say is some opinions deserve more…

      Read more

      Patrick

      Thanks for your friendly reply. I'll make this brief because I'm travelling and in and out of reception.

      You say an appeal to authority is not automatically fallacious. Sure, but take note: I didn't claim your argument was fallacious. I said it was weak, as it rested exclusively on the appeal. The same applies to your commenters who've joined you in the attack on Meryl.

      As for the thrust of your article, I don't accept that all you're trying to say is some opinions deserve more weight than others. I'll tell you why. We all already know that some opinions deserve more weight. That's a given. Right or wrongly, we all tend to favour opinions and arguments pitched by experts. There's no need to throw your weight behind that notion. It simply doesn't make for an article worth writing or reading, in my opinion.

      Think about it this way: the main thrust of Meryl's argument is that there are problems with the popular orthodox viewpoint. You write an article claiming she can't be taken seriously because she's not of the popular orthodoxy! Do I need to point out that if that's all you're saying then you're not really saying much?

      I think it's quite obvious you're trying to convey much more. The reason I think this is you coloured the article in the following ways:

      1. You made refernce to Meryl's views as 'bulldust'. Sure you didn't use your own words to do so because, as you pointed out, you aren't qualified to make that call. Only experts are. In this case your expert was TV presenter Jonathon Holmes.... mmm.

      2. "Meryl Dorey is the leader of the Australian Vaccination Network, which despite the name is vehemently anti-vaccine." What do you suggest they change the name to? (Please don't say you don't know enough about the AVN to make that call).

      3. The title is: "No, you're not entitled to your opinion". A title like that certainly sets the scene for a censorship call, don't you think? And surely censorship is merely the end play of a gradual campaign aimed at eroding the freedom to express, and broadcast.

      So, in summary, I think you certainly are 1. buying into the scientific argument, although in a weak fashion, and 2. making a call designed to encourage censorship. I think it's fairly plain to see you don't like the fact that some media broadcasters have shown interest in Meryl's views. But ultimately, they've shown interest because people have shown interest.

      An argument which doesn't have the support of authority needs to be quite robust/appealing to get anywhere. Meryl has gained some followers and Mediawatch (and now you) have responded with a call to diminish the effect she's having. Right or wrong, that's what you're doing.

      I hope you didn't take my "slip" comment the way Linda did. I don't know how she dragged what she did from it. It refers to someone being unaware of a flaw in their outfit: one which others can see quite easily due to the fact that they're looking from a different angle. Like someone pointing out your fly is undone. In this case you presented yourself as a philosopher, but your argument was exclusively based on appeal to authority. I know you reject this, and I suppose I have to defer to your judgement, in line with the article. :-)

      I know I'm pulling your rope a bit here. I've no doubt you have a greater knowledge and understanding of philosophy than I do, but I would hazard a guess and say you possibly don't know much about the vaccine issue. Perhaps you don't even understand why Meryl holds her views. Perhaps you don't want to know because you feel it's not your business. Your a philosopher... not a doctor, right? And only doctors should involve themselves with such things.

      The other issue I'd like to address is that of who the 'experts' are. Someone took exception to me enclosing the word in quotes, but I do that because it's difficult to work out who the experts are. I know you disagree with this also, but I'll have to write more later (providing comments don't get closed down). I've been traveling for work and have just arrived in a city and managed to get internet access, and to be honest I'm tired. I said I would be brief but it turned out not so.

      Thanks again
      Greg

      almost 2 years ago report

    9. Greg Beattie

      logged in via Facebook

      In reply to Greg Beattie

      Patrick

      OK. Now to the question of who the 'experts' are. I understand you regard this as a straighforward question with a straightforward answer: namely doctors (and particularly immunologists). But as I said earlier, I suspect you don't know much about the 'issue'. I take a more careful approach and suggest we need to first consider what our questions are. Let's start with benefit. As consumers we're surely interested in evaluating this first to give us something against which to compare the…

      Read more

      Patrick

      OK. Now to the question of who the 'experts' are. I understand you regard this as a straighforward question with a straightforward answer: namely doctors (and particularly immunologists). But as I said earlier, I suspect you don't know much about the 'issue'. I take a more careful approach and suggest we need to first consider what our questions are. Let's start with benefit. As consumers we're surely interested in evaluating this first to give us something against which to compare the likelihood of harm. So we're going to be looking for an expert who knows its track record: someone familiar with the empirical evidence and able to answer, for example: "How has vaccination affected mortality and morbidity?"

      Immunology is the study of the 'immune system'. As such it doesn't offer any expertise to our question. I'll cut to the chase... it's no secret other doctors are similarly unsuitable, with the exception of epidemiologists. So why don't we ask epidemiologists? Well we could but most of them haven't looked at the question. In fact, one of them commenting here readily admits (Candice, in another forum) she has litle knowledge of the relevant data. So what is this unified voice with which everyone speaks when describing vaccination as the most successful medical intervention ever? Or when it tells the story of how vaccines delivered us from the dark days of unbearably high death rates? Well, it's a choir simply singing a well known song.

      Hence suggesting consumers need to rely on experts for their answers is already looking a little more problematic than initially thought. The relevant experts are not where we thought they would be, and the loud choir is largely an army of faithful drones. (And I ask other commenters to resist the temptation to accuse me of disrespect re the term 'drones'. I use it here as a shorthand to describe those who don't investige but are happy to sing the song.) Still that doesn't mean the song is wrong. But wait... there's more.

      We don't actually need experts for this. We can look at it ourselves. Of course few want to go to that trouble. Most simply listen to the choir, like you suggest. But what if there are compelling arguments suggesting the choir is off-key? Ironically, it was well-known philosopher, Ivan Illich, who compelled me to question things a long time ago. He claimed the choir's song was completely wrong. I found this confronting, and realised I could actually check for myself. It didn't require any specialised skills, just a modest numeracy and analytic ability, both of which I had. So that's what I did. It wasn't hard. It was tedious, but not challenging from a skills perspective.

      So now we have two changes. First, those we initially thought were the experts, in fact aren't. Second, those we initially thought were helpless (ourselves), in fact aren't. We have the capability to evaluate things ourselves to an extent. Sure, it's not everyone's cup of tea but we can do so if we wish. So Patrick, I think you are way off base when you say medical people in general, and immunologists in particular, are the 'only' people in a position to judge.

      But what about other issues such as the autism controversy? Should we venture that far? To cut a long story short, many who look into the previous question conclude the song is in fact not in line with the evidence. Vaccines didn't deliver us from those horrid scenes of death and misery. What part did they play? Probably precious little. Possibly nothing. The most reliable data suggests no role whatsoever. But the choir.... what about the unified voice of the experts? Remember this is the fundamental claim used to market vaccination. And there, Patrick, is the issue. The choir is indeed singing in unison, the vast majority blissfully unaware of the song. And these are the experts we defer to for our remaining questions!

      You must realise this is not a pure science we're talking about. It's open to interpretation. Some will agree with the conclusions I mention above. Others won't. There are various viewpoints arising from the evidence (and a significant amount of the variance is among medically trained people). The fact that 90-something percent of the choir is singing in unison means little if 90-something percent are just following the others. The song may be right or it may be wrong. But to suggest we leave it up to the choir to decide is, let me say it.... 'bulldust'. It's perfectly reasonable to question. Most don't. They simply hear the loud choir and conclude it must be beyond question. I believe that's roughly where you sit at present, Patrick.

      Those are my thoughts. I apologise for the length. It's a complex issue.
      All the best.

      almost 2 years ago report

    10. Peter Ormonde
      Peter Ormonde is a Friend of The Conversation.

      Farmer

      In reply to Greg Beattie

      I don't like the term "expert". I have worked with experts. It is not easy.

      By definition an expert has literally come to absorb a form of knowledge that only comes with deep familiarity. A "sense of smell" that is in essence innate. They can hear that something is wrong with the second injector in your old diesel, that that isn't running right, that there's a step missing, that the plan won't work.... but they can't actually tell you. Not without a major effort at unpacking assumptions, thoughts…

      Read more

      I don't like the term "expert". I have worked with experts. It is not easy.

      By definition an expert has literally come to absorb a form of knowledge that only comes with deep familiarity. A "sense of smell" that is in essence innate. They can hear that something is wrong with the second injector in your old diesel, that that isn't running right, that there's a step missing, that the plan won't work.... but they can't actually tell you. Not without a major effort at unpacking assumptions, thoughts they are oblivious to, leaps over the obvious...

      Give me someone with knowledge and ideas over an expert anytime.

      Unless you want your diesel tuned.

      One of the things that seems to emerge in these discussions is that for some folks they have no idea what investigation and research actually involves... that there are no rules or tests... one just gets a bee in one's bonnet and starts reading similars... and there it is ... lots of other folks saying the same thing and that's evidence innit?

      For some folks schooling has failed them badly. They have not learned to learn. They do not learn - they prop up a starting position. They dismiss "learning" ... a conspiracy of vested interests...there is no real information ... no Truth... science doesn't know, so my guess is as good as theirs.

      The information hyperplasma has given these folks a voice. Friends. Supporters. Believers. Dressing gowns and foil beanies.

      What is to be done?

      almost 2 years ago report

    12. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

      In reply to Greg Beattie

      Hi Greg,

      Sorry for the delayed reply; the dreaded marking monster is stirring again – and for that reason this reply will be a little truncated. Might have more to add later.

      I’m not saying Ms Dorey shouldn’t be taken seriously simply because she disagrees with the popular orthodoxy (by which I assume you mean the prevalent view among researchers and practitioners within the relevant disciplines). But there are two ways you could critique such orthodoxy. You can either make a case within the…

      Read more

      Hi Greg,

      Sorry for the delayed reply; the dreaded marking monster is stirring again – and for that reason this reply will be a little truncated. Might have more to add later.

      I’m not saying Ms Dorey shouldn’t be taken seriously simply because she disagrees with the popular orthodoxy (by which I assume you mean the prevalent view among researchers and practitioners within the relevant disciplines). But there are two ways you could critique such orthodoxy. You can either make a case within the canons of scientific research, or you can attack the scientific paradigm from the outside. If you’re going to do the former, quite simply you have to have the training (more on this below), and you have to abide by the evidentiary standards of that paradigm. If you’re going to argue against science from without, that’s a very different kettle of fish. In that case, you need to defend another knowledge paradigm and show it to be as or more effective at explaining and manipulating the physical universe. What it’s not open to us to do is to make scientific claims while not working to the evidentiary standards of science, as those standards define the truth-value of a scientific claim.

      In short, you can play soccer, or you can play rugby, but what you can’t do is pick up the ball and then insist you’re still playing soccer, only better.

      Now, you say that it’s “a given” that “we all tend to favour opinions and arguments pitched by experts” and thus “There's no need to throw your weight behind that notion.” Yet you go on to assert that it only takes “just a modest numeracy and analytic ability” in order to start critiquing claims made within science.

      Let’s just dwell on that for a minute: you presume that your self-described “modest numeracy and analytic ability” (and I’m sure you’re being too modest here) are sufficient to trump people who have the same ability *plus* extensive training *in their field*. And that is indeed one of the reasons why I felt the need to write the article and why weight needed to be thrown behind it: this widespread assumption that there’s no special insight conferred by advanced education, that ‘anyone can do it.’ It’s the whole “I went to the School of Life!” retort writ large.

      One of our guys, Rene Descartes, wrote “Of all things, good sense is the most fairly distributed: everyone thinks he is so well supplied with it that even those who are the hardest to satisfy in every other respect never desire more of it than they already have.” We all trust our ‘common sense,’ and it’s very hard to accept that when our common sense conflicts with what someone with advanced knowledge tells us that it’s our common sense that has to yield. (Actually I’ve had precisely this argument with 9/11 ‘Truthers’ before: my rudimentary high school maths doesn’t trump what an engineer says, no matter how self-evident things seem to me – because in addition to an engineering degree, he did high school maths too. And unlike me, he presumably didn’t suck at it). But that’s how it is, I’m afraid. As I said in my last post, this is the price we pay for advanced knowledge as a species.

      You suggest that there are no ‘experts’ available on the present topic. I’ll leave it to others to point to the epidemiological literature on this. But here’s where your choir metaphor breaks down: if 90% are apparently singing in tune and 10% are off, the audience, being astute music critics, can say which is singing ‘correctly’ and which is wrong. However, when we’re talking science, ‘truth’ is simply a function of the weight of findings. There’s no external right or wrong for the ‘audience’ to judge the ‘choir’ against. So your claim that “to suggest we leave it up to the choir to decide is, let me say it.... 'bulldust'” falls down here, because if we agree these are scientific questions, there’s no-one else to decide. Scientific questions have to be decided scientifically; there’s no other available standard of truth for such questions. Now again, if you’re going to argue that we have ways of getting at the nature of physical reality other than science, let’s hear it. Otherwise, you can either sit in the pews or join the choir. But as with a real choir, raw talent isn’t enough – you need the training.

      On the name of the AVN: my point was simply that, given that vaccination is widely reckoned to be a good thing, one would think an organization of that name would be pro-vaccine or at least neutral. You’d be surprised if the Australian Breastfeeding Association turned out to be anti-breastfeeding, or if the Cancer Council turned out to be pro-cancer.

      I don’t think my article title “sets the scene for a censorship call,” no. That particular slope would need quite a lot of greasing to get to the slippery stage. All I am saying is that fringe views that are not backed by relevant expertise don’t have a prima facie case to be taken seriously in the interests of ‘balance.’ A right to free speech doesn’t mean everyone gets a turn on the megaphone. I take it that’s also the point Jonathan Holmes was making, and being an ethical/policy point it’s one that he, me, you and anyone else can defend or contest. I understand that on the AVN page today Ms Dorey wrote that “yes, you ARE entitled to your own opinion on this and every other issue, as opposed to what Patrick Stokes has said - Australia is still a democracy.” Indeed it is, thankfully. And in a democracy each of us exercises a tiny amount of power over each other. That in turn creates a moral responsibility to make sure that we can back up our views – otherwise we’re just using that power arbitrarily.

      You also note that Ms Dorey has attracted considerable attention and interest. But that makes not a jot of difference to the scientific validity of what she says. Likewise, the reasons why Ms. Dorey holds the views she does also have no impact on their scientific validity. You speak of “many who look into the previous question” and have concluded otherwise – then let them publish in peer-reviewed outlets. That’s where the action is.

      All best,
      Patrick

      almost 2 years ago report

    13. Greg Beattie

      logged in via Facebook

      In reply to Greg Beattie

      Patrick

      No need to apologise. We all have busy lives. Thanks for taking the time.

      1. You say we have two options if we wish to critique the orthodoxy: get 'training' then join the discussion, or discuss it from some other (I assume you mean non-scientific) paradigm. Some questions. For the first option, what is training? What about someone educated in statistics? Economics? Auditing? Or others. Is it only medical quals? Should GP's, who have no specialised training for our questions, bend…

      Read more

      Patrick

      No need to apologise. We all have busy lives. Thanks for taking the time.

      1. You say we have two options if we wish to critique the orthodoxy: get 'training' then join the discussion, or discuss it from some other (I assume you mean non-scientific) paradigm. Some questions. For the first option, what is training? What about someone educated in statistics? Economics? Auditing? Or others. Is it only medical quals? Should GP's, who have no specialised training for our questions, bend our ears more than others? What about people who are self-educated? Some examples:

      Darwin and Wallace (evolution, geology, geography...)
      Faraday (electricity)
      Herschel (astronomy)
      Ramanujan (mathematics)
      Mary Anning (geology)
      Mendel (genetics)

      These were some of the most influential scientists of all time, and all changed our world profoundly, despite no formal training in science. Einstein also had some interesting views on formal education. A couple of his quotes:

      "It is a miracle that curiosity survives formal education."
      "The only thing that interferes with my learning is my education."

      So formal education is certainly not a prerequisite for contributing to or discussing science.

      Quoting you - "What it’s not open to us to do is to make scientific claims while not working to the evidentiary standards of science, as those standards define the truth-value of a scientific claim." I don't think anyone here is proposing that. As I said, Meryl is asking to be judged by her arguments rather than by people's perceptions of her 'self' or how educated she is. This is a very reasonable request. I'd argue true science would regard it as an expectation.

      2. Regarding the notion that we all have a tendency to defer to experts, you say I don't trump someone with similar ability plus extra training in their field. Sure, but that wasn't at all what I said. I said that (for example) immunologists are not in a better position by virtue of their extra training, unless that extra training is directly relevant to the question. And in relation to the questions I raised earlier, it most certainly isn't. I would add that they're obviously in a worse position if they haven't investigated the question anyway. Remember, you initially assumed immunologists were the 'experts'. This was a poor assumption, and your conclusion was based on it. Their specialised training won't help for the questions I posed earlier. It may help them shed light on mechanisms by which vaccines may help or harm our bodies, but it gives them no special skill in evaluating their track record in preventing death or suffering; nor of them doing so safely. And these are our primary questions. Although immunologists may be some of the loudest voices in the choir, remember, they have a vested interest in singing, as I guess do all medical people.

      3. You missed the point of my choir analogy. We aren't trying to gauge how well the choir are singing. I was pointing out that, as it was a choir, we EXPECT them all to be singing the same tune. But that doesn't mean the tune is the right one. The whole choir may be singing the wrong tune. We can't judge that simply by noting that they're all singing the same. Yet that's the basis of your argument: that the 'experts' appear to be singing the same tune. I pointed out that we can expect that, because the choir is populated mostly by 'drones', who have no specialised training to offer the question, and haven't investigated it anyway. They are simply repeating the opinions of those who claim to have done so, who are very few in number.
      (However, I'll take the blame for this misunderstanding, as I muddied the analogy by talking about singing off-key.... which you interpreted as the choir not singing together. I meant singing off-key 'as a choir').

      Anyway, you shouldn't be debating this with me because I'm formally trained in music. :-)

      almost 2 years ago report

    14. Sue Ieraci

      Public hospital clinician

      In reply to Greg Beattie

      Greg Beattie - your list of self-taught innovators shows a fundamental misunderstanding of the way scientific knowledge is built.

      There is no branch of science - be it astronomy, immunology, geophysics or botany - that is built on the theoriy of a single person.

      Yes, thinkers can develop revolutionary ideas. To be useful however, they need to be both feasible and demonstrable, measurable, repeatable. We don't treat stomach ulcers with anitbiotics just because someone thought it might be a good…

      Read more

      Greg Beattie - your list of self-taught innovators shows a fundamental misunderstanding of the way scientific knowledge is built.

      There is no branch of science - be it astronomy, immunology, geophysics or botany - that is built on the theoriy of a single person.

      Yes, thinkers can develop revolutionary ideas. To be useful however, they need to be both feasible and demonstrable, measurable, repeatable. We don't treat stomach ulcers with anitbiotics just because someone thought it might be a good idea - the evidence was produced, as was the test to detect helicobacter pylori in an individual.

      Darwin conceived the theory for evolution of the species, but it was the huge amount of subsequent evidence found that solidified the scientific model.

      Your choir analogy - though drawn from your area of expertise - doesn't work in science. The choir doesn't keep singing the same tune of lyrics - they are constantly questioned, reviewed, updated. The fact that you are not aware of those processes does not mean that they don't occur.

      almost 2 years ago report

  26. account deleted

    logged in via email @gmail.com

    Children, please!

    This is neither edifying or educative.It's not even entertaining.

    The questions being asked are legitimate.They may not be especially useful, but that doesn't justify the vitriol being sprayed about by people who are obviously capable of much better.

    If the science is clear, just say so and point to the research. If it's not, why are yu getting so hot under the collar? Just acknowledge there are gaps and perhaps seek some funding to close those gaps, or wait for the research…

    Read more

    Children, please!

    This is neither edifying or educative.It's not even entertaining.

    The questions being asked are legitimate.They may not be especially useful, but that doesn't justify the vitriol being sprayed about by people who are obviously capable of much better.

    If the science is clear, just say so and point to the research. If it's not, why are yu getting so hot under the collar? Just acknowledge there are gaps and perhaps seek some funding to close those gaps, or wait for the research of others to do so.

    Science doesn't advance by debate, but by discussion and the classic path of observation, hypothesis, test, This has descended into that "town hall meeting" that somebody mentioned above.

    I'll just make the observation that what is being discussed here is not science, it is risk-management. The pro-vaxers are discussing the stochastic risk to the population, a standard public-health consideration, while the anti-vaxers are dicussing the deterministic risk to individuals. They see that risk as unacceptably high, given the possible hazard presented (ASD). Some of the pro-vaxers have got quite personal in dismissing that concern about a possible hazard, but even if the risk is small, it's a big issue if your child is the one affected, especially if they suffer severe debilitation.

    I have no personal understanding of the topic of vaccines, as I've said before, but I:do understand risk and hazard assessment. Given that the hazard of such a deterministic outcome exists, it is not unreasonable to manage it. te question then becomes whether the risk is great enough to outweigh the potential individual benefits.The public health people say it is, the anti-vaxers say it isn't.

    What is the quantifiable risk of a negative deterministic event and what is the quantifiable individual benefit? I think the public health herd immunity argument is moot, given that the anti-vaxers are asking for an individual choice.

    almost 2 years ago report

    1. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

      In reply to account deleted

      "What is the quantifiable risk of a negative deterministic event and what is the quantifiable individual benefit? I think the public health herd immunity argument is moot, given that the anti-vaxers are asking for an individual choice." - This is curious. You're saying that because someone refuses to accept that collective responsibility may outweigh individual autonomy in certain instances, we have to completely set aside the moral value of collective goods like herd immunity?

      I say this is…

      Read more

      "What is the quantifiable risk of a negative deterministic event and what is the quantifiable individual benefit? I think the public health herd immunity argument is moot, given that the anti-vaxers are asking for an individual choice." - This is curious. You're saying that because someone refuses to accept that collective responsibility may outweigh individual autonomy in certain instances, we have to completely set aside the moral value of collective goods like herd immunity?

      I say this is curious because even the most anarchistic versions of libertarianism acknowledge at least some safety-related collective goods that impose responsibilities on individuals - for instance, the responsibility to fund some sort of police and defence force. One could easily say that herd immunity has a similar structural role to a defence system, with the 'enemy' in this case being particular pathogens rather than hostile foreign powers.

      I'm also very doubtful we could, with any real ethical seriousness, discuss vaccination as a *wholly* individual question, given the decision to vaccinate is a) made on behalf of another person (i.e. the child) and b) affects other individuals besides (particularly those who cannot be vaccinated, are immuno-compromised etc.).

      almost 2 years ago report

    2. account deleted

      logged in via email @gmail.com

      In reply to account deleted

      I must have been unclear. All I'm saying is that knowing what the stats are isn't much benefit if you are coming from the POV that no amount of risk to your child is acceptable.

      I agree completely with the public health argument and the common good, but unless the pro-vaxers can nominate a zero risk, I suspect the anti-vaxers will remain unconvinced. In that case, it comes down to whether the risk that they pose as unvaccinated potential hosts of the pathogen is sufficient to justify coercion.

      My own children were properly vaccinated with no ill-effects as far as can be discerned.

      almost 2 years ago report

    3. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

      In reply to account deleted

      Ah right, got it. Unfortunately there's simply no zero-risk option available here, so it's all about weighing competing risks - and as a species we don't seem terribly well equipped to assess probability on a first-personal level, as any casino owner can probably attest (while lighting his cigar on a burning Rembrandt and dining on roast unicorn). Asking us to put a reduced risk of an abstract future risk ahead of the very present and visceral fear of being injected with something is no doubt asking us to overcome a lot of evolutionary heritage. But for me and my kids it was a pretty simple decision.

      almost 2 years ago report

      It's a pretty vexed issue, really.

    6. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

      In reply to account deleted

      I think the coercion question is a valid one to consider. Sometimes we do have to compel people to fulfil their obligations to others, but it's always a serious business and must be well-justified. In this case I'd suggest the relative risks and benefits make the case for it pretty clear.

      almost 2 years ago report

    8. account deleted

      In reply to account deleted

      Hi Debra, you seem to be quite willing to require the coercion of others. I wonder if you'd be quite so keen on it if you were the one being compelled to do something you don't want to do, especially when the primary argument being used to justify the coercion is that it will be good for everybody, while you are of the view that it will be bad for you?

      It's easy to sit back and say with great gravitas "this is a noble cause, everybody must be made to go along with it", but I'd like to see how…

      Read more

      Hi Debra, you seem to be quite willing to require the coercion of others. I wonder if you'd be quite so keen on it if you were the one being compelled to do something you don't want to do, especially when the primary argument being used to justify the coercion is that it will be good for everybody, while you are of the view that it will be bad for you?

      It's easy to sit back and say with great gravitas "this is a noble cause, everybody must be made to go along with it", but I'd like to see how you draw the line between noble causes that don't justify coercion and those that do.

      When does the end justify the means and when is it just bullying? Is there any kind of empirical relationship in your mind, or is it simply ad hoc or even post hoc? The public health argument is essentially utilitarian, while the argument from the anti-vaxers is essentally libertarian, with a flavouring of liberalism. It's not easy to reconcile those two very different approaches, it seems to me, without resorting to a reduction per se in the rights of individuals to self-determine and possibly to take self-protective action. You musn't forget that the essential argument of the anti-vaxers is that the risk to their kids (of a negative outcome causing an ASD) is of greater import to them than the community benefit justifies. They see childhood diseases like the MMR set as a part of growing up, whilst ASD is seen as a pure negative. Some high-functioning Aspies might dispute that, but more severe debilitation is quite catastrophic.

      Simply abusing them as stupid or somehow wilfully obstrucive doesn't actually address that point and nor does a public health stochastic analysis. The only thing that would be effective is showing that either the childhood diseases are themselves likely to be catastrophic and that they have a high risk of being contracted, or that the vaccines are absolutely benign with respect to the serious side-effects that are being claimed.

      If it is your purpose to convince them, then you need to grow a thicker skin and use your superior understanding of the science to make your case.

      It can't possibly be done if there is an assumption of bad faith on either side of the argument..

      almost 2 years ago report

      "The only thing that would be effective is showing that either the childhood diseases are themselves likely to be catastrophic and that they have a high risk of being contracted"

      Sometimes I wish anti-vaxxers would all collect together in one community and, in so doing, allow this evidence to be collected. It is already known that measles, for example, is extremely contagious, and infants (who can't develop immunity) can die from pertussis.

      It is only because vaccines have brought disease…

      Read more

      "The only thing that would be effective is showing that either the childhood diseases are themselves likely to be catastrophic and that they have a high risk of being contracted"

      Sometimes I wish anti-vaxxers would all collect together in one community and, in so doing, allow this evidence to be collected. It is already known that measles, for example, is extremely contagious, and infants (who can't develop immunity) can die from pertussis.

      It is only because vaccines have brought disease rates down that anti-vaxxers have the luxury of choosing not to vaccinate without being particularly likely to suffer the ill effects of that choice.

      You will never get a zero risk with vaccines, just as you will never get zero risk when choosing what type of vehicle to buy. Parents that do not want to place their children at any risk will never take them (or let them travel) anywhere on roads. Most parents, however, would buy the safest they can afford, and accept whatever risk comes along with it. They concede that the benefits of transport are worth the risk of being driven into by a useless driver.

      almost 2 years ago report
