    Read more

    Thank you Patrick. I am constantly trying to say this to people. As the time when I am constantly trying to say this is usually in a bar, I am nowhere near as articulate or logical as you.

    As a lawyer I am well used to being asked a legal question and, before I have even taken a breath to answer, the questioner launches into telling me what the legal position is. This is usually based on their one experience of getting a divorce/challenging a red light ticket/getting an intervention order etc. If I dare to disagree with their interpretation of the law I am usually told 'well, I'm entitled to my opinion'. If I reply that legal processes are not a matter of opinion (clearly jurisprudence is) and I spend lots more time dealing with legal processes than they do, the person will usually just repeat that they are entitled to their opinion. To which I usually reply that I vastly regret spending so many years and paying so much HECs to get a law degree, when clearly I could have spent just as much, but had more fun, sitting in a pub and gathering various 'opinions' on how law works.

    In future I will simply hand this article to people and go order the drinks while they read it. Satre, of course, said much the same thing beautifully in Anti-Semite and Jew. Perhaps I'll hand the person both and find someone else to drink with!

    http://www.freerepublic.com/focus/news/675238/posts

    almost 2 years ago report

  28. Baz B

    Writer/Researcher at Them

    The article makes a statement which I believe is demonstrably false, namely that there is congruence within the ranks of suitably qualified immunologists on this topic, especially in regard to dismissing a proposed vaccine/autism causality.

    I have been in contact with immunologists from around the world, and where they are able to operate in an independent framework, they often contend similar things along the lines of minimal vaccine efficacy, and wide ranging adverse reactions.

    At the recent…

    Read more

    The article makes a statement which I believe is demonstrably false, namely that there is congruence within the ranks of suitably qualified immunologists on this topic, especially in regard to dismissing a proposed vaccine/autism causality.

    I have been in contact with immunologists from around the world, and where they are able to operate in an independent framework, they often contend similar things along the lines of minimal vaccine efficacy, and wide ranging adverse reactions.

    At the recent Vaccine Safety Conference in Jamaica some of the world’s top professionals in this area presented their ideas and concerns, especially about the effects of aluminium as a vaccine additive, and a possible causal role with a broad range of neurological disorders, auto immune dysfunction, and digestive issues.

    I will draw your attention to a few examples:

    The senior post doctoral researchers in vaccine safety at the Univeristy of British Columbia, Dr Lucija Tomijanovic and Professor Chris Shaw, contend that aluminium adjuvents are most probably linked to autism.. Their article here:
    http://omsj.org/reports/tomljenovic%202011.pdf

    Dr Yehuda Shoenfeld, who organised the conference talks about aluminium’s role in auto immune dysfunction here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wf8sw3n7xrE

    Professor Shaw on aluminium neuro toxicity here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fmgw3KNjEJ4

    Dr Blaylock on aluminium and mercury derived vaccine additives and their health risks: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u9DkcpEEBPI

    Dr Susan Markel, a member of the US Board of Pediatrics on childhood vaccines: http://www.attachmentparentingdoctor.com/vaccinations.html

    There’s plenty more…..

    In terms of MMR, it is worth noting that it has been banned in Japan since the early 90’s after around 1.3 million adverse reactions were noted. In more recent times an Italian court ruled that it caused a boy’s autism, after drawing upon a considerable body of expert testimony. You can read about it here:
    http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2160054/MMR-A-mothers-victory-The-vast-majority-doctors-say-link-triple-jab-autism-Italian-court-case-reignite-controversial-debate.html

    I am not suggesting for a moment that this constitutes definitive proof, but it does illustrate that eminently qualified professionals would disagree with the article's assertion. The book ‘Vaccine Illusion’ by immunologist Dr Tetyana Obukhanych:
    http://www.amazon.com/Vaccine-Illusion-ebook/dp/B007AW2CLG
    In the introduction she states: 'I never imagined myself in this position, least so in the very beginning of my Ph.D. research training in immunology. In fact, at that time, I was very enthusiastic about the concept of vaccination, just like any typical immunologist. However, after years of doing research in immunology, observing scientific activities of my superiors, and analyzing vaccine issues, I realized that vaccination is one of the most deceptive inventions the science could ever convince the world to accept.'

    There is much talk of 'logic' here, but when eminently qualified immunologists make statements like this, we need to pay attention, be vigilant about dogma and exercise true scientific principles, namely the constant questioning of of the assumptions we operate under. Science must always be open to new inputs.

    almost 2 years ago report

      Dear Baz,

      I cannot comment of your references until I have given the the respect of a thorough reading. Thank you, though for pushing my education forward in these matters.

      Initially, though I would remind both of us that there can be no conferences of merit without opposing views no matter how narrowly that expert is focused. On many mainstream issues, we have to look at minutia to continue to move forward.

      EVERYONE- most especially the scientists and experts grieve at any detrimental effect but I submit that NOT one of your experts would advocate the whole sale rejection of vaccinations. They just want to see them improved and spend their lives trying to make that happen on a practical level. Upsetting the public with the cutting edge efforts to do so which can be a great PhD thesis, is not what most try to do. They do seem to try to keep the good in place while working furiously to improve things. These are the last people in the world with their heads in the sand, wouldn't you agree? Now, I am not talking about a few wronglly invested academics but true scientists.

    2. Sue Ieraci

      In reply to Baz B

      Baz Bardoe - you don't state your area of research, but it clearly isn't a clinical one.

      The references you cite re-appear on so many of the anti-vax sites. Tomljanovic and Shaw have no clinical credibility - they have posed a theoretical question from their roles within non-clinical ophthalmology research. They are frequently quoted by anti-vaxers.

      Blaylock is a retired neurosurgeon who is a "born again" anti-vaxer. He has no credibility in that specialist communities of immunology, infectious…

      Read more

      Baz Bardoe - you don't state your area of research, but it clearly isn't a clinical one.

      The references you cite re-appear on so many of the anti-vax sites. Tomljanovic and Shaw have no clinical credibility - they have posed a theoretical question from their roles within non-clinical ophthalmology research. They are frequently quoted by anti-vaxers.

      Blaylock is a retired neurosurgeon who is a "born again" anti-vaxer. He has no credibility in that specialist communities of immunology, infectious diseases or paediatrics.

      The Italian court decision is likely to be overturned on appeal - it is an illogical legal opinion without the back-up of clinical science.

      It's easy to manufacture a disagreement between specialists if you only quote the disagreers. Meanwhile, the overwhelming majority of paediatricians, early childhood nurses, GPs, immunologists, infectious diseases specialists and, in fact, parents, continue to agree about the benefits of vaccination and the vast dominance of benefit over risk.

      almost 2 years ago report

      Read more

      Sue,

      I'm pro vaccination but I got to point out that resorting to the same tactic as an anti-vaxxer (appealing to authority or popularity or single cases) is not helping the rest of us.

      Why do those particular researchers lack credibility? Is it because they have consistently done shite research that has been disproven, is fraudulent or makes absolutely no sense? Or is it because they are being quoted by anti-vaxxers?

      The other thing too is although it would be unwise to trust an author with a dodgy track record, every so often even "an idiot" can come up with a meritorious idea. If this is not an example of that, what about the idea is not meritorious. i.e. is it the methods, etc go back to the science, and use that.

      Baz,

      Sue is correct. You can't just quote a couple of authors trouted on an anti-vax site and appeal to their authority. Why is their research valuable? What other research supports and does not support their arguments? Go back to the science.

      Just saying "Scientist said" doesn't mean crap. That's also the flaw of the main article, when comparing an expert with a non expert opinion. It doesn't point out clearly enough that who said it matters less than the merit of what is being said, although, backing up arguments with evidence is clearly the main point and that is not something I've seen anti-vaxxers clearly do as yet. Likewise the difference between an expert and non expert is we'd expect the expert to have evidence to back up the argument. This is not always true, but it is considerably more likely (hence we'd be more inclined to trust an expert but it is fallacious to appeal to their authority).

      Does that apply to the research you've quoted?

  29. Chris Sherley

    Researcher

    I've read many articles on this website and I sincerely love it. However, I have never been as perplexed by an article and its comments as this one.

    Everyone, absolutely everyone, is entitled to their opinion, no matter how crazy it may seem to you or I. I accept that there should be a level of credence given to scientific experts that is not extended to the lesser informed. However, let me remind everyone of the fallibilty of science:

    Thalidomide

    There are an infinite number of examples…

    Read more

    I've read many articles on this website and I sincerely love it. However, I have never been as perplexed by an article and its comments as this one.

    Everyone, absolutely everyone, is entitled to their opinion, no matter how crazy it may seem to you or I. I accept that there should be a level of credence given to scientific experts that is not extended to the lesser informed. However, let me remind everyone of the fallibilty of science:

    Thalidomide

    There are an infinite number of examples that anyone can find for themselves of "certain science" turning sour. For example, I will remind everyone that it was considered the best "scientific" solution to take indigenous children off their parents in Australia during the 20th century.

    There is no such thing as an exact science, and to assume there is, is nothing short of ignorance. In fact, Russel and Whitehead were never even able to mathematically prove that 1 + 1 = 2.

    Now please don't misinterpret what I am saying. I believe in the big bang theory, and until I see good scientific evidence to the contrary I will continue to believe it. I believe in evolution and Darwinian theory. I also believe that for every action there is an equal and opposite reaction. However, we moved past positivism for a reason. There is no such thing as proven science, only the best model we have to work with at the time.

    Everyone's opinions should be heard, and yes, most of the time forgotten. But to suggest that an opinion should be ignored, especially if it is because that person doesn't have a piece of paper to their name. I think Ramanujan is the only response that one can give to that argument. Possibly one of the greatest mathematical minds in history, and almost all of his work was done without a qualification.

    almost 2 years ago report

    1. Debra Joan Smith

      Account Executive

      In reply to Chris Sherley

(as long as that makes you feel good) or with your passionate or insincere self interest continue to spout what has been proven wrong??? What if it klls people? Sometimes it appears that lies look like truth…

      Read more

      Chris, I honestly appreciate your input on this and surmise that there must be thousands of people out there who feel as you do and THAT is precisely why some of us are taking on this battle. How long after your premise is proven Wrong are you allowed to and enouraged to hold that perspective? (as long as that makes you feel good) or with your passionate or insincere self interest continue to spout what has been proven wrong??? What if it klls people? Sometimes it appears that lies look like truth if they are said without challenge in the public space.
      What I and I think others are saying is - bring it on if it is true and relevant. For example a person named Boz brought forward some cutting edge information which I will avidly read through. What it does is add to the base of knowledge- what it does not do and cannot do is support some of the stances taken here. It can add to and pinpoint POTENTIAL sources of problems and people far more capable that i will decide what if anything to address in these articles which are like arrows pointing to places for improvment. NO ONE is more committed to progress and improvement than these scientists and that is evidenced by the existance of someone like BOZ. As for the others, I hope you read the comments on the original article for some of these people are panicked by obviously wrong information, others have agendas and perhaps wish to keep their organizations and thus their pay cheques alive and some others are just poop disturbers of the highest magnitude.
      In my field, the best advice I do give is "Wash your hands- alot".

      almost 2 years ago report

    2. Sue Ieraci

      Public hospital clinician

      In reply to Chris Sherley

      Debra - you present a sound and reasoned point of view, but don't be misled into thinking that the references cited by Boz are "cutting edge" - they demonstrably are not. (see my other comments).

      This site is so prone to people quoting abstracts off the net back and forth - generally only having read the title and perhaps the spin summarised in the conclusion. There is a big difference between doing a Google search and re-posting a few abstracts as opposed to reading - and understanding - the actual study, its methodology, its data and its findings.

      We could improve the level of debate by citation by requiring anyone referring to a published paper to present a critical analysis - of the entire paper.

      almost 2 years ago report

      But gee Ms Sue, don't turn it into a seminar with overheads and maybe powerpoint presentations. Too many years of my life, honestly.     4. Sue Ieraci

      Public hospital clinician

      In reply to Chris Sherley

      Oh but I did mean it, Mr Peter - but perhaps not as you had envisioned.

      No powerpoint or even over-heads required (do the GenY's even know what overheads are?) - just succinct statements showing that one has read and understood the full paper that one cites.

      Let me illustrate:

      Baz Bardoe posts this:
      "The senior post doctoral researchers in vaccine safety at the Univeristy of British Columbia, Dr Lucija Tomijanovic and Professor Chris Shaw, contend that aluminium adjuvents are most probably…

      Read more

      Oh but I did mean it, Mr Peter - but perhaps not as you had envisioned.

      No powerpoint or even over-heads required (do the GenY's even know what overheads are?) - just succinct statements showing that one has read and understood the full paper that one cites.

      Let me illustrate:

      Baz Bardoe posts this:
      "The senior post doctoral researchers in vaccine safety at the Univeristy of British Columbia, Dr Lucija Tomijanovic and Professor Chris Shaw, contend that aluminium adjuvents are most probably linked to autism.. Their article here: http://omsj.org/reports/tomljenovic%202011.pdf";

      Sue Ieraci goes to the article, and finds that:
      1. Those researchers (whose papers she has previously seen used in anti-vax arguments) are not "researchers in vaccine safety" at all.
      2. Their paper is not a research report but a theoretical discourse, which calls for more research.
      3. WHere Baz Bardoe says "contend that aluminium adjuvents are most probably linked to autism..", the actual paper says nothing of the sort.

      A reasonable (brief) critical analysis of this paper would then be:
      "These authors are researchers within the Neural Dynamics Research Group, Department of Ophthalmology and Visual Sciences, at the University of British Columbia. They have several publications in low-impact journals in the area of vaccination, although this is not their specialty area. The specific paper cited is in a journal of inorganic chemistry. The paper is a theoretical discourse - not a research report. What they do is correlate a rising incidence of ASD diagnoses with an expanding vaccination schedule. This has occurred during a time that ASD has been more precisely defined and more commonly diagnosed. They have only shown correlation of two things - not causation."

      See? No need for powerpoints, graphs or long dissertations. Just a bit of effort and some intellectual honesty

      almost 2 years ago report

  30. Steven Liaros

    Town planner at PolisPlan - town planning and eco-village consultants

    Patrick,
    I appreciate that you are trying to elevate the debate but your argument, like Plato's is fundamentally flawed.
    Plato's purpose for distinguishing between opinion (doxa) and 'knowledge that is certain', was so that he could argue that 'Reason', by which we arrive at certainty, is superior to 'Opinion', which is always uncertain. Plato also argued that everything that is uncertain is striving towards certainty.

    The problem with his argument is that we come to regard Reason as somehow…

    Read more

    Patrick,
    I appreciate that you are trying to elevate the debate but your argument, like Plato's is fundamentally flawed.
    Plato's purpose for distinguishing between opinion (doxa) and 'knowledge that is certain', was so that he could argue that 'Reason', by which we arrive at certainty, is superior to 'Opinion', which is always uncertain. Plato also argued that everything that is uncertain is striving towards certainty.

    The problem with his argument is that we come to regard Reason as somehow superior to Opinion. Opinion is often arrived at through intuition and cannot be argued in a logical or mathematical way.

    ... read John Ralston Saul's "Voltair's bastards- The Dictatorship of Reason in the West"... or listen to any political debate to hear how a lie can be couched in a reasonable argument to somehow become the truth;

    So because we can't use logical reasoned arguments to explain certain things, these things always lose the debate.
    Alternatively, we then apply 'logical arguments' or the scientific method to matters of opinion, testing all the different opinions to find the 'correct opinion' or the 'ortho - doxa' ... the 'orthodox truth'. As a result 'opinions' that are accepted by consensus (or enforced through oppressive means) somehow become truths... so they can win the debate.

    ...and the problem with this is that the 'facts' of the establishment become the truth even if they are not.

    Just because someone has certain qualifications or is more expert than others does not make them, by definition, the holders of the ALL the facts.

    ...truth is not a debate or a contest... the holder of more facts or of a more well reasoned argument is not, as if by majority vote, the holder of the truth.

    almost 2 years ago report

    1. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

      In reply to Steven Liaros

      Hi Stephen,

      Thanks for a thoughtful reply – and I always appreciate a John Ralston Saul reference (I enjoyed his earlier books, particularly The Doubter’s Companion, but kind of lost the thread after On Equilibrium).

      I think it’s very important not to reify, let alone deify, reason. That’s precisely what Plato does, and that’s one of many reasons I don’t agree with his epistemology. I also agree that intuitions are an irreducible part of our moral, practical and theoretical experience (check…

      Read more

      Hi Stephen,

      Thanks for a thoughtful reply – and I always appreciate a John Ralston Saul reference (I enjoyed his earlier books, particularly The Doubter’s Companion, but kind of lost the thread after On Equilibrium).

      I think it’s very important not to reify, let alone deify, reason. That’s precisely what Plato does, and that’s one of many reasons I don’t agree with his epistemology. I also agree that intuitions are an irreducible part of our moral, practical and theoretical experience (check out the paper of mine I link to in the article for more on this as it applies to moral intuitions).

      That said, acknowledging the limitations of reason – and even giving up on the idea of absolute and final certainty – isn’t the same thing as giving up on the idea that different opinions have different truth-values. The fact that we’re epistemically and cognitively limited don’t entail that anything goes.

      You point out, rightly, that a lie can easily be couched in a reasonable-sounding argument, and that consensus and absolute objective truth aren’t the same thing. But that doesn’t mean we must completely give up on standards of rational argument and simply accept a total relativism of competing truth claims. Rather it means we have to accept – which Plato, to his cost, did not – that we do not have, and might never have, access to 100% certainty about anything. Yet that doesn’t vacate the entire concept of truth. Rather it means that truth might be something we always tend towards while being aware of our own ever-present fallibility – and that in turn should warrant a certain intellectual humility with respect to complex questions that have been studied in greater depth by others. It’s that humility that I think is sorely wanting at present, with respect to properly scientific questions at least.

      Best wishes,
      Patrick

      almost 2 years ago report

    2. account deleted

      logged in via email @gmail.com

      In reply to Steven Liaros

      Hi Patrick, this is a fair way from the subject of vaccinations as useful tool, but I find this concept of humility in the face of greater perceived authority a little troubling. Whilst I agree that those who have arrived at their views through proper application of the scientific method have a more strongly-based claim than someone who relies on intuition or a faulty application of reasoning alone, oftentimes it is a willingness to challenge accepted postulates that lead to the most interesting…

      Read more

      Hi Patrick, this is a fair way from the subject of vaccinations as useful tool, but I find this concept of humility in the face of greater perceived authority a little troubling. Whilst I agree that those who have arrived at their views through proper application of the scientific method have a more strongly-based claim than someone who relies on intuition or a faulty application of reasoning alone, oftentimes it is a willingness to challenge accepted postulates that lead to the most interesting results. There are any number of examples of well-regarded models being shown to be incomplete or even completely wrong upon application of reason to a different set of postulates to explain the same data set.

      That doesn't imply that it is always valid to do so, since it clearly can lead to nonsensical results, however it is certainly true that accepted wisdom is not necessarily going to lead to an improved understanding. It is important to distinguish between models and empirically-derived results. A model is only useful insofar as it explains the observations, it is not independent of what can be measured. It has no life of its own.

      I know I'm making a lot of what may have been a poorly chosen word, but I don't see any place for such humility in scientific endeavour. Everything is able to be challenged and must be. The core concept is falsifiability, and it is only through such an approach that useful questions can be asked. Certainly those who have a long history of making observations in a field have some claim to superior understanding of the data set, but having a data set is not the same thing as having an understanding of the mechanisms, or even of having a usefully formulated set of questions, even if the hypotheses that underlie those questions have not been yet falsified. Think of the ructions in mechanics in the early part of last century, where the accepted wisdom of 300 years was challenged and found to have limits, all through the application of reason to a changed set of postulates. The field continues to investigate the implications of quantum mechanics today and there is no guarantee that a similar upheaval will not take place tomorrow.

      A "truth" is an observed piece of data, that is all. What is done with that data is what enables understanding, but as you say, it may never be complete except in limited ways. Having the arrogance to challenge accepted models is critical to advance that understanding.

      Rather than humility, what is required is good faith in and acceptance of purity of motive. It is that good faith that is lacking in the discussion around vaccination, it seems to me. On both sides.

      almost 2 years ago report

    3. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

      In reply to Steven Liaros

      Hi Craig,

      Thanks for this very helpful comment.

      I’d like to suggest that the attitude you’re describing here is actually not opposed to what I mean by intellectual humility. A “willingness to challenge accepted postulates,” and a preparedness to abandon models that aren’t supported by empirical data, would indeed seem to be essential for any kind of research. However, what you (I think quite rightly) call ‘good faith’ in that context will also involve being open to the possibility that one…

      Read more

      Hi Craig,

      Thanks for this very helpful comment.

      I’d like to suggest that the attitude you’re describing here is actually not opposed to what I mean by intellectual humility. A “willingness to challenge accepted postulates,” and a preparedness to abandon models that aren’t supported by empirical data, would indeed seem to be essential for any kind of research. However, what you (I think quite rightly) call ‘good faith’ in that context will also involve being open to the possibility that one might also be wrong. Falsifiability doesn’t play favourites. So there arguably is a role for intellectual humility even within a disciplinary practice like science, without it amounting to deference to authority.

      However the same virtue in different contexts can look very different and issue in different actions. What counts as bravery on a battlefield might not be the same thing as bravery in facing an illness, for example. Likewise, the virtue of intellectual humility within a discipline might look very different to humility on the part of someone outside that discipline with respect *to* that discipline. In that latter context, intellectual humility very likely will involve deference.

      In other words, there is a pretty significant difference between scientists challenging other scientists on scientific questions, and non-scientists challenging scientists. Humility will operate very differently in each case. I still think it’s the same virtue operative in each case – though I am, I hope, open to the possibility that I might turn out to be wrong about that!

      Best,
      Patrick

      almost 2 years ago report

    4. account deleted

      logged in via email @gmail.com

      In reply to Steven Liaros

      Patrick, I'm struggling to properly express this, so please excuse me for perhaps seeming obtuse.

      The issue of falsifiability relates to the questions being asked, not to the model that might result from the reasoning process. Confirmation bias is a problem that persists and can impact the most eminent scientific output. Few genuinely independent scientists exist, after all.

      New paradigms arise through rationalism informed by empiricism, or sometimes through cognitive leaps that have little…

      Read more

      Patrick, I'm struggling to properly express this, so please excuse me for perhaps seeming obtuse.

      The issue of falsifiability relates to the questions being asked, not to the model that might result from the reasoning process. Confirmation bias is a problem that persists and can impact the most eminent scientific output. Few genuinely independent scientists exist, after all.

      New paradigms arise through rationalism informed by empiricism, or sometimes through cognitive leaps that have little obvious basis in empiricism. Whilst I take your point that great learning deserves respect, it seems to me that the greatest thinkers are the ones who have most spectacularly failed to respect learned opinion, while some of the most spectacular failures have been eminent people who have doggedly clung to ideas that have been later shown to be flawed or limited.

      This is not to say that divergence from the dominant consensus is axiomatically a good thing - I agree that not all views are equally worthy and some are obviously garbage, but I do think that it is axiomatic that good science is open to new ideas wherever and however they arise. As long as a proposition can be falsified it can yield useful results and new ideas. Negative data is still useful and a gifted or lucky amateur can inform significant investigation.

      It seems to me that the deference you describe is essentially a defence of special pleading, in that it relies on a class difference in the source of the opinions rather than on objective evaluation. It may even stultify rather than fertilise fruitful developments.

      Thanks for taking the time to discuss this stuff. On a broader level than scientific endeavour our new world of rapid communication and easy dissemination of ideas creates a need for people to swiftly evaluate what they read and far too often that evaluation is informed by some form of confirmation bias. That in turn can lead to a deterioration in the good faith we discussed above and that leads nowhere good, as the catcalling on this thread demonstrates.

      It's a vexed and entrenched issue that deserves proper consideration. With due humility of course :-).

      almost 2 years ago report

    5. Steven Liaros

      Town planner at PolisPlan - town planning and eco-village consultants

      In reply to Steven Liaros

      Patrick, thank you very much for engaging in this conversation... I also lost the thread after JRSaul's early works.
      I, like Craig, am troubled by the issue of humility before superior knowledge or expertise.

      I think we are experiencing a fundamental shift, both in the ways our minds work and consequently in the way in which we, collectively, perceive the world... as our perception changes, our understanding of the truth also changes.

      Most of our education systems have to date been based…

      Read more

      Patrick, thank you very much for engaging in this conversation... I also lost the thread after JRSaul's early works.
      I, like Craig, am troubled by the issue of humility before superior knowledge or expertise.

      I think we are experiencing a fundamental shift, both in the ways our minds work and consequently in the way in which we, collectively, perceive the world... as our perception changes, our understanding of the truth also changes.

      Most of our education systems have to date been based on a very linear model... a growth model, where new knowledge is built on the shoulders of existing knowledge. This is consistent with the use of logic and reason.

      This has been extremely useful in building up the body of human knowledge but has meant that in order to continue to build we have to become more and more specialised. Existing knowledge in most disciplines is now so complex that it requires years of reading and learning and research just to get to the frontier of knowledge before you can think of adding to it. When following along this path it is appropriate that we acknowledge with humility those who have trodden this path before us.

      I suggested that we are experiencing a fundamental shift because I believe that the internet is changing everything. Access to base level knowledge is significantly greater. This allows for a substantially greater ability to challenge expressed 'truths'. As a result, the holders of knowledge are no longer able to bluff their way through... this is particularly evident in government... most governments around the world are being challenged to an unprecedented degree... and 'fundamental truths' like 'economic growth is good' and so should be the principal purpose of government is no longer accepted.

      The democratisation of knowledge, the free access to knowledge, is the best way to arrive at the truth. Provide all the existing knowledge freely to all and allow it to be challenged from any and all angles by all interested parties. This is the foundation of a truly democratic society.

      Most of our society consists of churches of knowledge, whether its religion, or science, economics, law, medicine or immunology. The high priests of these churches demand humility, demand that the rest of us bow down to their superior knowledge.

      In the same way that the printing press democratised access to knowledge and resulted in both the Protestant revolution and the Enlightenment, so will the internet and social networking again democratise knowledge, taking it out of the hands of self appointed 'experts'. It will do this, not using the linear model but by hyperlinking across disciplines to create a connected flow of ideas... and we will know the truth when it resonates across large sections, or all, of the population... not when we are simply told that it is the truth.

      The ability to hyper-link across disciplines is an expression of the lateral thinking that is absent from our current systems and I can't wait to see the explosion of ideas to come.

      almost 2 years ago report

    6. Greg Beattie

      logged in via Facebook

      In reply to Steven Liaros

      Craig and Steven

      Beautifully expressed!

      almost 2 years ago report

  31. Bridget Apricot Hunt

    logged in via Facebook

    "I have spoken with literally hundreds of doctors who are totally clueless on this subject - and that includes immunologists, paediatricians, rheumatologists and other specialists.

    As opposed to the opinion of many people here and in the greater community, a degree in medicine does not give one any 'magical' powers to determine the truth or otherwise of scientific issues. Doctors are not trained in research and in fact, that majority of their information about drugs and vaccines comes directly…

    Read more

    "I have spoken with literally hundreds of doctors who are totally clueless on this subject - and that includes immunologists, paediatricians, rheumatologists and other specialists.

    As opposed to the opinion of many people here and in the greater community, a degree in medicine does not give one any 'magical' powers to determine the truth or otherwise of scientific issues. Doctors are not trained in research and in fact, that majority of their information about drugs and vaccines comes directly from the manufacturers of those same products."

    Well, that's wrong. As a medical student, I can confidently say that we ARE trained in research because, funnily enough, we need to know how it works and will be expected to keep up with the latest research throughout our career. We've never once had a rep from a pharmaceutical company come to uni and teach us about immunology. Strange as it is, immunologists teach us about immunology. And we do study immunology. In fact, I'm studying it this semester. Attempting to claim that said immunologists are "totally clueless on this subject" is, to put it kindly, insane. Seeing as it is the basis of their entire career, they do need to know a little about it.

    almost 2 years ago report

  32. Emma Anderson

    Artist and Science Junkie

    On the specific issues of vaccination and gay marriage, most of the evidence supports having both as accepted features of contemporary life, with some caveats (see below).

    However, most the arguments, from all the angles I've seen thus far, including on this web-page, appeal to authority, popularity, are ad nauseum, ad hominem and generally lacking in the evidence. It's tiresome, achieves nothing and neither perspective is winning the fight because of it. Being berated by anyone on these issues…

    Read more

    On the specific issues of vaccination and gay marriage, most of the evidence supports having both as accepted features of contemporary life, with some caveats (see below).

    However, most the arguments, from all the angles I've seen thus far, including on this web-page, appeal to authority, popularity, are ad nauseum, ad hominem and generally lacking in the evidence. It's tiresome, achieves nothing and neither perspective is winning the fight because of it. Being berated by anyone on these issues is not working.

    The evidence, to be clear, from what I've seen so far suggests:

    > Vaccination is an effective force for the social good, if the social good is defined as preventing small children from dying of preventable diseases.

    With one caveat, individual differences in biology/social variables tend to create the occasional situation where what is good for most people is not always good for that individual. But because doctors are supposed to account for this by taking family medical history, looking for signs of these factors and so on, this issue can be dealt with. Thus, to deny all children vaccination on the grounds that a handful of cases have not been dealt with effectively in this matter, is throwing the baby out with the bathwater, and increasing the rate of preventable diseases. It is unscientific and unethical. On the other hand, was the anti-vaxx argument just about increasing the rate of doctors performing individual evaluations in more detail, that would be an ethical argument and would apply to issues other than vaccination. Unfortunately, to date, that has not been the case.

    > Gay marriage is a force for social good, if the social good includes equal rights and recognition for legal relationships that match contemporary values of non-discrimination.

    With one caveat, a relationship probably should not have to be legally binding for it to be afforded the social acceptance and rights of the individuals involved to freely associate with each other without interference from the broader community. As homosexual and trans relationships, like heterosexual ones, involve freely associating adults, it ideally shouldn't matter if they are married or not for the relationship to be valued as equally meaningful to the individuals involved. In short, if we need marriage to convince others that gay people really are in love and no different from straight people in the nature of their affections, then our society still has a long way to go before we can say that the book is closed on ending discrimination against homosexual, bisexual and trans people.

    over 1 year ago report

  34. Chris Buchli

    Music Tutor

    I'm in agreement with this article. It's fair to say that an assertion should be defensible. If what you assert cannot be defended it is irrational, by definition.

    I don't think there is a suggestion that only people with relevant degrees are entitled to opinions, that would be a fallacious argument from authority. It's the argument that is relevant, not the arguer. I don't care who is making the point, if it stands up to scrutiny then it does; if it doesn't, it doesn't.

    I have a student who recently said "you're the teacher, so you're probably right", I replied that I'm not right because I'm the teacher; I'm right AND I'm the teacher. My rightness had nothing to do with the fact that I am his teacher and everything to do with my assertions being backed by evidence.

    over 1 year ago report

    1. Steven Liaros

      Town planner at PolisPlan - town planning and eco-village consultants

      In reply to Chris Buchli

      Chris Buchli
      Music Tutor

      It's also fair to say that music is not rational ... I would not assert that music is therefore irrational as you use that word (i.e. irrational = 'wrong'). As a music teacher I would hope you are showing students that the opposite of rational is intuitive and creative.

      Evidence only works in the rational sphere of our world view and new ideas and breakthroughs in knowledge actually challenge the existing rational world view... creativity is all about choosing not to pursue that rational path followed by others.

      over 1 year ago report

  35. Chris Buchli

    Music Tutor

    Steven Liaros - There are actually many things about music that are perfectly rational. Certain intervals have perfect ratios between them, for example, two strings an octave apart are always in a ratio of 1:2. So, the theory behind music is rational.

    What you do with that rational process is not a question of rationality, but preference and value. This is irrelevant to the topic.

    You equate 'irrational' with 'wrong' but this is a problem. You could assert something that is right but for which you have no evidence. Until you have evidence, believing this assertion to be true is irrational, even though it is correct. God is a great example of this: there's no evidence for His existence, even though He might. To believe it is irrational which is why people need 'faith'.

    over 1 year ago report

    1. Steven Liaros

      Town planner at PolisPlan - town planning and eco-village consultants

      In reply to Chris Buchli

      Chris,
      I agree that there is much that is rational about the theory and craft of music... and a teacher of music, as with all disciplines, can only teach the theory and craft. The creative/ artistic element of music is not rational, is far more than 'preference and value' and is the only part of music that we (non-musicians) value.

      As a teacher of any discipline (but especially music) you can only offer the building blocks, you can only teach the rules that a creative person will break in order…

      Read more

      Chris,
      I agree that there is much that is rational about the theory and craft of music... and a teacher of music, as with all disciplines, can only teach the theory and craft. The creative/ artistic element of music is not rational, is far more than 'preference and value' and is the only part of music that we (non-musicians) value.

      As a teacher of any discipline (but especially music) you can only offer the building blocks, you can only teach the rules that a creative person will break in order to make beautiful music or art.

      This is all very relevant to the topic because those who suggest that more rational knowledge makes you superior are ignoring the evidence of countless great musicians in history who had no or limited knowledge of rational music theory.

      Finally, your assertion that God 'might' exist (after claiming that his existence is 'correct') proves my point. Either he exists or he does not. If you can prove with a rational argument that he exists then he is not God because he is no longer beyond our understanding.

      If he exists and you can't prove it rationally then that proves that rational processes can only take you part of the way. It also proves that those who insist that he exists are enforcing their opinion as if it was 'truth'.

      Everyone is entitled to their opinion because everyone is different, has experienced a different life journey and so their music and art will be different ...Rather than insisting that everyone must align themselves with the established enforced truth... we should allow everyone to express themselves honestly and authentically... to express their opinion and to show their creativity, their music and their art.

      over 1 year ago report

    3. Chris Buchli

      Music Tutor

      In reply to Chris Buchli

      Steve,

      You're playing with a few words dishonestly, or you just don't know what they mean. I'm willing to grant the latter.

      First, You can't "agree" that much about the theory AND craft of music is rational because I only asserted that the theory of music is rational, not the craft, so this is not agreeing with me. I do agree that the creative/artistic element of music is not rational, but only in the sense that it is not a question of rationality. You say that it's not a matter of preference…

      Read more

      Steve,

      You're playing with a few words dishonestly, or you just don't know what they mean. I'm willing to grant the latter.

      First, You can't "agree" that much about the theory AND craft of music is rational because I only asserted that the theory of music is rational, not the craft, so this is not agreeing with me. I do agree that the creative/artistic element of music is not rational, but only in the sense that it is not a question of rationality. You say that it's not a matter of preference and value and then proceed to point out that non-musicians 'value' music's creativity. This is part of the creative process though: What do I value and have preference for (this could relate to sounds, techniques, physical and technical capabilities etc.) and what do my (intended) audience value and have preference for?

      As I said in my first post, I'm not going to suggest that this is a stupid argument to have because I have heck loads of musical knowledge to back me up and so therefore I'm right. But all you have to go on is the value you place in music and your preferences, which only serves to prove my point! What is it beyond preference and value that you think is involved?

      2. Telling me what I can and can't teach is pretty dangerous territory. I actually do teach these things and I teach them well. Why can I only teach the rules which they will then break? I teach them the rational theory and I teach them what they can do to move beyond that and get creative, which is, by the way, completely a matter of preference and value. It's also my job to teach this. Beauty and art I'd like to point out, are matters of preference and value (personal or cultural), so again, you're proving my point.

      I think we need a working definition of creativity to further this part of the conversation, I'm happy to receive amendments. Here's mine: creativity is taking existing ideas and applying them in new ways.

      3. I don't think anybody is suggesting that having rational knowledge makes you superior. I'm not anyway. More rational, sure, but that's not superior, unless you measure superiority (which I have no interest in whatsoever) by that marker alone... You're misunderstanding something about music theory. Music theory, like scientific theories, is a model for how musical concepts interrelate. It is not a set of 'rules', it is a guide to help us understand and organise the things which we have discovered about music. Much as the laws of physics aren't rules about how physics is required to work, so much as a list of observations about how it does, in fact, work.

      Anyway, great musicians without knowledge of music theory had only their preference and value for certain sounds, techniques and other musical ideas to go on.

      4. I did not assert that God might exist after claiming that his existence is correct. I said that an assertion can be correct but irrational because you have no evidence for it. I then used God as an example for an irrational belief because of a lack of evidence.

      Whether or not God is provable is based on how you define God. You have provided the definition that God is beyond understanding. I'd be interested in discussing this, and I'd ask what the point of something beyond our understanding is (and point out that that's a paradox because you understand that God is beyond understanding - how do you understand this?), but it's irrelevant to my main discussion, so I'll leave it to the side for now... Yes, I know I'm being cheeky getting my point in there.

      Something being correct but not provable rationally only shows that it is not yet rationally understood, not that it is beyond understanding. If I don't know what a chair is made of, it's irrational to assert that it's made of wood, even if it is made of wood. I can later prove that it is made of wood, and only at that point is it rational to assert so. I do not assume that because I don't know something that it cannot be known (that would seem rather arrogant, or at least presumptuous).

      I'm in total agreement that anyone insisting God exists is enforcing their opinion as if it was truth. There is absolutely no evidence for His existence. I think you may have thought that I was asserting this, but I think I've cleared that up.

      5. You're missing the point about music and art. They are not questions of rationality, there is no 'established enforced truth' about music or art. You can't factually say "this is good art" or "this is bad art", even less "this is true art" or "this is false art". You could say these things based on your preferences and values; It's not a question of rationality. I agree everyone should be able to express themselves artistically however they like (that is according to their preferences and values!) because art has nothing to do with facts.

      On matters of fact, however, you should not make assertions that contradict facts without proof and evidence to back up those assertions. Is that so hard to understand?

      over 1 year ago report

    4. Chris Buchli

      Music Tutor

      In reply to Chris Buchli

      Emma Anderson - I agree that the most fun in art does come from improvisation and trying new things. It's not 'irrational' it just has nothing to do with rationality. Just as deciding to eat an orange instead of an apple has little to do with rationality.

      Those inclined, like myself, could delve into the issue of free will here, but I think I'll leave that for another day.

    5. alfred venison

      records manager (public sector)

      In reply to Chris Buchli

      music you're talking about (i'm presuming) is grounded on a well tempered scale with 12 equal intervals between octaves. it is undeniably not a natural scale; it is a product of rationality. so too there's nothing irrational about instrument making, physics & acoustics constrain in favour of reason & the scale chosen.

      unless you're emulating anthony braxton or elliott carter you're beholden to a harmonic system which exerts influence on you whether you strain against it or align with it…

      Read more

      music you're talking about (i'm presuming) is grounded on a well tempered scale with 12 equal intervals between octaves. it is undeniably not a natural scale; it is a product of rationality. so too there's nothing irrational about instrument making, physics & acoustics constrain in favour of reason & the scale chosen.

      unless you're emulating anthony braxton or elliott carter you're beholden to a harmonic system which exerts influence on you whether you strain against it or align with it. it is a rational system evolved in conjunction with the well-tempered scale - even if the answer to "why (for what reason) did you score or play this chord at that time", is "because i wanted the effect that would ensue" it is rational.

      western music is teleological - it is a narrative, normatively, not a process; arguably, the final V-I cadence is implied in the opening progressions & is the destination that every musical event works towards or postpones.

      musical inspiration is not necessarily irrational - musical execution is almost always rational & grounded on good technique. ecstatic exuberance in musical execution is never wholly irrational. -a.v.

      over 1 year ago report

    6. Chris Buchli

      Music Tutor

      In reply to Chris Buchli

      Alfred,

      I can kind of run with that on the basis you give. The creation of a sound and its ensuing effect are perfectly rational. The part I think that is based on value and preference is what led to the choice to want to create a particular sound in the first place. This could be argued to have a rational basis, but I'm not sure if research substantiates this. Anxiety sufferers, for example, often become musicians; It may help to centre and channel emotions better. So an anxiety sufferer's choice…

      Read more

      Alfred,

      I can kind of run with that on the basis you give. The creation of a sound and its ensuing effect are perfectly rational. The part I think that is based on value and preference is what led to the choice to want to create a particular sound in the first place. This could be argued to have a rational basis, but I'm not sure if research substantiates this. Anxiety sufferers, for example, often become musicians; It may help to centre and channel emotions better. So an anxiety sufferer's choice to want to hear a certain sound may very well be backed by rational decisions; it would be just as rational as taking medicine for an ailment.

      I'm reluctant to call any musical choice rational because it implies that there are particular solutions to musical 'problems', or situations. In my experience, there are often multiple ways to get where you want to go in music, especially with regard to improvisation; it's not necessarily a linear activity. So, the choice between these equally valid solutions comes down to preference.

      over 1 year ago report

    7. Steven Liaros

      Town planner at PolisPlan - town planning and eco-village consultants

      In reply to Chris Buchli

      Chris,
      I apologise if you feel that by challenging you and debating with you that I was dishonest and arrogant... perhaps amongst other things. Clearly you feel that I do not have the right to challenge you on the subject of music so I will not pursue those arguments.

      I would like to challenge your last paragraph, "On matters of fact, however, you should not make assertions that contradict facts without proof and evidence to back up those assertions. Is that so hard to understand?"
      This gets…

      Read more

      Chris,
      I apologise if you feel that by challenging you and debating with you that I was dishonest and arrogant... perhaps amongst other things. Clearly you feel that I do not have the right to challenge you on the subject of music so I will not pursue those arguments.

      I would like to challenge your last paragraph, "On matters of fact, however, you should not make assertions that contradict facts without proof and evidence to back up those assertions. Is that so hard to understand?"
      This gets back to the subject of the original article "No, you are not entitled to your opinion".

      My issue is not whether my opinion has merit but whether I'm entitled to express an opinion.

      You appear to agree (correct me if I'm putting words in your mouth) that in any human endeavour there is a rational component and a non-rational component. The non-rational component is the domain of intuition, of creativity and of objectivity as well as preference and personal value.

      So when you refer to "matters of fact" and even if you then claim to know ALL the facts and to possess ALL the possible rational knowledge in your field of expertise you can't know everything about it because you can't 'know' the non-rational component ... most importantly you can't understand your discipline from an objective viewpoint.

      If you are schooled in music theory or economic theory or medical theory or religious theory etc. and you build up a body of rational knowledge in your area of expertise and you have invested a huge amount of time in understanding the rational framework and you then teach from the standpoint and your income is derived from your expertise and so your livelihood depends on that income and you also define yourself as an music teacher or an economist or a doctor or a bishop... do you think you will ever accept someone from outside your field to challenge your opinion?

      You, like Patrick, the author of the article and a large proportion of the population appear to believe that every discipline is entirely independent of every other discipline and the body of human knowledge is a number of independent strands and no-one outside your strand could possibly understand your discipline. You choose to believe this because it serves your self-interest, it makes you an expert and a teacher. That status gives you personal value and that status guarantees you income and so it sustains your very life.

      You therefore insist that without rational proof and evidence no-one is entitled to an opinion. You believe it is unreasonable to allow anyone to challenge your expertise as you have invested so much in building it up. It is unreasonable to entitle anyone to offer an opinion.
      ...but then reasonableness is the domain of rationality and it seems you are afraid to step outside of it.

      over 1 year ago report

    8. Chris Buchli

      Music Tutor

      In reply to Chris Buchli

      Steve,

      Here's what it comes down to. You certainly have the 'right' (although I don't believe in rights, but that's another matter) to express your opinion on matters that are not questions of fact, such as the non-rational component of any human endeavour.

      You're welcome to challenge me on anything relating to anything, I was merely suggesting that you're fighting as much of a losing battle doing so as I would be challenging a surgeon on matters of surgical procedure. This isn't to protect…

      Read more

      Steve,

      Here's what it comes down to. You certainly have the 'right' (although I don't believe in rights, but that's another matter) to express your opinion on matters that are not questions of fact, such as the non-rational component of any human endeavour.

      You're welcome to challenge me on anything relating to anything, I was merely suggesting that you're fighting as much of a losing battle doing so as I would be challenging a surgeon on matters of surgical procedure. This isn't to protect my apparently lucrative teaching business, and from whom would I be protecting myself by not having this conversation with you? What a confusing statement.

      Anyway, here's what I think people who feel the need to express an opinion on a factual matter should do first: Do some research, find out what the facts are and go from there so that your opinions are not misguided. You are entitled to your own opinions but you are not entitled to your own facts. Furthermore, you are entitled to express those opinions, but it's a stupid idea to do so because you will be treated like an idiot for making baseless claims. I'm not saying that this is right or wrong, but this is what is going to happen. It's not worth your trouble to do so and it's not worth my trouble to hear people's false facts because they do not help.

      A better thing to do is ask questions. Rather than making a statement of 'fact' regarding something about which you have no idea, why not ask a question of someone who does know and try to find what the correct answer is? If there is currently no correct answer (maybe more research or better technology is required), the honest thing to do is to say "I don't know", the dishonest answer is to make something up (that's the 'opinion' that this article is referring to).

      In this case, rather than make assertions about musical facts which you admit you have no training in, it would be better to ask: "Is music a rational or irrational endeavour?", or "which components of music are rational and which are not?". How you ask that exactly is preferential and you would be welcome to express your opinions about how to ask that question and to do so in your own way. To express your own facts about music is asinine.

      Lastly, I have no interest in upholding any kind of status quo. If somebody can point out, with evidence, that something I believe is wrong, guess what I'll do? I'll stop believing it. If they can make a positive claim for the existence of something that is factual, I'll believe that. What I won't believe is someone's opinion for which they have no evidence.

      over 1 year ago report

    9. Steven Liaros

      Town planner at PolisPlan - town planning and eco-village consultants

      In reply to Chris Buchli

      Chris,
      Here is what it comes down to in my opinion.
      There is no such thing as the very Western idea of right or wrong. Like yin and yang in Chinese philosophy, black and white are simply two sides of the same thing (like day and night, light and dark... light is not 'good' and darkness 'evil'... they are just two parts of the whole.

      In the absence of right and wrong there is no rational truth as we interpret the idea of truth... ie. there is no collection of facts that will take you anywhere…

      Read more

      Chris,
      Here is what it comes down to in my opinion.
      There is no such thing as the very Western idea of right or wrong. Like yin and yang in Chinese philosophy, black and white are simply two sides of the same thing (like day and night, light and dark... light is not 'good' and darkness 'evil'... they are just two parts of the whole.

      In the absence of right and wrong there is no rational truth as we interpret the idea of truth... ie. there is no collection of facts that will take you anywhere meaningful.
      Your collection of 'facts' is only your perception of the world.
      Current ideas of right and wrong are only common perceptions or more often ideas that are followed by people who have not thoughtfully inquired but find it easier to follow other people's established perceptions.

      The only meaningful truth is that some things resonate with people and with the natural environment while many more things do not resonate. Like yin and yang again, resonance is an efficient harmony of equal opposites... a 'storage and release' of energy, store and release in equal measure (I am sure you will have a different definition). You will find that most scientific or natural 'truths' boil down to resonance... and that's why music is so important, why it touches us on a fundamental level.

      The only 'truth' is something that resonates not something that is supported by a collection of facts, many of which are founded on perception or self-interest... and so, for example and getting back to the original article, if vaccinations are 'good' shouldn't medical experts insist that they should be freely distributed to all people everywhere? ... or is their 'goodness' derived in part from the profit that compulsory vaccinations will deliver to drug companies? We will only know the answer when the 'truth' does not benefit the 'truth-sayer'.

      As for rights, no-one has the right either to grant or deny someone else's right to live. The right to live is fundamentally linked to the right to express yourself honestly and authentically... to express an opinion.

      over 1 year ago report

      To answer one thing directly: yes vaccinations…

      Read more

      Steve,

      You'd be surprised to know that I agree with a lot of what you've said there. I think some of what you said in the middle there is waffle and I think you have little or no idea how the scientific method works, but I agree with you overall. I agree there's no right and wrong or good and evil (except insofar as people have labelled those things), but I think you are expecting 'fact' to equate to 'absolute truth' and this is a problem for you.

      To answer one thing directly: yes vaccinations, which would be considered 'good' insofar as we can use that word should be distributed to everybody. Unfortunately, we live in a world where economic good is the highest good in the highest echelons of society. This is no longer necessary in a globalised world with the technological capabilities we have, but there's another discussion for another day.

      I've read your yin and yang spiel a few times now and I just struggle to see how that means anything at all (not without more definitions - what is energy, for example?), or what your basis for thinking this is. I struggle to see how this is at all demonstrable, could you give some examples? If it is not demonstrable you should explain why you believe it and why I should too.

      Facts take me to many, many meaningful places. Facts also help me to get out of places, whether they be physical places or mental states, that have no meaning too. Sometimes no matter how much you want something to be true, it just isn't.

      Of course I could take away someone's right to live. All I'd have to do is kill them (dead = no rights). Of course, I don't want to live in a world where people go around killing people, so I will refrain from this. That's why I don't believe in rights; no right is unalienable (in a practical sense, that is, paper proclamations do nothing), perhaps with the exception of one's right to think as they wish, but only because nobody can control thoughts. Hopefully that day never comes.

      I've no idea how you got to 'right to express an opinion' from 'right to live'; if there's meant to be some logical connection there, you haven't made it.

      over 1 year ago report

    11. Steven Liaros

      Town planner at PolisPlan - town planning and eco-village consultants

      In reply to Chris Buchli

      Chris,
      It has been interesting and challenging debating with you.
      As for my 'yin yang spiel' ... there is no short and sweet way of explaining it but if interested google "The Ecstasy of Yang" which is a paper I presented last year at a conference.

      I take your point about dead=no rights. Perhaps our idea of 'rights' is more about our hopes for the type of society we want to live in... so we label them as rights hoping that that will assist in achieving universal agreement... a rare and elusive…

      Read more

      Chris,
      It has been interesting and challenging debating with you.
      As for my 'yin yang spiel' ... there is no short and sweet way of explaining it but if interested google "The Ecstasy of Yang" which is a paper I presented last year at a conference.

      I take your point about dead=no rights. Perhaps our idea of 'rights' is more about our hopes for the type of society we want to live in... so we label them as rights hoping that that will assist in achieving universal agreement... a rare and elusive commodity.

      In my opinion, living is not simply 'not dead'. Living, as suggested by the ancient Greek saying is to "Know Thyself". The Greeks referred to the state of knowing yourself as "eu-daemonia" (ie. healthy spirit, later translated to beatitude, the state of blessedness, the pursuit of happiness). To know thyself requires interrogation, internal and external, it requires debate, to challenge and be challenged, to be open to criticism, to acknowledge your flaws and to freely offer your talents. To do these things requires a democratic forum, a forum for debate where everyone's opinion is heard and encouraged... to discourage opinion is to crush the spirit. Living with a crushed spirit is, in my opinion, not living.

      The idea of resonance and how it relates to energy is something I'm finalising in another paper... it addresses the relationship between resonance and reason, particularly how human societies were once based on harmony and resonance until the elevation of the scientific method to its current status ... I have no problem with the scientific method or with reason, which is valid when applied to things that can be tested and when it is acknowledged as only one perspective or approach. Unfortunately it is too often used (together with rhetoric) to construct and establish 'truths' around matters of opinion...hence you get the idea of orthodoxy, which literally means 'correct opinion'.

      over 1 year ago report

  36. Peter Ormonde
    Peter Ormonde is a Friend of The Conversation.

    Farmer

    Ms A,

    I suspect that down deep where it counts it is near impossible - even pointless - to try and disentangle the emotional from the rational. It's a blurry business.

    What we choose to accept, to take on trust, to find unacceptable, to regard as important ... are any of these devoid of an emotional resonance? We are not all that mechanical.

    Even at the pointiest end of great science - the most rational of mathematical speculations - there is always a leap - a guess - a hunch ... a bit…

    Read more

    Ms A,

    I suspect that down deep where it counts it is near impossible - even pointless - to try and disentangle the emotional from the rational. It's a blurry business.

    What we choose to accept, to take on trust, to find unacceptable, to regard as important ... are any of these devoid of an emotional resonance? We are not all that mechanical.

    Even at the pointiest end of great science - the most rational of mathematical speculations - there is always a leap - a guess - a hunch ... a bit of imagination as Einstein would put it. And it is that little spark that drives the whole show forward isn't it?

    Perhaps we need a Recommended Daily Allowance of irrationality. No harm in moderation. But just a sprinkle.

    But right now we are being force-fed a diet dripping with unreasonableness, idiocy and irrationality. Like our clogged arteries, our neurones are pumping industrial sludge about.

    See there's probably a month's worth of adult dolt dose in your average Andrew Blot column for example. Perhaps a three month serve in a single issue of the Weekend Orstrayun. Should we tax it? Plain packaging? Or just put clear labels warning of excessive levels of silliness ahead? Perhaps photos of regular readers and the damage done. Recommending a book for balance.

    Some folks would even think I was being silly. Imagine that!

    over 1 year ago report

And allowing for politics and adapting yourself to some popular beliefs is not doing a peer review.
