  38. Simon Batterbury

    Associate Professor at University of Melbourne

    I am delighted to see Patrick's article featuring so prominently.

    I am not all that interested in the vaccination examples, which receive too much of an airing already (especially here). But on the conclusion, <i> 'So next time you hear someone declare they’re entitled to their opinion, ask them why they think that. Chances are, if nothing else, you’ll end up having a more enjoyable conversation that way.'<i/> I wondered how that might work in other areas.

    On skepicism about anthropogenic…

    Read more

    I am delighted to see Patrick's article featuring so prominently.

    I am not all that interested in the vaccination examples, which receive too much of an airing already (especially here). But on the conclusion, <i> 'So next time you hear someone declare they’re entitled to their opinion, ask them why they think that. Chances are, if nothing else, you’ll end up having a more enjoyable conversation that way.'<i/> I wondered how that might work in other areas.

    On skepicism about anthropogenic climate change, yes - it works. You can discount the views of the small number of (often) engineers, geologists, pro-free-market entrepreneurs and other frequent commentators like Monckton using unrefereed material who decry the work of climatologists and don't believe them. Often the former have no primary data or solid analysis themselves to offer and lack relevant qualifications and expertise. People who have the qualifications and can show that their work is defensible, gain more respect and have a right to more airtime too. Only a tiny debate on the anthropogenic impact in general remains in climatology itself, between climatologists. 99% in favour of AGW theories.

    But how do we treat issues like indigenous knowledge of the environment, important in the areas I work in? I face situations in which indigenous knowledge of farming in Africa (I worked in the Sahel, where thare are somei food shortages) is challenged by western agronomists. The latter tend to say they they understand pest resistance and social fertility much better and the crop varieties thay produce will outperform local varieties used by local farmers. The farmers find engineered varieties less good because they don't account for labour scheduling in farming, suboptimal field conditions, and so-on. People like me, with a PhD and years of study in this area, disagree with other people with a PhD and years of study in this area. That's the debate on the science and on knowledge and expertise. Fine.

    But what we do with farmer's knowledge? They write no papers, do not conduct scientific experiments in a field trial setting, and are not invited to agronomy conferences. But they have managed to feed their families for generations and have huge knowlege of farming. Is it correct, as we do, to assign only post-hoc scientific validity to their work , and to their indigenous experimentation, by publishing and fieldwork, without having open debate in which they can participate (and in which they have no interest in their practical knowledge being heard)?

    In a struct interpretation of Patrick's line, farmers don't get a seat at the table because they are not credentialled researchers and could not reply in an articulate way as to why their opinions are valid. They can reason by assertion but without hard facts.
    Nonetheless they know more about field conditions than anybody else. How to bring them in? Robert Chambers and others argue via participatory research-action work, but it is not the same thing as treatign all knowledge-holders equally.

    I do find it odd that in this debate I trust the locals who I feel have more valid expertise capable of feeding Sahelian communities. This is because I am an expert on their situations and have lived with them. They don't do trials and work labs on ag stations (about which I am less skilled).

    But with vaccination I trust the scientists. With climate change, ditto.
    In sum, the things missing from the discussion are a) the politics of knowledge, whcih can throw up these inconsistencies and b) use and interpretation of 'practical knowledge' that is not scientific, as in the case above.

    over 1 year ago report

  39. Elizabeth Hart

    Independent Vaccine Investigator

    Further to my previous comments on this discussion thread in relation to vaccination.
    Recently the Australian Academy of Science has entered the vaccination fray with its publication “The Science of Immunisation: Questions and Answers”: http://www.science.org.au/policy/documents/AAS_Immunisation_FINAL_LR_v3.pdf As the Australian Academy of Science has taken it upon itself to engage in this matter, it can expect to be held accountable.
    For example, I have recently forwarded an email to Sir…

    Read more

    Further to my previous comments on this discussion thread in relation to vaccination.
    Recently the Australian Academy of Science has entered the vaccination fray with its publication “The Science of Immunisation: Questions and Answers”: http://www.science.org.au/policy/documents/AAS_Immunisation_FINAL_LR_v3.pdf As the Australian Academy of Science has taken it upon itself to engage in this matter, it can expect to be held accountable.
    For example, I have recently forwarded an email to Sir Gus Nossal, Chair of the Oversight Committee for “The Science of Immunisation: Questions and Answers”, enquiring if disclosure statements for members of The Science of Immunisation Working group, i.e. detailing any possible conflicts of interest, are publicly available on the Australian Academy of Science website.
    My email to Sir Gus Nossal, which includes reference to discussion threads on The Conversation website, i.e. http://theconversation.edu.au/profiles/elizabeth-hart-6978 , can be accessed via this link: http://bit.ly/U3ygHo
    For information, members of the Science of Immunisation Working Group are: Professor Tony Basten (Co-Chair), Professor Francis Carbone, Professor Ian Frazer (Co-Chair), Professor Patrick Holt, Dr Julie Leask, Professor Peter McIntyre, Professor Terry Nolan and Professor Judith Whitworth.
    Members of the Science of Immunisation Oversight Committee are: Sir Gus Nossal (Chair), Professor Ian Gust, Professor Fiona Stanley and Professor Robert Williamson.

    over 1 year ago report

  40. Elizabeth Hart

    Independent Vaccine Investigator

    What is going on at The Conversation? Last night I left a comment on the “No, you’re not entitled to your opinion” thread, and today I discover that my comment has been curtailed, i.e. cutting off the link to my email to Sir Gus Nossal, Chair of the Oversight Committee for the Australian Academy of Science publication “The Science of Immunisation: Questions and Answers”. For the record, here again is the link to my email to Sir Gus Nossal, which also includes reference to discussion threads on…

    Read more

    What is going on at The Conversation? Last night I left a comment on the “No, you’re not entitled to your opinion” thread, and today I discover that my comment has been curtailed, i.e. cutting off the link to my email to Sir Gus Nossal, Chair of the Oversight Committee for the Australian Academy of Science publication “The Science of Immunisation: Questions and Answers”. For the record, here again is the link to my email to Sir Gus Nossal, which also includes reference to discussion threads on The Conversation website: http://bit.ly/U3ygHo
    Looking at other threads, it appears all longer comments have been curtailed. And just when I’d included links to The Conversation threads pertinent to vaccination in my email to Sir Gus Nossal, which I’m circulating via the internet… Is this censorship by sabotage?
    The Conversation’s “Who We Are” page says: “We aim to be a site you can trust”: https://theconversation.edu.au/who_we_are Well my trust in The Conversation, and in the university and research sector, is rapidly diminishing… I don’t think The Conversation, (or others in ‘the establishment’) likes mere laypeople challenging the status quo on vaccination. It’s interesting that most of the threads pertinent to vaccination on The Conversation are closed down very quickly, while most other threads remain open. See for example ‘Study should dispel HPV vaccine myths’: https://theconversation.edu.au/study-should-dispel-hpv-vaccine-myths-9914 ‘Measles outbreak calls for vaccination vigilance’: https://theconversation.edu.au/measles-outbreak-calls-for-vaccination-vigilance-10042 Monday’s medical myth: childhood vaccinations are dangerous: https://theconversation.edu.au/mondays-medical-myth-childhood-vaccinations-are-dangerous-10872 and the list goes on…
    I’m considering my position on this and will be making a formal complaint on this matter.

    over 1 year ago report

    1. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      Elizabeth: This is a bit odd, but a moment ago I could still see the link to your email to Nossal in your previous comment, though I had to click on the 'Read More' button. But now that I'm typing a comment I can't see the 'read more' button anymore. Not quite sure why, but does seem to be a technical glitch of some sort?

      over 1 year ago report

    2. Keith Thomas

      Retired

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      It's all visible to me, too.

      My perception of The Conversation is that, as a topical website it does not have a responsibility to leave its items open indefinitely for comment. After about 10 days, only a few diehards, locked into their own rigid stances are left and there is no "conversation" going on at all, no fresh ideas, just sniping from entrenched positions from long and tedious posts including URLs (perhaps because the poster does not have the courtesy or the ability to summarize them…

      Read more

      It's all visible to me, too.

      My perception of The Conversation is that, as a topical website it does not have a responsibility to leave its items open indefinitely for comment. After about 10 days, only a few diehards, locked into their own rigid stances are left and there is no "conversation" going on at all, no fresh ideas, just sniping from entrenched positions from long and tedious posts including URLs (perhaps because the poster does not have the courtesy or the ability to summarize them for other readers). After the first couple of days, most posts are not responses to the article; indeed many show no sign of the writer having read or understood the article, and they are responses to responses and drift way "off topic" into battles that can be found at many other sites and even including paragraph plagiarized from other sites. I admit to having played this game a bit myself, but always with a twinge of guilt and a realization that it's more for my ego than as a genuine contribution to a conversation in a civil society.

      If readers/visitors to The Conversation have not made their point within 10 days or have not discovered the particular thread, that's their lookout. The Conversation provides a daily e-mail alert that enables readers to respond to articles promptly. I would prefer to see The Conversation close off all discussion after 10 days. People who feel badly done by can always search for a sympathetic academic to launch a new topic and a new debate that will take the conversation on beyond where the original topic left it.

      The Conversation has involved subscribers in its design and protocols and will probably continue to do so.

      over 1 year ago report

    3. Elizabeth Hart

      Independent Vaccine Investigator

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      A technical glitch do you think Patrick?
      See below my correspondence with Gus Gollings, Technical Director of The Conversation:
      From: Elizabeth Hart Date: Fri, Jan 11, 2013 at 8:45 AM

      If you had taken the time to look at the screenshots I sent you, you would have seen the [Read more] facility wasn't working.
      Using the read "Newest" comment option this morning, the [Read more] facility is still not working, see screenshot attached.
      What a coincidence…

      From: Elizabeth Hart Date: Fri, Jan 11, 2013 at 8:45 AM
      Gus, re your sarcastic response below...
      If you had taken the time to look at the screenshots I sent you, you would have seen the [Read more] facility wasn't working.
      Using the read "Newest" comment option this morning, the [Read more] facility is still not working, see screenshot attached.
      What a coincidence, just as I'm circulating a document to Sir Gus Nossal http://bit.ly/U3ygHo which includes reference to The Conversation discussion threads pertinent to vaccination which contain my long comments.
      According to you, Gus, people who leave long comments are 'verbose' and 'belabour' and 'aggrandise' their points. It appears that people who challenge the status quo on The Conversation are in a no-win situation. If they're not a so-called 'expert' on a subject the response is: "No, you're not entitled to your opinion": https://theconversation.edu.au/no-youre-not-entitled-to-your-opinion-9978 And if they do go to the trouble of providing an argument to back their opinion, they're accused of aggrandisement, verbosity, and belabouring points...
      There's something really rotten going on here...
      Sincerely
      Elizabeth Hart

      On Thu, Jan 10, 2013 at 11:15 PM, Gus Gollings wrote:
      Dear Elizabeth,
      All comments longer 500 character are truncated so people who aggrandise their points in detail and through verbosity cannot visually overwhelm the threads.
      In cases where comments are truncated in this way, there should also be a "… [Read more]" link which you can click to reveal the entire belaboured point.
      Please let me know you if you require further assistance.
      Regards,
      Gus

    4. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      As someone who regularly writes long, verbose, patience-testing comments here, I really don't see problem with putting long comments behind a 'jump'. It makes comments easier to scan and anyone who wants to read the whole comment can do so. So your letter to Nossal (here: bit.ly/U3ygHo) is perfectly visible for anyone who wants to read it. But you've clearly decided that everything is one big conspiracy, and have no qualms about insinuating the TC admins are up to something 'rotten,' so I doubt you'll be satisfied with that. (Also, if you want people like Nossal to listen to you, maybe don't call people like him "so-called 'experts'". People who have dedicated decades of their life to study and research kind of get offended when people who haven't done the hard yards insist their views are of equivalent standing. Can't imagine why).

      over 1 year ago report

    5. Elizabeth Hart

      Independent Vaccine Investigator

      In reply to Elizabeth Hart

      On the subject of so-called ‘experts’, people who take it upon themselves to dictate poorly evidenced medical interventions can expect to be challenged. Experts/professionals in our society hold a privileged position as trusted advisors. They must be held to account if they abuse their position of trust, e.g. by failing to obtain ‘informed consent’ for medical interventions.
      For example, along with my colleague Bea Mies, I have been campaigning against over-vaccination of companion animals for…

      Read more

      On the subject of so-called ‘experts’, people who take it upon themselves to dictate poorly evidenced medical interventions can expect to be challenged. Experts/professionals in our society hold a privileged position as trusted advisors. They must be held to account if they abuse their position of trust, e.g. by failing to obtain ‘informed consent’ for medical interventions.
      For example, along with my colleague Bea Mies, I have been campaigning against over-vaccination of companion animals for the past four years (i.e. “done the hard yards…”). Here’s a link to a brief summary which also includes a list of hyperlinks to some of the correspondence, submissions and articles we have produced on this topic: http://bit.ly/VcmCLG
      See for example my essay circulated in June 2009 “Over-vaccination of pets – an unethical practice”: http://bit.ly/11sEt5h and my article “Vaccine failure!” which warns there is a potential for maternally derived antibodies (MDA) to interfere with a puppy’s response to core vaccination, and calls upon the World Small Animal Veterinary Association’s (WSAVA) Vaccination Guidelines Group to provide clear and objective advice on optimal puppy vaccination, and an optional titre test confirmation protocol: http://bit.ly/lB9YDH
      As a result of our persistent efforts, change is slowly happening in companion animal vaccination practice. It is a disgrace that members of the public have to be the leaders for change due to the failure of self-interested experts/professionals in the veterinary vaccine industry.
      CHOICE, the consumer watchdog, took up the matter of over-vaccination of pets in August 2010, i.e. “Pet vaccination: Over-vaccinating your pet could be harmful to their health as well as your own hip pocket”: http://bit.ly/VWuu2h
      Over-vaccination of companion animals, and exploitation of pet owners, is big business, worth billions of dollars on an international basis. My experience in this area is informing my investigation into lucrative over-vaccination of humans, as there are parallels to be considered. I’m appalled that people such as Patrick Stokes and others are trying to impede progress on this matter.
      It is also notable that the university and CSIRO funded The Conversation website is determined to ignore the queries I have raised on discussion threads about:
      - the second arbitrary ‘booster’ dose of the live measles/mumps/rubella vaccine: https://theconversation.edu.au/measles-outbreak-calls-for-vaccination-vigilance-10042;
      - questionable universal vaccination of adolescents with a 3 shot vaccine for the low risk HPV virus: https://theconversation.edu.au/catch-cancer-no-thanks-id-rather-have-a-shot-7568;
      - questionable whooping cough ‘boosters’ for a new strain of whooping cough, i.e. how does increasing the numbers of ‘boosters’ of the existing vaccine protect against the new strain?: https://theconversation.edu.au/vaccine-resistant-whooping-cough-takes-epidemic-to-new-level-5959; and
      - the ongoing controversy of ‘lethal flu virus’ development, i.e. the US National Institutes of Health is funding research into making H5N1 more transmissible – does this contravene the Biological Weapons Convention?: https://theconversation.edu.au/censoring-influenza-research-gagging-scientists-could-put-lives-at-risk-4978
      There’s a ‘big picture’ on lucrative over-vaccination which it appears many are reluctant to consider.
      The Australian Academy of Science has now taken it upon itself to enter the vaccination fray with its publication “The Science of Immunisation: Questions and Answers”: http://www.science.org.au/policy/immunisation.html
      The members of the Australian Academy of Science’s Oversight Committee for this publication can look forward to some more questions from me in due course.

      over 1 year ago report

I notice you are using your skills as a philosopher to set up such a situation, do you derive…

    Read more

    Patrick. This has been up for months now, and no doubt you'd be tickled pink because of the lively discussions it has sparked. Isn't it about time to write a piece on the importance of respect and tolerance, seeing that so much barely disguised cyberbullying and mobbing have been targeted on a couple of people dared to present their perspectives which, whether 'correct' or otherwise, dared to dissent here? I notice you are using your skills as a philosopher to set up such a situation, do you derive pleasure out of setting up bullies who take advantage of the eloquent, but ethically problematic, argument you have presented in this piece to demean people simply for daring to partake in this conversation. The argument you have developed here does not pass everyone's muster, and the fact that you're clearly not taking any responsibility for the sophistry you have developed to empower these bullies is doing harm. I think I am entitled to my opinion, which is that I think it is time for you to write another piece. Remember Socrates - he paid for sticking to the noble truth with his life, you need do much, oh so very much less than that!

    over 1 year ago report

    1. Dania Ng

      Retired factory worker

      apologies for the bad prose, this doesn't let me edit.

    2. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

      In reply to Dania Ng

      Hi Dania,

      Could you point to some of this "barely disguised cyberbullying and mobbing"? Are you referring to the discussion here, or elsewhere? Which comments here seem outside the normal cannons of civil debate to you? (Serious question).

      I've recently seen quite a few anti-vaxxers who are prepared to condemn whole swathes of people (up to and including the entire medical profession) of whom they know nothing as corrupt, greedy, and immoral, with no credible evidence to that effect, then…

      Read more

      Hi Dania,

      Could you point to some of this "barely disguised cyberbullying and mobbing"? Are you referring to the discussion here, or elsewhere? Which comments here seem outside the normal cannons of civil debate to you? (Serious question).

      I've recently seen quite a few anti-vaxxers who are prepared to condemn whole swathes of people (up to and including the entire medical profession) of whom they know nothing as corrupt, greedy, and immoral, with no credible evidence to that effect, then call anyone who points out how weak their arguments are a 'bully' or worse. I find this curious. Apparently impugning the character of tens of thousands of strangers on the basis of stunningly unlikely conspiracy theories is ok, but telling someone that their opinion is not as valid as someone with degrees and professional experience on a topic is abuse.

      Just on Socrates, a couple of years ago I was teaching a class on the Apology [for anyone reading this who doesn't know it, it's Plato's account of Socrates' ultimately unsuccessful defence on charges of impeity and corrupting youth], and had a chance to try out an electronic voting system in class. At the start of the class I asked the students to vote on the question "Given the laws in place at the time, were the Athenians right to condemn Socrates to death?" I then got them to vote again on the same question at the end of the lecture. At the end, slightly more students were in favour of execution than at the start! Socrates may be long gone, but his power to annoy people enough to make them want to kill him apparently lives on :)

      over 1 year ago report

    3. Dania Ng

      Retired factory worker

      In reply to Dania Ng

      Patrick. Thanks for responding so swiftly. This forum is not your class. We are not in the student - lecturer mode. I have absolutely no problem with an article which outlines a method for how a good argument should be constructed. I have no problem either with a discussion on how one needs to provide a system of acceptable evidence to back ones argument with. What I do have a problem with is the incivility which these arguments have prompted toward those who dared to confront the consensus here…

      Read more

      Patrick. Thanks for responding so swiftly. This forum is not your class. We are not in the student - lecturer mode. I have absolutely no problem with an article which outlines a method for how a good argument should be constructed. I have no problem either with a discussion on how one needs to provide a system of acceptable evidence to back ones argument with. What I do have a problem with is the incivility which these arguments have prompted toward those who dared to confront the consensus here and elsewhere. There is no reason why one cannot contradict a belief held by someone else, and yet still do so in a respectful manner.
      As one who has pointed out some regular commentators on TC as bullies (which I think you mean in your veiled comments), I have seen how your 'rules' of argument empower some, yet disempower others. I know that some of the opinions of medicos and scientists have been challenged here, and I have done this myself. However, I can see that they have been challenged where they tell untruths, or stretch and misreperesent evidence to suit certain ideological perspective. I also see how 'evidence' is manufactured, and represented simply on the apparent basis that the 'experts know better'.
      Above here I see Maryl Dorey being ridiculed and abused by people, who set upon her personally in the manner in which starving vultures descend on a corpse. I happen not to agree with what she stands and argues for. Standing back from it all, so to speak, what stands out for me is that she has been civil and tried her best to explain her position, such as it is. In response, there were few attempts to be civil to her in return. Comments such as, "You are a fringe dweller (even though you clearly don't see yourself as one). Your opinion on vaccination is as valid as a flat Earther", "Maybe if you had the tools to properly evaluate reality you wouldn't be such a crackpot", etc.. Then followed the paternalistic comments by the 'experts' who so much like to put lay people down for holding some opinions. Then there were those demanding some commentators hold qualifications before they could comment, and so on. Lastly, I was prompted over to this thread by the comment which Michael J. I. Brown made on the thread under his recent article: "When it comes to what to believe, I very much agree with http://theconversation.edu.au/no-youre-not-entitled-to-your-opinion-9978";. Keeping in mind what this chap believes, how is it that he refers to your article here to justify his stance, Patrick? Apparently he believes that it is mainly those scientists over 50 who are providing the science which 'deniers' of his 'real' science that are problematic - hence the title of his paper, and the statement: "As elderly scientists fade from view [i.e., die] and aren’t replaced by credible alternatives, the public debate will stop questioning the science" [that is, his 'science']. You see what your article is justifying, Patrick?
      [Did you also tell your students that the city build a statue to honour Socrates after his death?]

      over 1 year ago report

    4. Sue Ieraci

      Public hospital clinician

      In reply to Dania Ng

      Ms Ng - you seem to be having a different discussion to the one many others are having on this thread.

      The premise of the article is that, if one is to present an opinion and have it seen as valid, it needs to be backed up with evidence,a nd the evidence needs to be credible.

      The author has used the example of Australian anti-vaccinationists, with Ms Dorey as (recently resigned) leader (since 1994). Certainly Ms Dorey appears to be reasonable in her tone on this particular thread, but many…

      Read more

      Ms Ng - you seem to be having a different discussion to the one many others are having on this thread.

      The premise of the article is that, if one is to present an opinion and have it seen as valid, it needs to be backed up with evidence,a nd the evidence needs to be credible.

      The author has used the example of Australian anti-vaccinationists, with Ms Dorey as (recently resigned) leader (since 1994). Certainly Ms Dorey appears to be reasonable in her tone on this particular thread, but many who comment here are probably aware of her previous comments, accusing the entire medical profession of conspiring with "Big Pharma" to harm children, claiming that no vaccine has ever benefited anyone, and describing vaccination as "rape with full penetration". These comments are well-documented - there is no need to take my word for it.

      In that context, it's hard to take Ms Dorey;s measured tone seriously.

      In the context of vaccination, the discussion and its conclusions can influence the health of children, and the public health of the community. This is more serious than discussing whether Socrates should have been condemned, or whether Lance Armstrong deserves his medals - it's about the health of children, and the type of public dishonesty that can threaten that.

      over 1 year ago report

    5. Dania Ng

      Retired factory worker

      In reply to Dania Ng

If you'd kindly write it for me, I will be most happy to post it up as if it is something I wish to say. You're in control.

      over 1 year ago report

    6. Darin Cairns

      logged in via Facebook

      In reply to Dania Ng

      Dania I have spent a very entertaining hours reading this conversation. I have worked in the field of Autism and early intervention for 15 plus years. I have seen so much nonsense with no concern for outcome based data or at least rationale inform therapy based on scientific studies, pushed onto parents lacking the training in science to tell the difference. Often those pushing these therapies etc actively push parents away from proven approaches or at least those that collect data by dissing…

      Read more

      Dania I have spent a very entertaining hours reading this conversation. I have worked in the field of Autism and early intervention for 15 plus years. I have seen so much nonsense with no concern for outcome based data or at least rationale inform therapy based on scientific studies, pushed onto parents lacking the training in science to tell the difference. Often those pushing these therapies etc actively push parents away from proven approaches or at least those that collect data by dissing science or making out some sort of 'conspiracy'. I have seen this has cost people their homes and children their future. It also implies those of us following science as humbly as we can are actually some sort of profiteers or heartless egoists. Its pretty nasty stuff at times.

      I won't get drawn into the MMR debate (partly because I have seen enough kids WITHOUT the MMR come to me with a Dx of ASD) and partly because frankly Ms Dorey refuses to play by the rules she asks of everyone else. She will not take responsibility for her claims (even though she challenged people to provide evidence of these unscientific and harmful claims and then refused to acknowledge the posters who responded to her exactly as she demanded). Also, she and those seemingly positing in support will not cite references with the level of responsibility Sue Ieraci showed. (Were you not horrified and offended to find that when she actually investigated the said reference offered as proof it failed at almost all levels to be what the poster claimed? This is as low as it gets in scientific debate - it is akin to lying. I see this all the time where 'thought' pieces are referenced as evidence or its not even about the topic at hand. Lastly, she plays into conspiracy theories that defy logic to me. I am a clinical psychologist - I do not trust drug companies that much either. But do you seriously think people who have committed to going through the often humility generating process os training for the sciences (yes it hurts when you realise how many of your opinions are really just emotion and baggage and you are not as smart as you think you are - nor is the world so black and white as it seemed) are just seeking power and status as Ms Dorey implies?

      Lastly, there is nothing elitest in pointing out that all opinions are not equal. Of course they are not. My dad is an electrician. I ask him for his thoughts on energy saving lighting for my home and pay scant regard to my neighbour who seems to think he knows everything and is qualified in nothing but a lot of time on Google. Conversely, my father listens to me when curious about strategies to promote development in my nephew who has a Dx of ASD. There is nothing elitest in that.

      Please bear something else in mind. All the scientists are taught to be critical of each other. We are trained it is not personal and we really don't take it as such - even when it hurts. The idea must stand up to the challenges of the scientific method and judgements given by the data. That is what I see here in the discussion, scientists demanding that ideas stand up. I see nothing particularly personal that is not matched by Ms Dorey. Indeed she seems to be using such claims as a way of dodging replying to the astute questions and evidence presented to her.

      Lastly - all the people with science training were once laypeople. None of the laypeople (who indeed may be VERY intelligent - my dad is a genius I suspect) have been scientifically trained. So could the lay people, instead of taking what looks like an anti intellectual stance at times, perhaps at least acknowledge they are not in the same position to comment on science, its methods and its culture and show some of the humility they claim they are not getting from the 'elitests'?

      Of course this is purely an opinion... Discourse is important. But reason, evidence and data must be the judge in the end. IMHO

      Cheers

      Darin

      over 1 year ago report

    7. Dania Ng

      In reply to Dania Ng

      Thanks for the thoughtful comment, Darin. Perhaps it may surprise you to hear this, but I don't actually attack science, I think you'll see from what I have written that I never do this, and that's simply because I believe science is an extremely useful method of making sense of our physical world. What I feel quite strongly about is the tendency for some scientists to use scientifically-derived knowledge for political ends, where they manipulate what is to be counted as legitimate knowledge. I have…

      Read more

      Thanks for the thoughtful comment, Darin. Perhaps it may surprise you to hear this, but I don't actually attack science, I think you'll see from what I have written that I never do this, and that's simply because I believe science is an extremely useful method of making sense of our physical world. What I feel quite strongly about is the tendency for some scientists to use scientifically-derived knowledge for political ends, where they manipulate what is to be counted as legitimate knowledge. I have written elsewhere about scientism. I am not at all in favour of not vaccinating children. But I do have a healthy scepticism of Western medicine (pun intended), and I thread cautiously around medicos. This is derived from personal experience, meeting and working with so many incompetent nurses and doctors in the course of my life (though of course I have also met some incredibly talented ones). Prior to here, I don't recall hearing of Ms Dorey and the organisation she worked with. I simply noted the mobbing aimed at her comments on this thread as an example of the effects of the article on which she commented. I was quite keen to get the author here to address some of the effects of his article, which has spread beyond here. For instance, I mentioned how another author for this publication even referred to it so to justify his approach that implied we ought to cherish the future, when scientists who are over 50 now will all be dead (expressing it as "one funeral at a time"), this apparently to do away with sceptics of the big bang theory, among others. Science at its best?

    13. account deleted

      In reply to Dania Ng

      Ignorant buffoon. Well done you for making her point for her so clearly.

      Dania, a conversation is, at it's best, a wide-ranging discussion of ideas. Similarly, a degree is meant to provide training in thinking usefully about ideas and situations one has not previously encountered. Sadly, in some cases this admirable intent produces instead narrow-minded, self-important fools, capable only of reiterating pre-digested ideas from "approved" sources.

      Sadly, the vast growth in tertiary education has produced far more of that type than the genuinely capable thinkers that is its express purpose. Those buffoons will be our next generation of leaders, when all they have learnt is how to follow.

      In my view, it is those people who Patrick Stokes should have directed his piece at, but by offering the dog-whistle of an "unapproved" viewpoint from Dorey, all he did was encourage a pack to form.

  44. Liz Parker

    Researcher

    I find irony in the fact this article was written by a philosopher with an especial interest in Søren Kierkegaard! Was it not Kierkegaard who discussed subjectivity? He argued that doubt is an element of faith and that it is impossible to gain any objective certainty about the existence of God - the best one could do would be to believe the probability that religious doctrines are true, but believing such doctrines, only because they seem likely to be true, does not demonstrate genuine religious-ness…

    Read more

    I find irony in the fact this article was written by a philosopher with an especial interest in Søren Kierkegaard! Was it not Kierkegaard who discussed subjectivity? He argued that doubt is an element of faith and that it is impossible to gain any objective certainty about the existence of God - the best one could do would be to believe the probability that religious doctrines are true, but believing such doctrines, only because they seem likely to be true, does not demonstrate genuine religious-ness (faith); faith requires an absolute, subjective, commitment to the entire religious doctrine...

    The desire for vaccines to be perfect protection for the masses is much like religious dogma. One must turn a blind eye to any research which demonstrates a flaw in vaccine perfection, and avert one's gaze from the list of known neurotoxins, teratogens, mutagens, poisons, aldulterants, and other toxins listed as ingredients in the vaccine concoction;and take, as an article of faith, that, once injected into the human body, these items become "safe." One must take, on faith, that the harm to some is acceptable because the many are saved.

    What the dissenting opinion recognizes, is that simply reading SUMMARIES is NOT the same as actually reading (and understanding) the construct of the study, how it was performed, and from what the soundbites were derived...

    For example, the Danish study (oft-cited as "proof" thimerosal is not linked to Autism) clearly does not prove this at all - the initial research was performed using only the in-patient population, after removal of mercury, they included the country's entire populous in counting the numbers with Autism (apples to oranges) even if this were not the case, the Danes used significantly fewer vaccines and they were administered much later in life than occurs in the US...Again, apples and oranges.

    Many "truths," touted by vaccine-supporters are not supported by fact:
    For instance, regarding polio, consider the following from http://christianparty.net/polio.htm) -

    Dr. Jonas Salk , creator of the polio vaccine, says that analysis indicates that the live virus vaccine in use since the 1960's is the principle, if not sole cause of all polio cases since 1961. Polio was pretty obscure before the twentieth century. There'd been some outbreaks in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, and most victims had been under the age of four. Note that these polio epidemics in earlier centuries ended on their own without the Salk and Sabin Vaccines

    Polio: 33,300 total cases of polio and 33 cases of paralytic polio in 1950 led to 9 deaths, but AFTER the Salk Vaccine had been widely implemented in 1960, paralytic polio cases increased 80 fold to 2,525

    http://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/hus_93.pdf

    Thanks to the Polio vaccine, "98 million Americans were also contaminated with monkey viruses [i.e., SV40 from the Salk and Sabin Vaccines] and may be one reason why there has been an explosion of cancer, new infectious agents and other new immune and neurological disorders among the baby boomers born between 1941 and 1961."

    Undoubtedly, the polio vaccine culture was the origin of HPV; and now we have a vaccine for the disease cause by another vaccine...Par for the course, the HPV vaccine is maiming young women at an alarming rate; literally causing them to drop like flies...Go big pharma!

    Where is your PROOF that any of the vaccines actually are effective? Historical charts indicate the sharp decline of each disease supposedly cured by vaccine well prior to the introduction of the vaccine...Here's a nice summary of history for you: http://www.whale.to/vaccines/decline1.html

    And about "herd immunity," that is a serious farce...Vaccines do not prevent individuals from contracting or carrying the disease they "prevent;" as a matter of fact, by design, individuals MUST regularly be exposed to the virus' to maintain vaccine immunity (much as unvaccinated individuals, exposed to the same circulating virus' develop immunity), otherwise the vaccine immunity wanes; this is why some "fully vaccinated" individuals still contract the full-blown disease and others suffer mild cases. If you read the vaccine literature, vaccine immunity is only temporal and can last up to a number of years; or not. So basically, one must wonder, if both natural- and vaccine-immunity are created and preserved by exposure to the same virus', and both vaccinated and un-vaccinated individuals run the risk of contracting these virus', then why not get rid of the medical procedure middle-man and return to nature's method of immunity (which, once conferred is life-long)? After all, if one DTaP, MMR, Varicella, etc. vaccine doesn't work the first time, why will a whole series work any better?

    If God made us in His image, I would think our bodies were already designed perfectly to cope with whatever Nature had in store...The issue seems to be what Man makes and introduces...In the case of vaccines, up to 32 shots by 24 months of age?! Seriously!!!
    http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/recs/schedules/downloads/child/2009/09_0-6yrs_schedule_pr.pdf

    It is interesting to note that, despite a rash of measles in 2008 ("Sixty-three of the 64 patients were unvaccinated or had unknown or undocumented vaccination status, one patient had documentation of receiving 2 doses of MMR vaccine...One was a child aged 12 months who was exposed in a physician's office when receiving a routine dose of measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine.") Some were hospitalized, but NONE died.

    With regard to the mumps, one-third of the 900 people with the mumps in Iowa were vaccinated, as a matter of fact, CDC officials said that most of the confirmed cases are among 16- to 22-year-olds who've gotten two doses of the mumps vaccine...So now, they are considering adding ANOTHER MMR to the schedule...

    It is also interesting to learn that those vaccinated against the flu are more frequently hospitalized...Three times more frequently.

    Returning to Kierkegaard, "What the age needs is awakening. And therefore someday, not only my writings but my whole life, all the intriguing mystery of the machine will be studied and studied." Until vaccines are truly studied, using sound construct, and appropriate control groups, there will be dissenting opinions; and, accordingly, decisions made by individuals using either subjective faith or objective criteria...

    about 1 year ago report

    2. Patrick Stokes

      One point I can comment on though: "If God made us in His image, I would think our bodies were already designed perfectly to cope with whatever Nature had in store...The issue seems to be what Man makes and introduces..." Obviously that argument only works if one accepts that a) there's a God who's b) perfect and c…

      Read more

      Decent summary of Kierkegaard, Liz. The rest of your points have all been debunked elsewhere I'm afraid, but I'll leave it to someone with the relevant training to go through that.

      One point I can comment on though: "If God made us in His image, I would think our bodies were already designed perfectly to cope with whatever Nature had in store...The issue seems to be what Man makes and introduces..." Obviously that argument only works if one accepts that a) there's a God who's b) perfect and c) made us in His image. So it's not going to have much purchase with those of us who don't accept a) in the first place! But even if there is a God, it's straining credulity to say that the human body is perfectly designed for its environment such that every instance of the body failing to cope is down to human intervention. What human intervention is the cause of, say, short-sightedness? The fact that childbirth hurts so much? The fact that knees are so prone to wearing out? To simply assert that these things *must* somehow be down to something humans do 'wrong' even though we have no idea what that might be does seem like more like an article of faith than a reasoned belief.

      about 1 year ago report

    5. Emma Anderson

      Artist and Science Junkie

      The knees.

      As far as I know, Homo Habilis were using fire first. Fire was one of many steps that changed human culture and physiology to it's modern forms.

      Modern knees descend from that.

      It could also be said that because of fire.....we have reading in poor light, and thus, short-sightedness.

    6. Christopher Chen

      Software Engineer

      In reply to Liz Parker

      It's a bit of a leap to say that fire (and other early human inventions) caused us to evolve weaker legs. Even after we shifted from hunter-gatherer tribes into larger agricultural societies, we used our legs with the same kind of regularity and necessity up until perhaps the last century or so. (A couple of centuries seems hardly enough time to noticeably change human physiology.)

      about 1 year ago report

    7. Emma Anderson

      Artist and Science Junkie

      In reply to Liz Parker

      On the contrary our knees are probably stronger but there hasn't been enough time for them to get strong enough to counter-act the effects of:

      1. Advancing life expectancy associated with not eating raw meat made possible with fire
      2. Changes in Vitamin D levels contributing to muscular and skeletal strength (reduction) associated with performing more activities at night and moving to colder climates made possible with fire.
      3. Changes in weight distribution associated with changes in food…

      Read more

      On the contrary our knees are probably stronger but there hasn't been enough time for them to get strong enough to counter-act the effects of:

      1. Advancing life expectancy associated with not eating raw meat made possible with fire
      2. Changes in Vitamin D levels contributing to muscular and skeletal strength (reduction) associated with performing more activities at night and moving to colder climates made possible with fire.
      3. Changes in weight distribution associated with changes in food consumption that coincide with changes in standing in a more erect position (more weight on the knees) that was furthered with the use of fire.

      We're seeing more knee problems these days because

      1. Life expectancy is at it's highest.
      2. Vitamin D blood serum levels are at it's lowest
      3. We're eating more food and exercising less (weakening muscles) but able to stand fully erect, and doing so without transferring that weight outward from the knee through movement, because lifestyles are more sedentary.

      All of these are long term consequences of cultural shifts that began with fire. But in evolutionary terms, it's the short term. If we survive another million years or so, our knees will change, although our cultures change much faster than that.

      about 1 year ago report

  45. Charles Szmanda

    Patent Agent

    One comment I have on the above article is that we should we should reject arguments from authority. "This guy is an expert and he says X." Our job in such a discussion is to make sure that the "expert" has also gone through some sort of process, whether it is analysis of hard data or evidence, or logical analysis.

    In the States, during the influenza epidemic of 1918 and following, the Surgeon General advised that sufferers should take Aspirin and go to bed. The science behind the advice was not understood other than the aspirin lowered temperatures and, by going to bed, sufferers could avoid spreading the disease. Still, it was the right advice and saved many lives, despite the deaths caused by the high doses of aspirin prescribed at the time. In that case, the best guess of the "expert" was pretty good. There was at least something behind his opinion besides a guess.

    about 1 year ago report

  46. Sandra Mornington

    Nurse

    At the risk of starting another fire, I could not fail to notice some interesting parallels between this debate and those surrounding another series of articles in The Conversation- the articles about biomedical research using animals.

    http://theconversation.com/scientific-research-on-primates-what-do-we-owe-animals-like-us-11673

    http://theconversation.com/the-elusive-ethics-of-animal-ethics-committees-10056

    I will not, on purpose, go into the more emotional aspects of this debate. However…

    Read more

    At the risk of starting another fire, I could not fail to notice some interesting parallels between this debate and those surrounding another series of articles in The Conversation- the articles about biomedical research using animals.

    http://theconversation.com/scientific-research-on-primates-what-do-we-owe-animals-like-us-11673

    http://theconversation.com/the-elusive-ethics-of-animal-ethics-committees-10056

    I will not, on purpose, go into the more emotional aspects of this debate. However, a key aspect of the argument from those proposing a ban on animal experimentation is the argument that studies using animals are not telling us anything useful- for example, that they do not lead to any cures to human disease, either in the short or long term, and are just wasting time and resources. The justification often involves the idea that anything worth doing can now be done either in vitro or using simulations.

    Against this viewpoint, there are voices from various scientists and people in the health professions (as well as a few people who have benefited from treatments), who support the view that animal-based research is still very much necessary (e.g., you cannot simulate something if you don't know how it works, etc.), and that a ban would cause a lot of damage down the track.

    These debates often evolve towards something similar to what we see here- whether the opinion of a member of the public, however well informed they believe to be, versus the opinion of the specialists. The same questions are often asked (what kind of degree you have, etc.). IN adition, like this debate, the minority position can always refer to the opinion of a few dissenting scientists and scientific papers for support, but the overwhelming majority says otherwise.

    Is this also a case where one opinion should not be weighted the same as the other?

    about 1 year ago report

    1. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

      In reply to Sandra Mornington

      Good point Sandra. I'd add though that the animal research debate is further complicated by the ethical issues involved, which also generates a fair bit of equivocation on the word 'necessary'. There's at least two senses of 'necessary' at work in those discussions: 'necessary' in the sense of "if we don't do x we won't be able to answer the question properly'' and necessary in the sense of "if we don't do x the moral consequences will be worse than if we do x." I can understand why many people on…

      Read more

      Good point Sandra. I'd add though that the animal research debate is further complicated by the ethical issues involved, which also generates a fair bit of equivocation on the word 'necessary'. There's at least two senses of 'necessary' at work in those discussions: 'necessary' in the sense of "if we don't do x we won't be able to answer the question properly'' and necessary in the sense of "if we don't do x the moral consequences will be worse than if we do x." I can understand why many people on both sides of that debate feel the need to appeal to the first sense of 'necessary', but that seems to be avoiding the question that really matters: is a given piece of research worth the death and/or suffering of a certain number of animals of a particular type? I think people avoid that question because they don't want to get into an argument over whether nonhuman animal lives have intrinsic value, and if so how much - but if we're going to talk seriously about the ethics of animal research, working out what we think animal lives are worth and weighing that against potential research outcomes seems unavoidable.

      about 1 year ago report

    2. Sandra Mornington

      Nurse

      In reply to Sandra Mornington

      Hi Patrick

      Thanks for replying. This is exactly why I decided not to discuss what I referred to as "the more emotional aspects". The moral argument ("is a given piece of research worth the death and/ or suffering...") is someting I don't think we can hope to solve objectively, since the "moral imperative" argument is applied by both sides of that debate. It will always boil down to a person's subjective judgement of how many mice are worth the life of a person, and what if this person is a criminal…

      Read more

      Hi Patrick

      Thanks for replying. This is exactly why I decided not to discuss what I referred to as "the more emotional aspects". The moral argument ("is a given piece of research worth the death and/ or suffering...") is someting I don't think we can hope to solve objectively, since the "moral imperative" argument is applied by both sides of that debate. It will always boil down to a person's subjective judgement of how many mice are worth the life of a person, and what if this person is a criminal, and what if the person is your daughter, and is a fish or a fly worth the same level of rights as a rat, etc. In any case, it would probably not belong in this thread (as the risk of having it hijacked...).

      However, there is something in that debate that, in my view, can be answered objectively, and that has a clear parallel with what we are addressing here: when the Animal Rights groups state, as an integral part of their reasoning, that animal research can be discontinued without damage, should we attribute the same value to their viewpoint, as opposed to the viewpoint of the vast amajority of scientists and health authorities?

      I think that this is a critical point. If one takes the Animal Rights viewpiont as truth, then the moral question is obviated, since there will be no damage to human lives incurred by stopping animal research. In other words, no one is likely to suffer or die unnecessarily in the future, from the lack of progress in medical science. On the other hand, if their viewpoint is clearly open to major criticism on objective grounds (e.g. by stopping animal research you are denying people from a chance to be cured, or to recover better from an accident), then the moral argument for stopping animal research has to be restrcutured accordingly.

      about 1 year ago report

    3. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

      In reply to Sandra Mornington

      Thanks Sandra, very well-stated - and yes I think you're quite right about that. I'd probably be considerably more optimistic about the prospects for the moral argument, but then I'm a philosopher, I would say that :)

      about 1 year ago report

  48. Colleen van der Horst

    logged in via email @tpg.com.au

    Yes, Patrick. While everyone can have an opinion, if they expect others to listen, they need to provide informed argument. There is a trend toward blurring beliefs or preferences with evidence. You might hear people say "I don't believe in immunization; "I'm against fluoride in water" or "I don't believe in climate change," as though this of itself should stand. What is this but an expression of feeling, instinctive preference or prejudice? Talk back radio supplies plentiful evidence of this…

    Read more

    Yes, Patrick. While everyone can have an opinion, if they expect others to listen, they need to provide informed argument. There is a trend toward blurring beliefs or preferences with evidence. You might hear people say "I don't believe in immunization; "I'm against fluoride in water" or "I don't believe in climate change," as though this of itself should stand. What is this but an expression of feeling, instinctive preference or prejudice? Talk back radio supplies plentiful evidence of this. The ABC host, Jon Faine, was actually censured for demanding a speaker provide "evidence" for an opinion. We seem to have lost the filter that once cautioned people against speaking publically on subjects of which they have no knowledge. It is a dangerous trend which despite all the technological progress, could catapult us back into the dark ages. Do we really have to listen to an unfounded opinion such as: Barack Obama is not an American citizen? No. As Patrick Stokes argues, not unless you can argue a case based on research, evidence and reason. Or at least we should not be required to listen to it.

    about 1 year ago report

  50. Clancy Wilmott

    PhD Researcher

    While I understand and agree with the point being made by the author of this article, at the same time there needs to be a balance. The scientific community, though knowledgeable, is still schooled in particular ways of thinking which are dominated by particular approaches to research. Scientific reasoning, and even medicine, are still relatively new principles and have a tendency to become dogmatic and single-minded with regard to people (and this has been particularly prevalent in the history of…

    Read more

    While I understand and agree with the point being made by the author of this article, at the same time there needs to be a balance. The scientific community, though knowledgeable, is still schooled in particular ways of thinking which are dominated by particular approaches to research. Scientific reasoning, and even medicine, are still relatively new principles and have a tendency to become dogmatic and single-minded with regard to people (and this has been particularly prevalent in the history of psychiatric medicine).

    Within this particular debate there also has to be room for accepting the value of other ways of knowing and understanding the world. Yes, there has been considerable evidence that disproves that vaccinations are linked to autism. However, that the arguments of the AVN seem to ring true to a large number of people, despite the lack of scientific evidence, cannot simply be dismissed as the ramblings of a few lunatics who aren't entitled to their opinions. Rather, I would argue, they need to be properly investigated in a broader, and perhaps even, non-scientific context. From where does this distrust of medicine and scientific rationalism originate? What is medical discourse taking away from people's experiences? Why are people prepared to potentially put their children at risk in order to resist the powerful expectations of the medical community, pharmaceutical companies and government interventionism?

    No, not everyone is entitled to their opinion, but it also needs to be recognised that for a long time those who have enjoyed absolute recognition and little outside challenge (the Christian churches, for instance) have often fallen into a laziness of thinking and of self-criticism which means that they all-too-easily dismiss the experiences of others as 'lunacy', 'ignorance', 'hysteria', 'deviance', 'exceptions' and which contemporarily are gradually being scientifically transformed into 'outliers', 'statistical anomalies', 'small minorities' and so on.

    about 1 year ago report

  51. Sabre truthtiger

    Truth teller

    Wow. this article is an overt propaganda piece.

    It starts off well describing how opinions on technical and science-based issues should be backed up by scientific, facts-based argumentation otherwise they're invalid.

    However it then talks about man made global warming skeptics and 'anti-vaccination' proponents as being characteristic of the uninformed and scientifically erroneous.

    In fact it tends to be completely the opposite.. You will note when it comes to man made global warming the…

    Read more

    Wow. this article is an overt propaganda piece.

    It starts off well describing how opinions on technical and science-based issues should be backed up by scientific, facts-based argumentation otherwise they're invalid.

    However it then talks about man made global warming skeptics and 'anti-vaccination' proponents as being characteristic of the uninformed and scientifically erroneous.

    In fact it tends to be completely the opposite.. You will note when it comes to man made global warming the skeptics back up their arguments with scientific facts and logical arguments. There is overwhelming evidence against significant man made global warming yet the Alarmists have provided no evidence to support it. They merely have speculation about hidden heat content in the oceans causing the current 17 year hiatus in temperature rises. ARGO buoys have shown no such hidden heat.
    The IPCC computer models are all drastically wrong, massively exaggerating predicted temperature rises 2 to 3 fold above that of reality. They predict positive feedbacks in their models which drives their alarmist apocalyptic warnings.
    These positive feedbacks are proven not to exist, or to be counterbalanced by equal or greater negative feedbacks by empirical data.
    There is no mid tropospheric hotspot predicted by the models from extra evaporation of water, this flat out disproves their positive feedback theory. ERBE satellites have shown that Outgoing Longwave Radiation goes up with warming not down as their models suggest, also disproving their positive feedback theory.
    Low level cloud albedo, cumulonimbic convective subsidence and radiative mass sinking due to increased warm atmospheric layer height from thermal expansion radiates more energy into space as surface temperatures rise.
    if you add to this the climate record whereby the Mediaeval Warm Period is proven to have been globally hotter than today with much less CO2, the fact that CO2 rise lags 800 years behind temperature rise in the climate record (Vostok ice cores) showing temperature drives CO2 not the other way round, the fact that it hasn't warmed in 17 years despite rising CO2, the fact that Antarctica is at record levels and the Arctic has mostly recovered from it's 2007 minimum, the fact that sea level rise has not increased, that sea temperature has not significantly increased, not at any rate anywhere near enough to account for the warmists' hidden heat theory, you realise all the evidence is against the Alarmists.

    If you also take the huge amounts of fraud and outright lying by scientists and the media you realise this is an agenda, it's all about power and politics and not science.
    Mann's infamous hockeystick where he gave hundreds of times the weighting to one faulty set of pine proxy data as he did to the others thus causing a 'hockeystick' shape in order to get rid of the Mediaeval Warm Period that was shown to exist in all the other proxies is the prime example. The removal of colder high altitude stations suddenly from collation of data to create a warming effect, the tampering of data as in Darwin Australia to 'fudge' the data upwards, the placement of temperature stations next to hot asphalt urban facilities, the crossing out of an earlier IPCC report conclusion which stated there was no discernible human influence and replacing it with the opposite 'there is a discernible human influence' etc shows the depths to which the highly politicised alarmists will sink to because the science doesn't support their conclusions.

    about 1 year ago report

    And as has been noted by others here (very few unfortunately) not all 'bulldust' is wrong. Indeed, Copernicus and others through the years have been proven to be correct, and the reigning authorities at the time (scientific or other) have been proven to be wrong.

  55. David Wright

    Electrician

    This guy is a thought police wannabe. Leave free speech alone, Patrick.

    12 months ago report

    1. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

      In reply to David Wright

      The article has nothing at all to do with free speech David, as it makes very clear. Having a right to speak (which everyone does) is not the same thing as having a right to be taken seriously in every conversation.

      12 months ago report

    2. David Wright

      Electrician

      In reply to David Wright

      It's a rhetorical move to just dismiss people though without refuting them. Remember the chaser, when they accused Lord Monkton of trolling just because he had an opposing view. I think this sort of approach can lead to the suppression of unpopular speech, which is best left out in the open.

      12 months ago report

    3. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

      In reply to David Wright

      Someone like Monkton can say what he likes. But speech is a public act, and that also means we're responsible for what we say; and one of those responsibilities is not pretending to have expertise, or even competence, one does not in fact possess. And it also means caring about whether or not what you say is true (Frankfurt's distinction between 'lying' and 'bullshitting' is very helpful here - the bullshitter just doesn't care, or care enough, if what they say is valid). I don't think we should stop people saying things that aren't true, though we should call them out on it; but at some point when you continually violate these basic rules of discourse, you start to forfeit - perhaps only temporarily - the right to be taken seriously as an interlocutor. And pretending to expertise you don't have is surely such a violation.

      12 months ago report

    4. David Wright

      Electrician

      In reply to David Wright

      What I am saying it that it takes judgement and expertise to perform the "de-legitimising move" from the assessment that the person in question is trolling, bullshitting, or lying.

      It must be done with the utmost caution and not for political, regulatory, religious or other reasons of motivation, but only with regard to the truth.

      I think that human beings probably can't live up to this standard. What you will have if you institute these rules of discourse is that you will in effect get a form of political censorship, the dominance of the view of the majority.

      12 months ago report

    5. Patrick Stokes

      Lecturer in Philosophy at Deakin University

      In reply to David Wright

      Ok, that's a very fair point. I'm not sure I'd be quite so pessimistic but the need for caution is certainly valid.

      12 months ago report

    6. Andy Cameron

      Care giver

      In reply to David Wright

      David, "freedom of speech" is about the relationship between citizens and their state - completely irrelevant to a private house or university classroom.

    8. Peter Ormonde
      Peter Ormonde is a Friend of The Conversation.

      Farmer

      In reply to David Wright

  59. Jena Zelezny

    research for second PhD in Humanities and Social Sciences (Performance Studies/Theatre & Drama/Dramatic Literature/Visual Arts) at La Trobe University

    If we accept that democracy and the privilege of free speech is not only an entitlement but a gift of that democracy, then everyone does have the 'equal' right to express an opinion.

    The quandary presents in the form of what is informed and what is not and the degree to which the information can be viewed as valid or expert. In the media there's the problem of who selects those with the valid or expert view? And does this selection process exclude those who have something important to contribute…

    Read more

    If we accept that democracy and the privilege of free speech is not only an entitlement but a gift of that democracy, then everyone does have the 'equal' right to express an opinion.

    The quandary presents in the form of what is informed and what is not and the degree to which the information can be viewed as valid or expert. In the media there's the problem of who selects those with the valid or expert view? And does this selection process exclude those who have something important to contribute? I suppose, in the case of media views, it is up to the potential contributor to assert their 'opinion' or perspective/interpretation in the form of submissions until the 'selectors' take note and establish that opinion through publication of it.

    Does this process work in the political arena or in academia? In the political arena the evidence would tend to show that it doesn't. In academia? It is quite a tricky and different arena … in my opinion (and it depends upon one's experiences, circumstances … and conditions). Sometimes it's about who you know and not what you know.

    7 months ago report

      Care giver

      I hope this helps.

  61. Lee Hatfield

    logged in via Facebook

    +this article seems to be implying that yoiu have no right to disagree with a scientist, because the person disagreeing with the scientist has not got a degree in that subject.but you can be self taught in any subject that you are very interested in. why are the religious allowed to say any implausible thing they like? mad religious views ruin lots of lives, but society acts as if they are true.
    for instance, why can't people have scientific views you disagree with? scientists are often wrong and frequently change their views anyway.i could write a long list of them but cant be bothered as i'd be here a long time....! it sounds like you are excusing your desire to bully others into believing what you would like them to believe....you would be better to develop plausible reasons for your beliefs and put them on the internet ,etc, do not do it face to face will get bored and agree just to stop you earbashing them,,, as people

    6 months ago report

    1. Dan Chubb

      logged in via Facebook

      In reply to Lee Hatfield

      We don't say anywhere that you have no right to disagree with someone who is more qualified.

      What we do say is that if you want to present your opinion as fact, then you have to be prepared to defend your opinion with evidence.

      This is particularly true when you want to put forward an opinion that is at odds with the vast majority of qualified experts in the field in question. If you want to make a claim that is contrary to the accepted theorum of the day, then you must present exceptional evidence that fits at least these two criteria:

      - It must be predicted by your contrary opinion
      - It must contradict the accepted opinion

      If you are able to do so, then you have my attention.

      6 months ago report

  62. Carmi Turchick

    bus driver

    In principle I agree...but I have some very serious issues with this article.

    First, it essentially makes a fallacy the basis of admission to public discourse. Argument by authority, according to him, should be the way we determine who gets into the media megaphone.

    Second, the expert authorities are often either wrong or dishonest or both. The expert authorities said American Atomics was releasing safe amounts of tritium into the air. My mom had her own authority who said otherwise, my grandfather the former head of the Manhattan Project medical team, but to the media she was just a parent with not even a Bachelors degree. By this professor's reasoning she should have been ignored. In fact she was right and the site was eventually seized by the National Guard, $300,000 of radiated food from the school lunch factory down the block was buried...

    The idea that we can safely rely on the argument by authority fallacy to settle our policy debates is dangerous and absurd.

    4 months ago report

      logged in via Facebook

  63. Jean Chat

    Journalist

    It's always interesting to see how opinions are created. To see how often are they are installed on universities (and later throughout society) through lobbyism from big companies who promotes research along certain very shortsighted and purely economical lines; biased to say the least. This process is all too common. As a journalist BA I did research for an article some years ago on possible damages from vaccinations (which I understand are mandatory in USA. The level of Liberty is higher here in…

    Read more

    It's always interesting to see how opinions are created. To see how often are they are installed on universities (and later throughout society) through lobbyism from big companies who promotes research along certain very shortsighted and purely economical lines; biased to say the least. This process is all too common. As a journalist BA I did research for an article some years ago on possible damages from vaccinations (which I understand are mandatory in USA. The level of Liberty is higher here in Danmark, where I live ;-) ). Some of the statistics on the effect of vaccination were clearly twisted, but since there was big money and votes for politicians involved criticism were underplayed by spin of various kinds.

    An example: many of the doctors were reluctant to report damages where vaccination was suspected by the children's parents - which might explain why the numbers on adverse effects are low in the statistics (by the way, quite a few of the vaccines contained Mercury).

    There's also some research that point to longtime negative effects of vaccinating children, such as arthritis, cancer, asthma, diabetes and cardiac disorders in adulthood.

    One of the doctors in the field whom I interviewed commented on the way the Danish State implements children's vaccination despite certain contradictory indications of the effects (not to mention the whole voluntary aspect): "Spanking!" was her short comment.

    The whole story was back then quite a showcase for me on how the pharmaceutical industry works, especially on creating strong and streamlined opinions in both the general public and inside governmental institutions (that of course also goes for teachers in many public educational institutions). I guess most of us know, that a lot of grey-zone stuff is going on in such areas, but it can be a bit heartbreaking to see employees at universities advocate rather carelessly for biased big company research on health issues.

    And if you yourself lean towards an opinion, that when parents or the press criticizes the Parnassus on these backgrounds, that "they are not entitled to their opinion" - you could yourself also see a doctor to have a similar mental vaccination - if you have not already done so. Cause many people have - and things become a lot easier afterwards. You get an infusion with a potent valid opinion - and thus do not have to think for yourself anymore. Very smart - and cheap.

    I for my part will definitely refuse such mental vaccinations - with the professors permission, of course. Thank you ;-)

    4 months ago report
